Consistent with our election commitments, the government is accelerating the pace of micro‐economic reform. Today the government is announcing major reforms in the petroleum products industry which will increase competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about petrol?

—Would you like to interject again? Do it again for the benefit of all of us, please. Let me say it again: today the government announces major reforms in the petroleum products industry which will increase competition, put downward pressure on petrol prices and benefit consumers, particularly consumers in the rural and regional areas of Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Small business is part of the heart and soul of the value systems of all members of this government. Small businesses are the engine room of the Australian economy. They provide a livelihood for millions of Australian families. They are the single greatest source of jobs and opportunities in our economy. They are the backbone of local communities and neighbourhoods as well as towns throughout regional and rural Australia.

Getting government off the back of small business has been one of our highest priorities since taking office. We are determined to promote the small business sector as a dynamic and expanding generator of jobs, national wealth, economic opportunity and community responsibility. We are re-invigorating it through a range of tax, labour market and deregulatory reforms.

On the tax front, one of our first actions was to cut the provisional tax uplift factor. In the budget, we implemented our promises to provide rollover relief from capital gains tax to allow small businesses to grow. We also provided an exemption for up to half a million dollars on capital gains on the sale of a small business where the proceeds are used for retirement. After listening to small business people, we recently made the scheme even better so that the capital gains tax relief applies not just to those rolling over into like businesses—a change described by the Business Review Weekly as the most significant change to the taxation system affecting the small business sector for decades.

We have already made a start on cutting red tape, regulation and the paperwork that bedevil so many hardworking small business operators. The ABS is reducing the burden of statistical collections on small businesses by 20 per cent. The report of the small business deregulation task force was received on 1 November 1996. That document will be responded to—in full and in a positive fashion—by the government no later than the middle of February 1997.

This government is proud to say that it has put Australian families at the centre of national decision making—whether it be economic policy, social policy service delivery, industrial relations or any other area of government activity. Our more responsible economic management has already delivered great practical relief for families through reductions in home loan interest rates.

But we also took direct action in the budget. Overall, we have cut the tax burden on families by around $1 billion. From the first day of 1997, the first day of the new year, almost two million low and middle income Australian families will benefit from our family tax initiative. For a one-income family earning up to $68,000 a year with two children, one of whom is under five, this will deliver an extra $34 a fortnight.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Through the interjections of the opposition, let me emphasise that this will of course include sole parent families. When it comes to families, we have delivered.

BREAK.PARA: We will make private health insurance more attractive to low and middle income families. From 1 July 1997, families with dependent children will be entitled to receive an incentive of up to $450 per year, paid either as an up-front reduction in their premiums or as a tax rebate. The government also recognises that, for many families, choice means access to quality, affordable child care appropriate to their needs. Our child-care strategy will ensure the continuation of a flexible and responsive child-care sector.

Other measures—including the retirement savings account, superannuation changes such as the low income spouse rebate, lower interest rates and lower inflation—will all ease pressures on families and provide them with more choice about how they live their lives. We also believe that the special work of carers deserves more recognition. In line with our commitments, we have provided significant additional funding for the national respite for carers program to augment existing respite funding and establish carer resource centres throughout Australia.

We know that various pressures produce family breakdown and we want to prevent this wherever possible. We have therefore increased funding for marriage and relationship education and funding to enable community organisations to help people become better parents.

We are addressing the root cause of youth unemployment by establishing the preconditions for real job growth through improved economic management and our regulatory and industrial relations reforms. We are implementing a number of strategies directly targeted at young people which particularly address the development of skills through education and training—for example, in literacy and numeracy—and through school-based vocational education.

Our training and industrial relations reforms will encourage the expansion of traineeship and apprenticeship opportunities. The government has allocated over $200 million over the next four years towards implementing the modern apprenticeship and traineeship scheme. The scheme will bring Commonwealth expenditure in this area to over $1.7 billion over the next four years.

Integral to our approach to other young people who need help is the development of strong social institutions—the family, the community and schools. Early intervention, family support and community involvement are critical to the success of our programs to deal with youth suicide and youth homelessness. The youth homelessness pilot program which I initiated, for example, involves community groups working with homeless young people to facilitate family reconciliation and to improve their level of engagement in work, education, training and the community. The national youth suicide strategy, which will receive an additional $18 million over three years, is a real attempt by all governments to address a serious social problem within our community.

The government retains a special commitment to the security and the well-being of older Australians. The value of their pensions is guaranteed through the indexing of pensions on a twice yearly basis in accordance with the consumer price index and by maintaining their value at a minimum of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

We are encouraging people to make greater provision for their retirement during their working lives—for instance, the exemption from capital gains tax where a small business is sold to provide for retirement. People will also be able to continue contributing to superannuation up to the age of 70, and the lower provisional tax uplift factor will also assist many older Australians. Discrimination in the tax system against self-funded retirees has also ended. The tax rebate applying to pensioners is being extended to low income retirees of pension age.

We have been particularly concerned to protect the economic future of people not readily covered by existing superannuation arrangements. Retirement savings accounts and the new superannuation spouse rebate will improve the opportunities for the accumulation of benefits by non-working or low income spouses. Our private health insurance incentives have also been welcomed by older Australians.

We said we would revitalise Australia's regions and provide the basis for renewed confidence in the future. We are well and truly on track to meeting this commitment. A strong small business sector and new investment will provide jobs in regional Australia, and our actions are aimed at encouraging both.

Some areas of rural and regional Australia are still recovering from the worst drought on record. The government has increased the support to farm families until normal cash flows return, so they can get on with rebuilding their properties and help restore the vitality of their regions. We announced in October an additional $81.5 million as a package for areas recovering from exceptional drought.

I am also proud to say that the government has introduced legislation to establish the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. That trust will provide more than $1.2 billion for a comprehensive program of action to address key environmental problems facing Australia. Funding for the trust is to be sourced from the proceeds of the sale of one-third of Telstra. Cleaning up waterways and improving land care are both crucial to future generations of Australians in country areas. The coalition is proud that in its first year it has, with the help of Senators Harradine and Colston, moved to implement this historic environmental reform.

Advanced telecommunications infrastructure is also critical for the social and economic health of regional and rural Australia. The government has moved to ensure the availability of enhanced services such as call waiting, call diversion and high speed access to the Internet through the early completion of the digitisation program.

We are also establishing a $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to ensure that Australians living in regional and rural areas are not left behind by advances in telecommunications technology. We are determined that there will not be communications haves and communications have‐nots in this country. We are committed to a policy which delivers a 21st century technology communications system to all Australians, irrespective of where they might live.

Transport costs often represent a significant economic hurdle for regional Australia, and the government remains committed to lowering this burden. We will spend $750 million upgrading the Pacific Highway and $149 million on black spots. Our reforms to rail will also provide a more efficient and competitive rail system, thus further reducing the barriers to invest in regional Australia.

We are also addressing specific challenges in sectors critical to rural Australia, such as the workability of the Native Title Act. We have given forest industry certainty through the granting of transitional licences for three years to underpin future investment and employment. We are working to ensure long-term resource security while protecting high conservation value forests under the regional forests agreement process. We have approved the $500 million Korea Zinc Australia operation at Townsville. Complementary Commonwealth‐state environmental assessment for the Jabiluka No. 2 proposal and the $1.25 billion expansion proposal for Olympic Dam arrangements have also been announced.

Australia's trading performance is a vital element of the government's strategy to improve job opportunities and living standards for all Australians. We are therefore putting particular effort into reducing barriers to Australia's exports—both tariffs and other obstacles. A recently concluded agreement with Taiwan—I pay tribute to the work of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) in this connection—will improve our access to markets for beef, citrus and other fruits and cars. As a result, Mitsubishi Australia has already concluded a $35 million deal to export its new Magnas to Taiwan and announced extra jobs at its Adelaide plant. We are exporting fresh milk to Hong Kong for the first time as a result of recent negotiations.

This year's APEC leaders meeting successfully maintained the momentum for regional trade liberalisation. Australia has already opened up its own economy, decreasing average tariffs to around five per cent. We look to other economies to match us and to respond to us. This year's APEC individual action plans represent a good start. These plans clearly show that the momentum for regional trade liberalisation is there and it is delivering concrete benefits for Australian business.

Restrictions on some agricultural imports are being reduced in Hong Kong and Japan. New access for Australian business in banking and investment will be available in China, Thailand, Singapore and the Philippines. The Philippines will lift import restrictions on coal, and Thailand will liberalise the natural gas market. In the World Trade Organisation, the government is working hard to ensure that market access commitments made in the Uruguay Round are adhered to. The government also wants to ensure momentum is maintained for further progress beyond the Uruguay Round outcomes in all areas of concern to Australian business.

Australia's success and prosperity is tightly bound to the future of the Asia‐Pacific region. The government is deeply committed to strengthening Australia's economic and strategic relationships with the other major economies and powers in our region. Within weeks of forming government I held a successful meeting with the Prime Minister of Malaysia. My first bilateral overseas visit was to two of our most important regional partners—Japan and Indonesia. Discussions with the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Hashimoto, and President Soeharto of Indonesia made clear their interest in cooperating closely with Australia under my government. At the APEC leaders meeting in Manila, I met the Chinese President, Mr Jiang Zemin, and underlined the importance the new government placed on our relationship with that country.

I was delighted to welcome President Clinton to Australia—only the third such visit to Australia by a United States President. The clear message from both sides during the visit was the enduring strength of the bilateral relationship and a common commitment to our region. The visit built on the Australia‐United States ministerial talks in July at which agreement was reached on a number of measures to strengthen the Australia‐US alliance and the contribution it makes to regional stability.

The government played an important role—and I particularly acknowledge the contribution of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer)—in concluding the comprehensive test ban treaty. We will continue to work hard for non-proliferation objectives.

Australia is by any comparison a united, tolerant and internally harmonious nation. The goal of my government will be always to focus on those things which unite Australians and not those which might divide them. Our success in absorbing millions of people from the four corners of the globe in a climate of tolerance and positive espousal of common national goals has been an example to the rest of the world. Despite our success, we must all strive to build on our past legacy of tolerance and egalitarianism.

My government is steadfast in its commitment to the process of reconciliation between indigenous Australians and the wider Australian community. We want higher living standards and greater economic independence for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We will work with states and territories and with ATSIC to achieve practical outcomes designed to overcome the undoubted social and economic disadvantage of our indigenous people.

We have demonstrated an enduring commitment to the role of the arts in Australian life. This has included a particular focus on accessibility through innovative programs such as the major festivals fund to assist Australian productions performed in capital cities and major regional areas. We are also providing support through the regional arts fund, the emerging artists fund and the touring programs of the Department of Communications and the Arts.

As part of our commitment to a safer Australia, the government has committed $13 million to the national campaign on violence and crime. This campaign is aimed at more effective coordination and implementation of crime prevention efforts across the country and at the reduction of crime and fear of crime. We are committed to dealing more effectively with the issue of domestic violence. We anticipate specific strategies to be endorsed at the National Domestic Violence Summit to be held in 1997.
We remain strongly committed to public involvement in the debate and the decision making process about Australia's head of state and we will announce the next step in that process early next year.

PARA.BREAK: In 2001, the centenary of Federation provides an opportunity to celebrate Australia's achievements and our immense democratic inheritance. The recently announced Com monwealth appointees to the Centenary of Federation Council will cooperate with the states, local government and community organisations to develop a coordinated program across the country.

BREAK.PARA: For us, the Australian national flag remains a focus of immense national pride. As promised, the government introduced on 26 June the Flags Amendment Bill to ensure that the Australian flag cannot be changed in any way without a national vote of all of the Australian people.

A very positive example of this government's commitment to our national institutions is the enhanced opportunity now provided to ask questions in the House of Representatives. Let every member mark these figures. In the last year of the Keating government there was an average of only 12.7 questions each question time. The average so far this year is no less than 19 questions. That is the highest average for the last 20 years. In other words, once again we have stayed true to a promise we made in the election campaign.

There are a whole host of other achievements across a range of portfolios and we have only just begun. Ten months on from the election, we are proud of the important start that we have made in restoring good government and responsible policy making at the national level: an important start in rebuilding a sense of national purpose in place of Labor's shifting alliance of special interests; an important start in restoring the family as the centrepiece of national policy making; an important start in fixing the fundamentals of our economy; an important start in re‐energising small business; an important start in revitalising regional Australia; and an important start in building genuine hope for young Australians and greater security for older Australians.

We know that, in all these areas, what we have achieved is only a start. We need to keep going forward—and we will. We need to ensure that all Australians—irrespective of their race, colour, beliefs or country of origin—are accorded respect and dignity as individuals and are given an equal entitlement to achieve their aspirations free from discrimination and intimidation—and we will.

Above all, we need to continue to relate the government's priorities to the concerns and aspirations of the Australian mainstream. We are unashamedly committed to listening to the Australian mainstream and not treating them with the contempt which was the wont of my predecessor in the office of Prime Minister of Australia. We need to continue to relate our agenda to those aspirations rather than to the narrower agendas of self‐appointed elites and special interests.

As Prime Minister, I am proud of my cabinet, I am proud of my team, and I am proud of my team's achievements. It has been a good 10 months for the Liberal and National parties but, more importantly, it has been a good 10 months for the Australian people who gave us their trust on 2 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—What an exercise in fatuous triumphalism! I concede that nobody could have accused us of being excessively modest when in government, but we never had the hide to walk into this parliament with such a mouse like set of achievements and announce them as though we were climbing every mountain, fording every stream, following every rainbow, till we found our dream! We had a couple of Prime Ministers who were amply capable of that, but they had sufficient sense and humility not to try.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian people want two things from their politicians. Firstly, they want a bit of humility and, secondly, they want a bit of leadership. That is what the Australian people want from their politicians. The Australian people know that the problems that confront our society are complex. The policies that we pursue to deal with them will not always be right. Fairness and justice are not necessarily manifold in our community. Opportunity is not necessarily available for all. Mainstream Australia carries burdens, some of which it cannot sustain.

The Australian people know these things. They do not necessarily expect political parties to come up with all the solutions, but when they hear a report from a Prime Minister or a Leader of the Opposition, they expect a bit of balance. They expect a bit of humility these days. Things have changed.

It is interesting to compare the mouse like achievements of this government with the achievements made when we were in office. Our achievements included: the deregulation of the financial sector; the establishment of universal health care; the doubling of participation rates in schools; a massive transformation of the higher education sector; the introduction of a totally new competency based training agenda; achievements in the defence industries; achievements in foreign policy, including security and survival for our people; the introduction of a decent retirement plan through superannuation; and bringing into surplus the $25 billion deficit which was left by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when he was the Treasurer of this nation.

As an aside, I was interested to hear the Prime Minister's commitment, because he has been starting to use fudge words on that surplus in interviews. The fudge words came this morning on the timetable for the achievement of that surplus. Well he might use fudge words—and I will say a bit about growth rates and the possible impact on that later on.

Despite the achievements of the Labor government, not one Labor Prime Minister came into this place to boast in an annual statement that those achievements had been made by us. We at least had enough sense and humility to say, `You do not need to trumpet your words at any particular point in time. By your deeds, you will be known. You can get your point across issue by issue when you have substantial things to do.'

Compare the introduction of universal health care in this society with the minor but bad adjustments the government has made to Medicare, about which it is boasting. Compare the achievements in education of the previous government with the slashing arrangements that this government has put in place and now boasts of here as somehow or other achieving its promises.

Compare a government which managed with four per cent per annum growth over the previous four years, maintaining a low inflation rate within the Reserve Bank targets, with this government coming into office, building on that inflation rate and sustaining it only by crushing growth in our society. Compare a government that lowered on middle Australia a tax rate from 30 cents in the dollar to 20 cents with one which has produced a paltry family tax package which demonstrated the dishonesty of their advertising that families were going to benefit to the tune of $34 when only one in nine is in fact going to get anywhere near that. Compare a government that did those things to the taxation system with that paltry achievement, and perhaps we have an answer as to the reason why the Prime Minister chose a non‐broadcast day on which to make this speech. Perhaps we have an answer to that. It is a paltry performance about paltry achievement, full of thundering cliches, volleys of cliches, rolling out across the parliament, but above all, it is a representation of his inability to heed his own words.

He warned his backbench against hubris yesterday; he warned them against taking the public for granted and within 24 hours he came in here with a vain, boasting, biased presentation on the achievements of his government, producing hoarse laughter again and again as he claimed honesty, competence of his government, great tax achievements—one after another, one pathetic performance, one pathetic statement after another.

Let me deal with this question of competence, accountability and honesty. Where? When? Let's take accountability first. We had a foreign minister stand up in this place and admit that he misled parliament and when you looked at the evidence of it you could say it was nothing other than deliberate. Did he go? No. We had a set of ministers come into this place, manifestly in breach of standards that the Prime Minister said were new standards. Then he said they were really the previous government's standards and then he said they were unachievable standards. If he had attempted to enforce them he would have taken out three or four of his senior ministers.

Is it accountability when we see a minister surviving in the Senate who repeatedly misleads? She invented a whole new family to produce completely misleading information on the real impact of the savaging that ordinary Australian families got in this budget. This is, as far as the Prime Minister is concerned, a demonstration of accountability and competence as far as this government is to be represented.

Then we had Senator Herron moonlighting, but Senator Herron is turning out a little bit better than expected in recent months. Why? Because we have an Aboriginal affairs spokesman who spends a fair amount of time around there teaching him to read. As far as that area is concerned, we are trying very hard to get to a position with you whereby we can restore a level of confidence in the Aboriginal community that they get fair treatment out of the parliament of this nation. So these are the competent and accountable people?

We come to the Prime Minister's praise of his foreign minister. Just get rid of him. Do yourself a favour; have a reshuffle. We still have our contacts with the departments in this town; as they said in that film Chinatown we have still got a few teeth in the head and a few friends down town. In every single department bar the odd one or two, there is speculation rife at Christmas time about the shift of their ministers. Sometimes it is the minister who has managed to keep his head down because none of them have demonstrated competence, as that report card has shown. Sometimes the minister who has managed to keep his head down is about to be shifted into a portfolio where a minister has not, but mostly it will be the senior members of his team. Vanstone must go; Downer must go. This is the view in these departments. Downer is obviously going to go. Moore is obviously going to go. All those poor fellows slashed in foreign affairs know they are being slashed to make way for a massive influx of new ambassadors as this Prime Minister gets to grips with the competence or otherwise of his team. And a very hungry backbencher is sitting there waiting for them. So, honest? Competent? Accountable? I am afraid not.

Then I come to the question of the treatment of this parliament. Yes, we are back to the number of questions asked in the question times of Malcolm Fraser and Gough Whitlam. That is the case, and that is an area where we, I must confess, Mr Speaker, were not good performers. We ought to have had more questions in question time when we were in office than we had. But in terms of the treatment of the forms of this House, that is about it.

We saw one of the major debates, with the liberty of conscience applying to it, taken out of this House, substantially, and put in the Main Committee. The Main Committee is a good device but it is not a good device for dealing with that particular issue, an issue in which we looked to—and I think obtained from—our members of parliament for a heightening in the public perception of the quality of the people in this place, but it was not on display. That was not an advance on standards.

Then we have this unusual position. You, Mr Speaker, are the only Speaker who has been successfully defied by a Prime Minister and a Leader of the House. Not even this Prime Minister's predecessor, who was exceptionally hard on speakers, did that. I can recollect an occasion when the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), in a fury, dealt with that particular issue from the then Prime Minister and got an apology from him. As far as I am aware, Mr Speaker, you have not gotten one from this Prime Minister, and you should have. The standards that are required in this parliament of the people in leadership positions are very substantial standards indeed and yet this Prime Minister simply has not been able to provide them,

As well as a bit of humility, a bit of balance, a bit of even‐handedness, what the Australian public also likes to see is a bit of leadership. The Prime Minister mentioned guns and the laws that have been implemented to deal with the plethora of firearms in our community. We have congratulated him on this many times and he showed leadership in the Australian community on that issue. However, I think we are sufficiently distant from it now to do a bit of analysis. The simple fact of the matter is that this was not necessarily a tremendously difficult task to undertake. It was a negotiating task, there is no question about that, though not for the Prime Minister.

Not only in the Prime Minister's party do there reside people who are—and I do not put this in pejorative terms at all—part of a gun culture, people who enjoy gun collection, people who enjoy shooting, people who enjoy hunting. They are not replete in the Liberal Party. There are a fair few in our ranks, I have to say, including one or two on my front bench and in my caucus. There is also a plethora of them in the National Party.

I am going to hand out a bit of kudos in this speech. I want to praise Tim Fischer. I think he showed marvellous leadership on guns, magnificent leadership on guns. He had a battle. Tim Fischer and his colleagues in the National Party—and I congratulate them collectively—had a battle. They had a struggle.

I am going to take that a point further on Tim Fischer. He alone amongst those in leadership positions in this government has stood unequivocally against the statements made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). He alone, on the front bench of this government, was prepared to sign that declaration on racial tolerance. He alone—as far as that front bench was concerned, and the foreign minister is out the back door as far as this issue is concerned—understood immediately, without being told, the impact that this would have on our relationships with the region around us. He alone understood what was required in the exercise of leadership in this place.

There is something else that needs to be said here and that is this: the statements of the member for Oxley, execrable as they were, were not unusual or unique in their expression, either in the Australian community or, for that matter, in parliament. They were not. They happened to be exceptional in their erroneous factual basis, but the motives underlying them were not exceptional.

What changed the debate was a statement about freedom of speech. Although there was a qualifying remark in it that said that freedom of speech was not licensed, unfortunately when these things get out into the ether the first sentence is not necessarily followed by the second. Putting the genie back in the bottle has required an extraordinary effort ever since. And it is not as though the American President—and he got some reference in the Prime Minister's remarks—was not alert to that and it is not as though there was not an element of deliberation in the American President's remarks when he was over here.

So that was a bit of leadership that went lacking as far as the Prime Minister is concerned. It is a very narrow definition of leadership which glories in our poor performances in the polls and seeks to make them worse by seeing whether or not we can tweak the immigration issue a bit. It is a very poor leader who goes into the caucus of his party and says, `A terrible mistake was made by the Labor Party because it did not support all our changes in the immigration area. I would just like to tweak that one a little bit.' That is not leadership in this community. That is being narrow and poll driven and ultimately dangerous in terms of the security and the coherence of this nation.

You like to see a bit of even‐handedness—and from to time we have had even‐handedness from the Prime Minister on the record of his predecessors. We do not get it now and we did not get it in this speech. But take the remarks he made about inheriting a terrible economy and all the rest of it and contrast them with his remarks to international bankers when he described the economy that he inherited as better than good.

How else could you describe an economy that had four years worth of four per cent growth? How else could you describe an economy that was enjoying about twice the rate of employment growth of any other industrialised nation? How else could you describe it other than that? How could you describe an economy which had a low interest rate regime and had a low inflation rate when this government got into office? That is how you describe it: you describe it as better than good, and so it was described by the Prime Minister.

He set great store by the difficulties he felt he faced when he had his budget. Let me just suggest to him these things: the way in which he handled the budget and the particular deficit problem he confronted was completely wrong. He implemented a set of promises which had not been properly funded and decided to describe them as core and then blame the previous government for the fact that he had to make even greater savings than he might otherwise have had to to achieve the level of balance that he wanted.

But he was politically driven by that budget. He decided that he would knock over a lot of public policies that he, in the last few years, said he supported but really did not. His intentions were there in Fightback, in all their pristine purity. He used it as an excuse to knock out that good public policy to produce for himself a situation in which he hoped, three years down the line, he would have a budgetary position that would provide him with a war chest to deal with his subsequent election campaign. Unfortunately for this nation it was the wrong prescription at the time.

It was the sort of budget that you put in place when you are confronting a boom. It was the sort of budget that you put in place when you have massive surging business confidence. It was the sort of budget that you put in place when the economy has not effectively plateaued and started to slow. That is the sort of budget that you put in place then. Not now. You always have to exercise a degree of fiscal discipline. I might say to you this: we did, ourselves, produce three surpluses; you have not yet. You say you will produce one from this budget but you have been fudging your words this morning. That will be an interesting thing for another debate at another time.

But your prescription was wrong. Tightening? Yes. The wholesale tightening and the destruction of good public policy? No. That was politics, not economics. That was not what the nation needed at this point of time. Nevertheless, that is what you chose to put in place and you are therefore required now to overclaim for yourselves. You have no responsibility whatsoever for the lowering of interest rates, except a negative one. You have contributed to the flattening out of the Australian economy. That has been your role in lowering interest rates. What has caused interest rates to come down—the essential underpinnings of it—is that we achieved low inflationary growth, sufficient for the Reserve Bank to be trusting of the situation in which they find themselves. Secondly, it is we who introduced the productivity based wage reforms, which have ensured wage outcomes that the Reserve Bank could begin to trust. What has come out of your industrial relations changes is paltry in comparison to what came out of the changes that we put in place and, I might say, as we have pointed out repeatedly, completely unnecessary. Don't think the business community doesn't know it. The business community is not doing handsprings, not jumping through hoops, on the basis of the industrial relations changes you have put in place. At best it is pretty ho‐hum as far as they are concerned. The business community has made that, I might say, both publicly and privately abundantly clear.

It was those changes that we put in place that produced the low interest rate regime, in case you had not noticed, despite the fact that we jacked up interest rates marginally a couple of years ago. It was marginal. It was not a massive increase in interest rates whatsoever and we left the way for them to come down. Unfortunately, I think the Reserve Bank has made a misjudgment. I agree with Bernie Fraser and I said so at the time, given that there is no stimulus coming through from the budget, given that the economy has been substantially talked down by this government. They are now trying to talk it up, but they have spent six months doing the opposite, sending the other message. Given all of that, their one last hope in town was for the Reserve Bank to produce a bit of a punch through and they really should have done a one per cent cut—three or four weeks ago—not the half that they did and the half that they did today.

The half a per cent cut today is not a matter for triumph for this government. The half today is a matter of sadness—if you like, sorrow. It is a correction which should have been undertaken a few weeks previously and which could have been. The Reserve Bank is overly concerned about the wages position; it has been for some considerable time. Treasury is constantly underestimating the inflation position. It was a problem with us and now, evidently, it is a problem with you. Treasury has found it hard to produce the inflation figures that are really happening. They are constantly overestimating the difficulties with inflation in this nation. It is part of the model that perhaps you need to do something about correcting. It was certainly a matter which troubled us from time to time when we were in office.

The inflation rate under us—and it will be so under you too—is less than anticipated and therefore, there is room for far more movement in interest rates than immediately meets the eye. I hope the new Governor of the Reserve Bank will bear that in mind.

Like Banquo's ghost at the feast, the question of jobs was there haunting the speech. But it never manifested itself in any serious way at all. A whole series of assertions without evidence was made. Somehow what we are doing on industrial relations will create jobs. What is going to happen here? Interest rates will create jobs. The economy getting the fundamentals right will create jobs. Nobody agrees with you. There is not a single serious analyst out there who expects anything other than a completely lousy jobs outcome and that includes your own Treasury. What an extraordinarily paltry set of predictions they made on job outcomes for the course of the next three years. It was about 60 per cent of our rate of achievement and on the last set of figures, everybody said, `Oh gee, terrific, after four months of coming down, we've got a 2.1 per cent lift in the ANZ jobs vacancies predictor.' What does that produce? Half the rate to achieve that paltry figure of 60 per cent of what we achieved. No wonder it was Banquo's ghost at the feast as far as jobs were concerned.

What was the one jobs initiative we got? What we got was Laurie Brereton. If we really got Laurie Brereton that would be a good thing, but we will not actually get Laurie because he is going to stay on the frontbench—and he will be chained to the bench if he tries anything in this regard! What we got was the re‐creation of Laurie Brereton's job. If people cast their minds back to who the new projects officer was, they will realise it was Laurie. Very successful he was, too. A mine or two in the north of this country are directly the product of Laurie's activities. I wish the government all strength to its right arm on the new projects officer, but do not try to sell him as some sort of invention or great initiative in the area of jobs, because he is not.

As far as jobs are concerned, we have seen a rate of increase in long‐term unemployment of about 10,000 a month since the middle of this year. It is falling in a heap and starting to reach crisis proportions. The number is up from about 200,000 to closer to 270,000. We have a situation now where serious problems are going to be created in our society. Your answer to that in the education and training area and in the encouragement of people into the work force is to slash Labor policies.

The junior Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) constantly gets up in this place and produces bogus figures. The outcome of our traineeships—and those traineeships were increasing exponentially when we left office—was 83 per cent in terms of jobs achieved. The outcome from skillshares was 60 per cent. They are dead. Despite the best efforts of the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) to portray this government as sympathetic to skillshare, this government has killed large numbers of skillshares stone dead.

Despite what the government says about MAATS—which is at best the re‐badged training arrangements that we put in place; and we were expanding traineeships into areas of employment where there had been no formalised training before and building on what we did in establishing competency based training—despite the boasting about the amount of money devoted to it, if you actually take what we spent on training in the various equivalent programs that we had in place, there has been a massive cut.

The government thinks that by simply mentioning a number and putting it in a vacuum and saying, `Observe the beauty of it,' it has actually said something meaningful in terms of whether or not we are going to get improvement on where we have been and where we are going. Of course, we are not. What the government has done is to massively pare that back, and there will be penalties.

One of the things that this government does not quite realise yet is that it is not still in opposition. It still believes that by simply asserting things, by simply making statements as though they were fact, it will produce outcomes that are somehow equivalent to it. It will not.

The reality is that youth unemployment is rising. The reality is that long‐term unemployment is rising. The reality is that unemployment is rising. Not a single decision taken by this government will do anything other than exacerbate it, whether it be cuts to the public sector, the partial privatisation of Telstra, or what it has done to the whole range of industry support packages that we put in place that were actually providing the means by which we had massively improved our export performance in complex manufactured goods and services. They did not come out of nowhere.

If you look at the performance of the firms which were in some way the beneficiaries of the R&D concessions—the various bounties, be they for the computer industry, books or shipping; or the various plans, such as the car plan and the steel plan—or the firms associated with those industries, and compare them with those which have not so benefited, the rate of contribution, the increase in our exports, is approximately three to one in favour of those so assisted.

What is the government going to do when it kills them—when it kills jobs but also kills exports? The government is re‐creating for itself this current account deficit problem. Yet it is now parading around the business community arguing that there should be some stimulus. Treasury is saying, `No, we have to keep growth between two per cent and 3½ per cent so we can resolve the current account problem.' It is going to be two per cent forever if that happens to be the case.

The simple fact of the matter is that we have always been able to sustain a level of current account deficit of around three to four. It is when it gets to six that you worry. It did go to six once or twice under us. It went to six once or twice under the Prime Minister when he was Treasurer. That is when you require a haul‐back. But, if you allow yourself to buy that line, what you are going to do is create the seeds of your own problem, a problem which will eventually render employment growth in this community sclerotic.

I am afraid to say that one of the answers they have started to develop to this is the worst answer of all. I am going to campaign on this. We are going to make an issue of this around the community. We revolutionised the structure of the labour market in this country when we were in office. Actually we did not. Let me not be boastful. We did not do that. We responded to it. What revolutionised it was a lifestyle change determination made by the women of Australia. We did not do it. We simply tried to facilitate it where it occurred. But they made the decision.

Many things happen in the economy which governments cannot direct. They have to respond to them. But you are trying to direct it. What you are trying to do in the propositions that you are operating on at the moment—be it in the area of child care or be it in the area of weighting your assistance packages to families—is drive women out of the work force. They cannot go. If they go, every woman who leaves is materially disadvantaging her family position. Many of those women who are earning $90, $100 or $150 a week, as well as getting some enjoyment out of life and a bit of self‐fulfilment, are supplementing the family income.

What you are doing in child care will probably succeed in driving a few of them out. But they will not go out to a great family tax package. What they will go out to is a decline in family income, a decline in security in the household and a fear in that household that they have lost one breadwinner in the work force and something may happen to the other one. I am afraid to say that an awful lot of women who are in the position I have so described happen to be married to men who are in the most vulnerable sectors of the work force when it comes to restructuring. So, the fears that they have are going to be augmented by the fact that they come from families constantly under stress on the question of whether or not they have a secure future for themselves and whether or not they are going to be able to keep going.

Mr Prime Minister, do you think they are going to spend? Do you think they are going to make a consumer contribution? Do you think they are going to make a consumer contribution to the sorts of growth figures that we need? No. They are voting with their feet at the moment. There is a declaration going on this Christmas in the shops and shopping centres of this nation about the level of confidence they have in their future as families. They are voting with their feet and they are walking out of those shops, or they are not walking into them. If they walk into them, they are walking out of them with nothing. They are doing a process of window‐shopping; for some of them it will be truly Dickensian in what they are presented with and what they cannot have.

They want to give your government a go, Mr Prime Minister. They really do. They were sick of us. There are no two ways about that. We were a hard government, we ran hard‐nosed policies, we were efficient, we changed things that needed to be changed; but we were not loved. We were respected by some; but we were not loved. A judgment was made that they wanted us out of the way, and they heeded you when you said that you wanted them relaxed and comfortable. They really crave that. They crave being stress free. You should have used that expression which they use themselves, rather than `relaxed and comfortable'. That is not what they talk about. They do talk about stress. As you would know from the focus groups that your party runs—they are the same as the focus groups that ours runs and they will have the same results—those families feel stress.

You boast about this tax change that one in nine families gets—the $34. Talk about truth in advertising, talk about honesty and accountability in government! One in nine families gets it. And what else do they get? They get HECS charges, they get pharmaceutical increases, they get job insecurity, they get a whole range of changes to government benefits that affect their families. Do you not think that young families are worried about what happens to their aged parents? Your minister is out there saying, `Perhaps families ought to provide.' Who are these families who are going to provide? The families who are going to provide are the families who are supposed to be benefiting from those tax changes. They are trying to keep their kids and they wonder what the heck they are going to do with mum and dad. A few of them are going to resent the fact that one of the things that is not going to happen to them is that little bit of boost in the family income that they expected when mum and dad go—from the family home. It will have gone towards keeping mum and dad when they finally have to be kept in a nursing home.

If I have got any major quarrel with this government, and I have got many of them, none goes further and none is more strident, I would say—aside from the industry policy area which I have already mentioned—than the area of education. What a stone is being served the children of Australia! What a stone—let us get biblical about it—is being handed to the children of Australia. They are being told now that they have got to get out of university. The tremendously debt averse middle Australia—and they are debt averse—are being told they will be debt ridden as they go through university.

I can advise them, as a person who has been used to public policy for some time, that they may well be able to sustain that debt in the income they earn ultimately. I can advise them of that, but they will not believe me. I tell you what, they will not believe you, either. They will not believe you, and the proof of the pudding is in the eating of what you have already confronted. The figures that are coming in now from the universities are dramatically down—and, I might say, other figures are down as well. An awful lot of those women I talked about, who were joining the work force and were going to university under the arrangements, are gone. If you think the figures are down for school leavers, try taking a look at the figures for those women from middle Australia who had decided to re‐enter the work force and retrain themselves. Where have they gone? Not to university any more. That is what has happened there.

BREAK.PARA: What else has happened with the universities? I did think that the objective of government was that we wanted a large, skilled work force, a clever country, a work force scientifically, technologically and engineeringly adept. I did think we wanted that, and I did think the Australian people wanted that. I do think they believed that, when they elected Mr Howard, they would continue to get it because, when we said they would do exactly what they did on HECS, Mr Howard said that we were lying. They said that about us. `Labor lies' was the pamphlet that went out. `Don't believe Labor when they say that we are going to increase HECS to you and make you pay at a lower threshold; Labor will lie about that,' they said. I suppose, in a funny sort of way, we did. The sort of thing we asserted was about half what they did. But that was accidental, I assure you, Mr Speaker. We did not believe that they had the gall—the sheer, naked, unmitigated gall—to declare the universities of Australia a non‐core promise. What an extraordinary thing it was that they should have done so.

Add that to what they have done to industry, add that to what they have done to the clever part of industry, and where is the vision for this nation? There is one great thing about Australians and it is this: we are one of the most technologically adept societies. I am sick of hearing people say, and the columnists write in their columns, that Australia is a nation that is either in decline or is somehow or other standing in the shade as far as the Asian tigers are concerned. To hell with that! It is baloney when you look at the performance of our information technology industries. We are, in absolute terms—we are not talking relative terms here—the second biggest user of information technology in this part of the Pacific Rim. We are beaten by Japan. We are not beaten by South Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand—all the other tigers to whom people refer.

We are very good, and we are very good because we have the right education system, because we have the right industry policies and because we have the right structure in Australian industry to deal with the challenges that face us. You could not admit, Prime Minister, that we are a bridge to Asia but we do need a bridge to the 21st century. And the bridge to the 21st century lies in the quality of our education system and its ability to deliver contemporary technology to the Australian community.

I am not going to go on a deal further with this because, really, this is not a speech that warrants any substantial response. I have tried to do a thing or two to assist that process, but I will conclude in one area—foreign affairs and defence policy. Mr Prime Minister, you are failing, your government is failing, in the area of foreign affairs and defence policy. Your government has inherited a wonderful position—as you acknowledge yourself when you go overseas, not here—from your predecessors. You do not have the ideas or the personnel to match it. You are not savable in that area, and, as a result of that, this country will be damaged.

The absolute ineptness with which you have handled those issues which your foreign minister has had to deal with has been really amazing, even to us. There are things that you can do. I will make a suggestion to you because I think I should have a few constructive things in this speech, and I have had one or two constructive suggestions. The thing that you should do is this: fire Alexander. You should have done it a few months ago. He has absolutely no credibility in the Asia‐Pacific region. He is the bearer of a piece of dishonesty on DIFF, as far as the region is concerned, and this means he can never recover. Wandering around the place flashing leg in fish‐net is not an answer. They do not take him seriously—get rid of him.

I suggest to you that you appoint either your industrial relations minister or your environment minister. I do not say that because they are any good. They are certainly not up to the mark that we established, but at least they are not Alexander. That is a very important attribute as far as the foreign policy of this nation is concerned. You should do that.

But you should do more than that. You should send them around quietly—not openly, not publicly; we do not have to humiliate ourselves—to say, `We did not understand when we dealt with you on DIFF what the real meaning of that was, and we are going to correct it.' You do not have to say that publicly. We will find out about it anyway. Do it privately; do not humiliate this nation. It is not required. We never want to see this nation humiliated, but do do what I suggest.

Then give him an assistant and leave that assistant out there. You have a big enough majority around here. Leave that assistant out there all year, and then go yourself. You missed a wonderful opportunity in India, as our foreign spokesman. I know they were to roll the red carpet out for you. In a funny sort of way I am grateful you did not go, because they rolled it out for me instead. But that was not good enough. It should have been rolled out for you. You had a great opportunity and you turned it down. As far as this nation is concerned, that was a sad thing.

Get that foreign policy of yours in order as best you can. At least keep it ticking over until some really competent people can get their hands on it again. At least keep it ticking over for a few years until we can do that. But part of the process is to really understand the resonance over there of what happens in domestic Australia.

My final point is that you and I, Mr Prime Minister, have this obligation, and I hope you recognise it: all Australians have to feel relaxed and comfortable. No matter what their racial background, no matter what their social background, they all have to feel comfortable in this society, and they also have to feel energised. They also have to understand that they are contributing to building a great nation; that they are contributing to building a national structure which will ensure the survival of this nation; that they are going to need to be educated to do it; that they are going to be secure in their health; and, above all, that they are going to be secure in their jobs.

They must not be frightened at home; frightened of their employers; frightened of the future of their industries; or frightened of what happens if a spouse loses their job. They must have that security. If you govern on that basis, Mr Prime Minister, you will get support from us. But, so far, you have not governed on that basis.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before we adjourned to listen to the address of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the Australian flag is a very important symbol. We should recognise it as a symbol which is more important to the people that live within Australia that recognise it as our national flag and as our national symbol; we should not place so much emphasis on what it means or its recognisability to people overseas. I think that is a very important element in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that earlier this year AGB McNair polled a number of Australians as to whether they thought the Australian flag should be changed. Sixty‐six per cent said no and only 27 per cent said yes. That reinforces the comment I made earlier with regard to the attitude, particularly amongst young people in Australia today, to our national symbol, and it is very important. I make a particular effort to get to as many schools as I can in my electorate, not just presenting the Australian flag to young Australians but actually explaining the importance and the significance of the elements of our Australian flag.

That is incredibly important in that educational process and I think that is probably what has been lacking in recent years. In my generation, we used to have the flag raising ceremony at school and we used to go through the process. But we were not ever taught at school about the importance of the elements and the symbolism of that national flag. It is important to note that a flag tells a country and its people their history. It symbolises our beginning and our heritage. The Australian flag tell us where we came from, where we are and our duty to the future. It is well known across the length and breadth of this country—the symbolism of the Southern Cross. That signifies where this great south land sits in the globe and in world affairs, that we are in the southern hemisphere.

BREAK.PARA: Interestingly, during the Australia Remembers year last year, I had the opportunity to talk to a number of prisoners of war who were incarcerated in Changi Prison in Singapore during the Second World War. One of the things that kept them going through those very hard years was the fact that they could actually see the Southern Cross in the southern sky and they knew that is where Australia was. That is incredibly important to those people, as it should be to everybody today. The Federation Star was originally on the flag as a six‐pointer but then the territories were added and it became a seven‐point star. That symbolises what the Commonwealth of Australia is made up of, that we were a number of colonies or states to start with that came together as a federation.

Just as importantly, there is the Union Jack. There is not a broad understanding of the importance and the heritage of the Union Jack. I suppose it is important to me as a Christian, but the Christian and biblical background of the Union Jack is very important and it is something that should be understood by all Australians if we ever got to the situation where as a country we were going to vote on whether or not we should be changing the flag. We should understand the elements of that flag. Yes, the Union Jack is the flag of the United Kingdom, it is the flag of another country, but the elements that come together to create the Union Jack have a much deeper cultural meaning to a lot of people in Australia than just the fact that it is a flag of another country.

The date of the completion of the Union Jack was 1801, and this coincided with the growth of the British commonwealth of nations under Queen Victoria. But what does the Union Jack mean? There are three things to remember about it: its name and the three countries it stands for; the three crosses and their meaning; and the three colours, red, white and blue, and their meaning. Originally, under the reign of King Richard I, in about 1189, the English flag had only one cross because it was for one country, and that was England. This cross was red on a white background and was called St George's Cross, after St George, who was the patron saint of England.

It is interesting to know a bit of background about St George. St George was born around the second half of the third century at Lydia in Palestine. His father was an officer of great wealth in the army of Diocletian, the Roman emperor. His mother was a daughter of the Count of Lydia. This Lydia is the same area that St Peter himself visited, which visit resulted in the conversion to Christianity of the whole town. That is the Cross of St George, and that is the red cross.

In 1801, in the reign of George III, Ireland was added to England and Scotland and with Ireland came its national flag of St Patrick, a red diagonal cross on a white background. The three crosses were then blended together to become our present Union Jack, which signifies the union of England, Scotland and Ireland as one Christian country under the blessing of the cross of the new covenant.

St Patrick of Ireland has an interesting background as well. St Patrick is the patron saint and national apostle of Ireland and there seems to be some confusion as to his exact date and place of birth. This is probably brought about by the fact that St Patrick is often mistaken for other characters of the same name and the same era. The most common evidence is that he was born in Dumbarton, Scotland, some time around the year 373 A.D.

The third element of the Union Jack is the Cross of St Andrew, the patron saint of Scotland. The national religious emblem of Scotland is St Andrew's Cross and he is the patron saint of Scotland. According to the Gospel of St John, Andrew was a brother to St Peter and is the first apostle named. The gospel further states that Andrew was a disciple of John the Baptist before Christ's call.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the St Andrew of the golf course.
—Yes, and I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Thomson), who is at the table, was named after St Andrew.

BREAK.PARA: Interestingly, they are the elements that make up the Union Jack. It is not just about the flag of another country, it is about a biblical heritage. And with this nation being predominantly a Christian nation—and I admit it is not all Christian—it is very important that we recognise the symbolism and the heritage in those three elements of the Union Jack. It is not just about the cross of another nation.

It is interesting to note that some commentators say that the name, the Union Jack, is a contraction of the union of Jacob and that the settlers in England, Scotland and Ireland were actually from the sons of Jacob who ended up in Great Britain. The Union Jack is actually the union of Jacob. That is very interesting to note. This is one argument that is quite often put with regard to the development of that national flag.

In closing, let me say that it is very important to the people of Australia, if they are ever going to consider changing our national flag, that they have the opportunity to vote on it. The flag is not to be changed within this place by politicians, by governments. The people of Australia must have the opportunity to vote on any change to our national flag.

Also, and most importantly, everybody in this country should understand the different elements of the flag and the symbolism that is contained within that flag. I encourage all members in this place to take the opportunity to distribute the national flag, particularly to schools in their electorates, as I do, and take the opportunity to explain the important symbolism and heritage that is contained in the different elements in the Australian flag. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed, having been interrupted once or twice earlier today.

—I advise all members that we have His Excellency Dr Haryanto, Minister of Communications from the Repub lic of Indonesia, in our gallery this afternoon. A very warm welcome to you, sir, and may you enjoy your stay with us.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Acting Leader of the National Party. Why is the government doing nothing more than writing letters to the oil companies about petrol terminal access and competitive wholesale prices? Do you recognise the enormous benefits to primary industries and country petrol consumers of Labor's plan to change the law and give all service station operators legal access rights to shop around for the cheapest wholesale petrol? Why has the government again sold out the bush by refusing to take on the petrol multinationals and guarantee lower petrol prices? Minister, do you agree with the Prime Minister's approach to petrol reform—just write a letter and hope for the best?

—This is pretty rich coming from this team when you think of what they did to fuel excise over the years. You went to the 1993 election promising no new taxes—and who did you hit? It was the rural sector, more than anybody else, with a massive hike in fuel excise on top of what you had done to it over the years and on top of what you had already done in terms of reducing outlays for road funding. Your record in this area is absolutely appalling. You did nothing. We are putting in place a range of measures which will be elaborated upon this afternoon and which will make a real difference. You created the mess; we are going to help fix it.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Given the fact that the big hope for creating jobs in my electorate of Robertson, and throughout Australia, rests with small business, what action is the government taking to take away disincentives for small business to grow?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that a question about small business should come from the member for Robertson. Not only is the member for Robertson one of the many examples of successful men and women in small business who have entered the parliament on the Liberal and National party side, but he is also someone who has a very deep understanding of the role of small business in the Robertson electorate. I think it is one of the reasons he was successful at the last election.

ANSWER.PARA: Can I say in response to the member for Robertson that there are many things that can be done to expand the economic and employment potential of small business. I am very pleased to remind the House of the steps that have been taken by the government in the area of the provisional tax uplift factor and also in some other taxation areas.

You will remember that in the budget we announced that as from 1 July 1997 capital gains tax rollover relief would apply to small businesses with assets below $5 million. This is the important thing to note: at the time of the budget announcement we said that this would apply if the assets were rolled over into another like-kind business. But, as a result of representations that have been made to the government from small business, we have decided to take away that condition. The Treasurer announced last week that the like-kind business test would not apply.

This particular amendment will greatly increase the incentive to invest in small business. It is going to result in a substantial reduction in compliance costs for small businesses wishing to qualify for the measure. In addition, the government has decided to extend the period—this is also a further important liberalisation—for reinvestment of the proceeds of the disposal from 12 months after disposal until 24 months after disposal. That is a doubling of the period of time. Not only are we removing the like‐kind business test but also the period has been doubled. No wonder one of the most authoritative commentators on business policy from both sides of politics in Australia, Robert Gottliebsen, somebody who on occasions has been quite critical of the coalition as he has been critical of the Labor Party, was moved to write in the Business Review Weekly only last Friday:

The small business capital gains tax rollover relief is the most significant change made to taxation in Australia for decades. It will revolutionise the way many talented people in Australia generate their income.

Here you have an absolutely emphatic endorsement from an objective source, an endorsement not from the backbench of one or other side of politics but from somebody who is recognised as an objective observer. He is saying that it is a measure of the coalition; it is the best move for decades in this taxation area; and it is going to revolutionise the way talented people in the Australian community—men and women who want to take a risk and invest in small business—can order their affairs. I cannot think of a more emphatic endorsement of the pro‐small business policies of the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Is the minister aware of reports that 4,000 to 5,000 service station small businesses in Australia will close if the government does not support Labor's plan for a legally enforceable access regime in the petrol industry?
—Ha, ha!

—You would think a former bowser boy would have a bit more respect for a private member's bill trying to help service stations around Australia. I would have thought you would think this is an important business. Why is the government refusing to give service stations the legal right to shop around for the most competitive wholesale petrol price? Why won't the government change the law to take power away from the big petrol companies and thereby protect thousands of small businesses and jobs, especially in regional Australia? Why is it, given that 4,000 to 5,000 small businesses are at stake, that the best the government can do is write a letter?
—Mr Speaker, Labor's proposition that 4,000 to 5,000 small businesses will close is their joke of the week. If that is the best they can do, that is what it is, a joke.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What are the prospects of Australian families and businesses benefiting from today's cut in official interest rates, and how have consumers benefited from recent rate reductions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, it is a matter of enormous pride for this government to be able to say that there have been three cuts in official rates during the term of this government. The third reduction in official interest rates was announced by the Reserve Bank this morning. Many financial institutions have already taken the opportunity to pass that on, and I congratulate those financial institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, in relation to home loans, FAI have already announced a reduction in the home loan rate to 7.3 per cent, not only implementing the cut in official rates but going further. Aussie Home Loans have reduced rates from 7.99 per cent to 7.49 per cent. St George Bank's standard variable rate has been reduced from 8.75 per cent to 8.2 per cent. The AMP Priority One variable rate has been reduced to 7.47 per cent. In relation to the Commonwealth Bank, the standard variable rate was dropped today from 8.75 per cent to 8.25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ought to ask you a supplementary.
—The member for Banks!

— When this government came to office the interest rate on the standard variable mortgage was 10.5 per cent. In relation to the Commonwealth Bank—the first of what I hope will be all of the major banks—it is now 8.25 per cent. That is a reduction of 2¼ per cent in relation to variable mortgages since this government came to office.
—You can't pay off a mortgage without a job.
—I warn the member for Banks.

— A reduction of 2½ per cent in a standard variable mortgage, for the average Australian on the average mortgage, represents a saving of $188 a month in relation to the reduction in home loan rates. That is $188 per month after tax. These are benefits which the home buyers of Australia are getting from a policy of locking in low inflation and a responsible budget.

ANSWER.PARA: We see the mournful faces of the Labor Party yet again. When Australia rejoices the Labor Party mourns, and they are in a deep period of mourning today in relation to responsible economic policy.

There are two things that you can do to lock in a low interest regime. The first is to keep inflation low and the second is to have responsible budget policy. The Labor Party stands opposed to both. It is at the moment, in the national wage case—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down, you dill.
—Be careful, psycho‐babble followed by exaggerated laughter! Be careful, it always starts off with the psycho‐babble.

—Mr Speaker, I intervene here on a point of relevance. This particular line has absolutely no relevance to the question asked of the gentleman. But I would ask him, while departing from the line, to keep smirking. It is one of the factors in our rising polls.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Here we go, Mr Speaker, the exaggerated laughter. I warn you, Mr Speaker, it is exaggerated laughter that always follows the psycho‐babble.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Speaker, there are two things that can be done to keep the interest rates low. The first is to keep inflation under control, and the second is to have responsible budget policy. Both those arms are opposed by Labor.

They are down in the national wage case trying to increase unemployment and increase inflation by supporting an unsustainable wage increase. They are up in the Senate trying to pull apart a balanced budget strategy. Both of these arms of policy are opposed by the Labor Party, which is against lower interest rates as a consequence.

Let it be entirely clear to the Australian people: a party that wants to increase inflation and a party that wants to oppose fiscal consolidation is a party that is in favour of high interest rates. And the Labor Party was the past master of high interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —We brought interest rates down.
—The member for Corio!

— Mr Speaker, this is a great day for home buyers. This is a great day for small business. These reductions will flow in, and have already flowed to credit card users as a consequence. These are the benefits of a low inflation, responsible budget strategy.

—Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the DEETYA leading indicator of employment for October, just released, has fallen for the seventh consecutive month; that is, every month since the government was elected? What immediate new steps will the cabinet's unemployment committee now take to reverse this steep decline in the jobs outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have not seen the indicator—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the member for Corio!

—Mr Speaker, I have not seen the indicator but the Leader of the Opposition invites me to say something about policies that might promote employment and reduce unemployment. One thing that will help promote employment is not only to lock in but to appear to permanently lock in lower inflation. One way those opposite can do that is to pass our budget and stop wasting time in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: If you had wanted to lock in a better economic climate and promote employment growth, instead of trying to frustrate our other measures in the Senate in the early months of the government you should have passed them. You profess yourself to be interested in employment generation. You profess yourself to be interested in progressive economic policy. You profess yourself to be interested in them, and yet every measure that this government has adopted to try to improve the climate you have opposed or tried to change.

Worst of all is the unbelievable gall of a man who had 13 years to fix it and now presumes to lecture us. This government was sworn into office a bare nine months ago today. The man who asked me the question was a senior minister in a government that took unemployment in this country to a post‐Depression high of over 11 per cent.

Every member of this House, whether they sit on the government side or the opposition side, ought to remember every time a question is asked by the opposition the contribution they gave to a legacy of high unemployment. For 13 years the average level of unemployment in this country under the former government was a whole two percentage points higher than the average level of unemployment under the previous government.

They took unemployment to a post‐Depression high. We had not seen such levels of unemployment for 60 years. It took a Labor government to remind Australians of what happened during the Great Depression, and you have the gall to ask us questions about unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the honourable member for Indi, I note that the House is showing distinct signs of severe and extreme disorderly behaviour. This is a general warning to all. I will act unhesitatingly.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In stark contrast to the last 13 years of Labor's lack of action in the fuel industry and the hardship caused to many people, including small business, can the Treasurer today provide details after only nine months in government of the new government's response to the inquiry by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission into the petroleum products declaration? Can the Treasurer outline to the House how the government will implement the petrol pricing policy of the Liberal and National parties? What will be the benefit for consumers of these reforms?
