ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Indi for his question. I acknowledge all the work that he did before the election in helping the coalition announce its policy and in bringing that policy to fruition today.

ANSWER.PARA: The government today announces the most comprehensive shake‐up of the petroleum industry, at least in the last two decades. This is a great structural reform in relation to the petroleum industry. This is a reform which has the capacity to deliver real benefits to consumers. Let me make it entirely clear that, in setting this policy, we have taken into account consumer benefits for those in both regional and rural areas.

In 1997 the government will lift the price surveillance in relation to petroleum products. It will be lifted once the oil majors have provided suitable undertakings for complete and open access at terminals not only to current distributors but also to new entrants, to new independents and to new wholesalers. This will mean that people who arrive at oil terminal gates will have access at open and transparent prices in relation to the material.

This government will also ensure that the Laidley agreement is not enforced. The Laidley agreement was one of those grubby deals done by the TWU in order to prevent open access to oil terminals. One of the reasons why the Labor Party did nothing about petrol pricing in 13 years was it was incapable of standing up to the TWU. Once you have a government that governs in accordance with the benefits to consumers and citizens and not trade union tsars you are able to engage in this kind of reform.

In addition, the government will encourage new entrants into the distribution market, some of which have already indicated and have already commenced. We will be encouraging state and local governments who have control of planning requirements to give access to new entrants who can come into the market and provide reform and restructuring in relation to the retail end of the market.

BREAK.PARA: The government is also disposed towards removing the application of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act once oil companies, distributors and retailers reach agreement on a new oil code and an appropriate code of conduct. We expect that the parties will enter into negotiations to achieve such an outcome over the next 12 months. The Department of Industry, Science and Tourism will work with industry participants to address concerns about an oil code.

I also note in passing that concerns about abuse of market power in relation to distributors and franchisees is already being considered by the House of Representatives fair trading inquiry, and we await the outcome of that. This is comprehensive structural reform. This is major deregulation in the petroleum industry. This stands in stark contrast to 13 years of inaction.

We heard earlier one of Labor's imputative spokesmen on Treasury matters asking why we would not agree to a Labor plan. There is one simple reason: there is no Labor plan. You would have thought, if there had been such a plan in 13 years, that we might have seen one piece of legislation. You would have thought, if there had been such a plan in 13 years, that we might have seen one press release. You would have thought that in 13 years, if there had been such a plan, we might have had one announcement.

Here are people who have luxuriated in 13 years of nothingness who suddenly find after an election that they had a plan, a plan which they did not even know about. I doubt whether the remaining part of the front bench has heard of it either. Here are people who, after 13 years of failed inaction, have cobbled together some kind of smokescreen to try to divert a government which after nine months has done what they were incapable of doing.

We have announced major structural reform. It is in accordance with recommendations from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. It will unleash new competitive forces in the industry, and that has the opportunity to deliver to consumers. This is a new deal for motorists, and this is the government that will deliver it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give the Treasurer a further opportunity to make a deeply unattractive spectacle of himself.
—Move to the question.

—Treasurer, how can you claim that this morning's interest rate reduction was not driven, above all else, by the weakness of the Australian economy, when you as Treasurer spent last night confessing that unemployment is now going to be worse than your budget forecast—a prediction which has just been confirmed by the DEETYA leading indicator, released 20 minutes ago, showing a fall in employment indications for the seventh consecutive month? How can you claim that it is otherwise than a response to the weakness of the Australian economy when the Prime Minister spent this morning on ABC radio foreshadowing that economic activity and revenue flows may well now be too low for the government to meet its budget deficit reduction targets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We notice the compliments that you hand to us in the preface to your question. Let us say that we love you dearly. You are one of the best things that has happened to this government since your appointment as deputy leader. May we wish you many long years in the job. May we also take this opportunity to wish you a happy Christmas, because it will be a happy Christmas for all of those home buyers who will be enjoying lower mortgage rates.

ANSWER.PARA: The comment that the Prime Minister made this morning, and I saw it, was that the government has laid down a plan to balance the budget over a three-year period. You do recall that was the plan you supported the day after the budget, before changing your position. He also made the point, as I saw it, that that plan could be under threat, and he is right. Whom is it under threat from? You. What are you complaining about now?

You are voting against every savings measure. You are trying to drive the budget into deficit. Then what do you say to the Prime Minister? `Look, the budget is going into deficit. We are succeeding.' What is your complaint against him? That you have been successful? What sort of logic do you have in relation to this? This is an opposition which has failed to come to terms with its electoral defeat. This is the born to rule school. They were in office for 13 years. They failed to come to terms with their defeat. They said they wanted to see a balanced budget, and then they voted against every measure that would get it there.

It is like saying, `I would like to drive from here to Sydney but I do not want to get in a car.' There is no logic. You are either for the balanced budget and you support the measures or you are against it, in which case you vote as you do. The Prime Minister was making the perfectly legitimate point that here is a government that had the courage to lay down a program to secure Australia's future, and there is an opposition that tried to sabotage it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the transcript of the Prime Minister's talk this morning when he attributed this to a slowdown in economic activity and revenue flow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. I draw the minister's attention to recent changes to Medicare eligibility rules for private psychiatric consultations. The minister had foreshadowed discussions with the college of psychiatrists on this matter. Would the minister please advise the House of the result of these discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question and her interest in this matter, as have other honourable members expressed an interest, in particular, the member for Kooyong. In the budget we announced that after 50 consultations in any 12-month period with a psychiatrist we would reduce the rebate by 50 per cent. The college of psychiatrists put to the government that this will cause a problem with a small number of people.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had discussions with the college and my department has had discussions with the college. We have come to an agreement that will accommodate these people. There are three small groups of people who may actually need more than 50 consultations a year. There are about 2,500 people seeing a consultant psychiatrist more than 50 times a year. We expect about 200 of those only will need additional treatment.

The college of psychiatrists has agreed that people who fall into the category of border line personality disorder, eating disorders, particularly anorexia nervosa or bulimia nervosa, or one of the three following psychiatric illnesses that have resulted from severe sexual or personal abuse—dysthymia, substance related disorders or somatisation—may qualify for additional treatments. In addition, the person will have been required to have had failed treatment in the past and, secondly, at an initial consultation display at least serious symptoms as are defined in the global assessment of functional scale which is contained in the DSM4, the generally accepted international schedule.

This will mean that those small number of people who may benefit from additional intensive psychiatry will be able to get it. In addition, the college of psychiatrists has agreed to state that it is generally inappropriate for intensive long-term psychiatric treatment outside hospital to exceed 220 visits per year. This will assist the Health Insurance Commission to police inappropriate psychiatric treatment, something that it has had very great difficulty in doing in the past. Accreditation of psychoanalysts within the college of psychiatrists will take place, and eventually the new item numbers for additional treatments will be restricted to psychiatrists with such accreditation. This will be a small number of psychiatrists, perhaps no more than 50 or 60.

What this means for the budget is that more than 90 per cent of the savings we sought to achieve will be achieved. We will have much tighter psychiatric treatment in Australia. We will now have the Health Insurance Commission with the power to tackle the rorts, something it has never had before. People who have genuine, well‐defined psychiatric problems that need this therapy will be able to get it and, hopefully, GPs will have a bit easier time trying to get their patients in to see a psychiatrist; one of the biggest complaints I get.
I would like to thank the college of psychiatrists for the very constructive role they have played in this. It shows what happens if people want to use reasoned debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the action taken in the other place earlier today to embrace the opposition's proposal to ensure that the power to direct Telstra remains with the minister for communications to help ensure that people in the bush get the same access to lower local telephone call charges that those in the city enjoy. Is it the intention of the government to support that desirable goal, or is the Prime Minister going to continue to deny the opportunity for people in the bush to enjoy the same cheaper local calls as the residents of Hunters Hill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the Leader of the Opposition should ask this question. Let me say to the Leader of the Opposition again that, under the telecommunications regime that we are putting in place, there is a guarantee that people will not pay higher charges than they do now. There is a guarantee of greater competition. I also remind the Leader of the Opposition that all his noisy protestations to the contrary cannot disguise the fact that much of the communications regime that is now before the Senate was modelled on an exposure draft that was released by the member for Dobell as the minister for communications in the former government. Included in that comment is the very device to which the Leader of the Opposition draws attention.

ANSWER.PARA: These questions cannot disguise the fact that, in the other place, the Labor Party has voted against not only the largest environmental initiative that any government has proposed since the end of World War II but also an investment of $250 million in telecommunications infrastructure.

Every time the Leader of the Opposition asks me a question about telecommunications in the bush, it gives me an opportunity to remind him and to remind people who live in the rural and regional areas of Australia that the Liberal and National parties want to help their telecommunications to be world class, 21st century, state of the art—and the Labor Party wants to oppose that. The Liberal and National parties want to make a great capital investment in the environment—and the Labor Party wants to stop that. The Liberal and National parties have in mind a 21st century that is built on high quality communications technology and proper protection of our environment—and the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats are disinterested in both.

I can do no better in concluding this answer than to draw on some remarks that were made by Alan Ramsey in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, a journalist who occasionally gives me a bit stick as he does those who sit opposite. He said, in effect, in his article that the world prize for being a bad loser in politics has got to go to the Labor Party on the subject of Telstra. He quite rightly reminded all of us that for 13 years the Labor Party made an art form of saying one thing about privatisation at an election and doing the exact opposite after. He reminded us that you promised not to sell the Commonwealth Bank—and you did. You promised not the privatise Qantas—and you did. You promised not to privatise Australian Airlines—and you did. We promised to sell one-third of Telstra. We are doing it, and you are doing your level best to frustrate the will of the Australian people. That is why you are held in such low repute and poor esteem, particularly on the issue of privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Prime Minister for conceding that his telecommunications reforms are ours. My supplementary question is: will you support the amendments?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition abuses the discretion on supplementary questions by asking a question which is not within your rules and, furthermore, by holding this House in greater contempt. He takes your invitation to put a supplementary question as an oppor tunity to make a speech. On that basis alone, Mr Speaker, it ought to be ruled out of order.
—The question was simple: will you support the amendment? It is an appropriate supplementary question.
—I take a great deal of interest in what the Leader of the House has mentioned, but the supplementary question is within the guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have ruled it is within the guidelines, I will be very happy to answer it. I will take the opportunity of commenting not only on the question but also on some of the babbling interjections of the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition cannot make up his mind. He is thanking me for acknowledging that our measure is his measure. If our measure is your measure, why are you voting against it?
—We are not.
—Oh! The Leader of the Opposition says that they are not voting against it. What are you doing with Telstra?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on relevance. The relevance is this: the particular measure that he is talking about—the competition policy—we are not voting against. We are dealing with a totally different matter. We are not voting against it.
—There is no point of order. Your question was short, precise, and is being answered similarly.

—Nothing can disguise the fact that, under the telecommunications regime that the coalition is putting into place, there is a guarantee that people will not pay higher charges, there is a guarantee of greater competition and there is also the undeniable fact that, under the former government, including when the Leader of the Opposition was himself responsible for telecommunications, there was absolutely no guarantee that there would never be price differentials. He in fact explained in a propaganda release that he put out to his own troops that that was the situation.

ANSWER.PARA: Against this kind of background, I say again to the Leader of the Opposition: you have no credibility in asking us questions about this. You cannot absolve yourself of the political responsibility in the Australian community for the fact that you are endeavouring to frustrate two of the most fundamental reforms that will work to the long-term benefit of people who live in the regional and rural areas of Australia. The first thing that you are trying to do by your actions in an—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order on relevance. The supplementary question was: would the government accept the Labor Party's amendment?
—There is no point of order.
—I remind the member for Melbourne that he is participating in an important debate later this day. Do not jeopardise your opportunity.
—I didn't say anything.
—The member for Melbourne has been constantly interjecting. Take heed.

—I say again to the Leader of the Opposition: nothing can absolve you from the political responsibility for endeavouring to strike down two reforms of the coalition that are going to do more to advance the cause of people who live in regional and rural Australia than any other measures that have been contemplated—namely, the establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, which will bring hundreds of millions of dollars of capital investment to do things that farmers and people living in rural and regional Australia have wanted done for years and which you were unable to do when you were in government. The second thing that you are endeavouring to frustrate is a $250 million telecommunications investment strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: You are displaying all the worst traits of bad losing in politics. You campaigned against one‐third of Telstra being sold. You campaigned against us. The Australian people gave a verdict. We are trying to implement the verdict of the Australian people. You and the Australian Democrats have spent hours and days in the other place endeavouring to deny to the people of the regions and the bush of Australia a 21st century telecommunications network and 21st century treatment and preservation of Australia's environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the difficulties faced by primary producers in my electorate of Parkes and across many other areas of Australia arising from the prolonged impact of drought on their farm cash flows. Minister, what is the government doing to help alleviate the strain on farmers from exceptional drought circumstances? Does the government's action acknowledge that it can take an extended lead time to recover the farm financial position even after drought has broken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and would certainly acknowledge that he and many others in this place have seen their constituents suffer from the enormous problems of drought, coupled with low commodity prices and high interest rates in recent years. So he has a real interest in this question of exceptional drought and how people and rural communities in general are going to recover from it.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say at the outset that on coming to government we implemented a complete and thorough review process for the rural adjustment scheme. We continue to work with the states to overhaul and implement a comprehensive drought policy and to make sure that the two are properly related to one another. I am delighted with the level of interest and the number of submissions that are coming forward in relation to the work that the review team is undertaking.

In the meantime, the coalition recognised that there would be many farmers and farm families out there who would have a very bleak Christmas this year in those areas where drought declarations were revoked on 11 June, following some decent seasonal breaks at last. There is a clear understanding on this side of the House that rain does not translate to a quick cash flow. The reality is that under the previous arrangement many hard‐pressed families would have had assistance, without which they could not carry on, withdrawn from today.

In response to this very urgent and serious problem the Prime Minister, the President of the National Farmers Federation and I paid a visit to Queensland. We went to Winton and Clermont. We talked with many people up there including the Premier of Queensland, Rob Borbidge. We have allocated an additional $81.5 million to extend drought relief payments for the period under which people are supported from six months to 12 months after exceptional circumstances revocation so that they can recover.

It is a real aid. Many farm families have been quite emotional in their expressions of gratitude over this, reflecting the extraordinary stress and pressure that they are feeling. It is a real aid to those families trying to maintain their business. It is a real aid too to those rural communities as they seek to recover from the devastation that they have experienced in recent times, particularly for the pastoral industries.

The beef and wool industries are in a mess. The wool industry is now suffering from a very serious problem of lack of demand for quality fibres, particularly in the Western world, arising largely out of flat economies in Europe. The beef industry is reeling from overproduction in the US and from real problems in terms of European and other consumption being down because of BSE.

That $81.5 million is on top of an additional $90 million found in June—all new coalition funding. When you couple it with three interest rate cuts since we came to government—worth around $90 million each to the farm sector if fully passed on—you really are looking at a very substantial improvement in the bottom line for Australia's hard‐pressed farmers.

Couple that with further achievements in reviving the heartland policy and some 40‐odd major policy proposals that have been fully implemented or are well down the road to implementation. It is a very proud record. The Prime Minister has just referred to a couple of the achievements. They will make a real difference to rural Australia, that vitally important part of our social and economic fabric so badly damaged after 13 years of neglect. We are getting on with the job of giving them a future again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment and the fact that it has fallen by 6.7 per cent? Has he seen the comments of the general manager of economics, Bill Evans, that the gloomy picture painted by this latest result is consistent with very subdued retail sales activity in recent months and with the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute leading and coincident indexes of economic activity? Has he seen the further comment:

QUESTION.PARA: In moving to cut interest rates by 0.5 per cent today, the Reserve Bank has clearly responded to the overall weakness in the economy exemplified by today's fall in consumer sentiment and the continuing low inflationary outlook.
Westpac expects further evidence will become available of a continuing soft economy and low inflation environment.

Will you now accept, Mr Treasurer, that this situation is a product of your excessively contractionary budget and your industrial relations policy which has so damaged consumer confidence in job security?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, let us go back over it. First of all, there was no deficit—do you recall that? In fact, the budget was balanced. That is what you said originally. Then there was a deficit and you were going to support it being balanced over three years. You then supported a balanced budget but you opposed every measure that would get it there. Now your shadow Treasurer is complaining that there is a deficit again. It is very hard to keep up with the twists and turns in opposition policy, because essentially you have not done the work to work things out, have you? You have not taken a position.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition, you are unable to discipline your front bench. It was obvious. You are from the right wing of the Labor Party. It is your job to rein in the left wing. And what do you do? You have got the member for Jagajaga out there on nursing homes. You have got the member for Hotham wanting to preserve tax rorts in R&D syndicates. He is running around Melbourne promising to keep the R&D syndicates. We are onto you. We know exactly what you are up to. We know why you want R&D tax syndicates. What is your answer for unemployment? To put the unemployed into tax syndicates? Do you think that will help them?

You could at least be supporting fiscal consolidation in relation to tax rorts. In fact, the December quarter ACCI Westpac survey reported that business confidence remains firm; a rebound in the September quarter. Except for the post‐election surge this year, business confidence remains higher than at any time for 1995 and 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order relating to relevance. The Treasurer is referring to the wrong survey. The survey which came out today on which the question is based is not the one to which he is referring. It is the consumer confidence survey which is showing consumer confidence down—that is what he was asked about.
—There is no point of order. The question was wide ranging; the answer is wide ranging.

—As I recall in relation to consumer confidence surveys, after the last cut in official interest rates you had the biggest increase since 1991. Let us look at the climate out there. We have got three official cuts in interest rates, an extra three‐quarters of a per cent as a result of competition, we have got families $188 better—
—Ours.
—Yours? Oh, I see—if interest rates fall, that is your responsibility, but if consumer confidence is low, that is our responsibility. Is that right?
—Probably.
—`Probably', he said. You ought to go to classes for Garenomics. You are no more sophisticated than he is.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It goes to relevance. The question quite clearly related to a collapse in consumer confidence—the 6.7 per cent figure that we used. Competition policy on interest rates was introduced by us, not them, as far as that competition goes, and he ought to stick to the answer.
—The Treasurer is coming to a conclusion.
—Yes, I will, Mr Speaker. In fact, I am told that one of the best sellers this Christmas will be a new release from the shadow Treasurer called `Garenomics made simple'.

ANSWER.PARA: The reduction in interest rates which occurred today—that was another part of the question by the Leader of the Opposition—was announced by the Reserve Bank of Australia in its release of today's date. It makes it entirely clear why there were the conditions for a reduction in interest rates. I will read it to you. It would actually be helpful if you read these things. It states:
This reduction essentially reflects a further improvement in the inflationary outlook.
Monetary policy is targeting inflation. The statement continues:
The Bank now expects underlying inflation to stay below—

TALK.START.PARA: —So?

—So? Because you are trying to undermine it. That is why you can take no responsibility in relation to monetary policy, and you are trying to undermine it in relation to the budget. That is why you can take no responsibility. But if you want to read what the Reserve Bank said, it is targeting inflation.
—On a point of order: Mr Speaker, I am sure you are not guilty of any of the things that the Treasurer is accusing you of. I ask that he direct his remarks through the chair.
—The Treasurer is aware of the conventions of the House.

—The other point the Reserve Bank makes clear is that the movement in the exchange rate will help to keep inflation down. Do you recall that? According to Garenomics, it was a fall in the dollar that was supposed to allow an interest rate reduction. But, as the Reserve Bank made clear today, it was a sustained increase over time that kept prices down, which gave us the break in relation to inflation, which gave us the break in relation to monetary policy. In answer to the question by the Leader of the Opposition, I table the Reserve Bank's statement. It makes it entirely clear, and I would urge him to read it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, you will recall at the time of the last election the Howard government committed itself to fundamental reform of aviation, undoubtedly one of Australia's most vital industries. Can the minister inform the House of the government's progress and achievements in meeting those commitments since taking office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hinkler, who takes a very great interest in aviation matters. It is a very important part of his local community's economy. There was, in the build-up to the last election, tremendous concern out in the community about issues relating to the aviation industry. To see why, one only has to go back to who was in charge of aviation at the time—the member for Kingsford‐Smith, known by his colleagues in the Labor Party as Dangerman. Dangerman was in charge of aviation in Australia. Is it any wonder, therefore, that there were some public concerns about it?

ANSWER.PARA: As a consequence of that, the coalition in opposition developed a very substantial aviation policy, which I am very pleased to be able to report to the House. We are in the process of fulfilling that speedily, effectively and fairly. We have designed all of our policies to build a safer, more competitive and more reliable aviation industry that can cope with the enormous growth potential that exists for aviation in Australia.

One of the highlights in our aviation policy, being released over the last little while, is the finalisation of the single aviation market. Those of us who have taken an interest in aviation over the last few years will remember that the former government talked about developing a single aviation market with New Zealand but when push came to shove they could not go with the flow. They could not stand up to the heat and they backed out of the particular agreement which had been agreed with the New Zealand government. When we came into government, we renegotiated a single aviation market and it came into effect on 1 November this year. It is interesting to note how significant a reform this is. The December issue of an aviation industry magazine states:

Not only is the single aviation market the most important aviation event in the last 20 years; it is also arguably the most far reaching economic development in the evolution of Australia-New Zealand relations.

It goes on to praise the coalition government's implementation of that single aviation market agreement with New Zealand which, incidentally, created a market worth $5,000 million a year, transporting 31 million passengers a year—a very substantial market indeed.

Also, we have entered into the sale of a number of our FAC airports. Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports are for sale. Adelaide will be put on sale next year. As part of that process, we have announced that landing charges at those airports will actually reduce, under our CPI minus X regime. We announced what the X factor was just the other day. Landing charges at those new privatised airports will go down—in Melbourne by 15 per cent, in Brisbane by 17 per cent and in Perth by 20 per cent—over the next five years under our new regime. Compare that to the proposal put forward by the former Labor government, which would have seen landing charges increase by 14 per cent per annum over the next three years.

In addition to that, we have had a substantial increase in international aviation capacity with other countries. It has increased under our negotiating regime by some 13 per cent over the last few months. For example, when we came into office I discovered that we had only one flight per week to China, one of the largest countries in the world and one of the fastest growing economies—an important tourist destination for Australia and for our tourism industry. We increased that under our negotiating regime from one flight per week to ultimately 13 flights per week. We have increased the air service agreements with Indonesia by some 40-odd per cent in the last couple of months. Dr Haryanto, the minister of communications in Indonesia, who handles transport matters, is here in Australia today negotiating further benefits for both Australia and Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great bloke.

—Yes, and he, indeed, is a very good minister and is doing a great job, not only for Indonesia but also for our relations with Australia. We then come to the other major area of the Labor Party's failings in aviation policy; that is, Sydney airport. Sydney airport was cause of considerable concern for people living in Sydney because of the very incompetent and dishonest management of the third runway at Sydney airport. We have reduced the amount of public concern over that issue simply by implementing our policy of sharing the noise. We have opened the east-west runway. Aircraft movements to the north of Sydney airport have now dropped from 50 per cent to some 33 per cent. Thirty-three per cent of those aircraft movements are now going to the north instead of 50 per cent under Labor's management—
—Where is your bill? We have been waiting.

—A substantial improvement for the constituents in your electorate; for example, in the suburbs of Sydenham, Marrickville, Stanmore, Leichhardt and Drummoyne. Those people are getting substantial benefit under policies which we have implemented since we have come to government.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps most important of all, there have been some very substantial steps forward in improving aviation safety under our policies, which will be further added to with new initiatives to be announced next year. All in all, these policies have helped create a more competitive, safe and reliable aviation environment to service the growing tourism industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer say whether the coalition government in Western Australia has included in its election platform the adoption of a federal goods and services tax? If not, can the Treasurer say why? Has the Premier of Western Australia advised the government that he will resume his advocacy of a broad based consumption tax after the polls close next Saturday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of whether that has been included in the election platform. I very much doubt it. I am sure I would be aware if it had been. Will the Premier resume advocacy after the election? Well—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members—Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I love to hear you all saying yes, because it is premised on the fact that he will still be the Premier on Sunday. All you geniuses of the Labor Party! Where do they find them? Where do they find such men? What the Premier of Western Australia advocates on Sunday is a matter for him. I am unable to comment, and I would not know.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Could he inform the House of the government's progress in the privatisation, outsourcing and commercialisation of DAS businesses as promised at the election? Could he further advise the extent to which property and procurement reforms are progressing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Some very real progress has been made and I think we are delivering some very positive outcomes for the taxpayers. There was a major change in DAS's focus. We initiated that in the lead‐up to the budget when I announced that there will be a number of strategic reviews of the DAS commercial businesses.

ANSWER.PARA: The outcomes of those reviews were announced in the budget when the government decided to sell or to restructure 12 DAS businesses: Asset Services, the DAS Centre for Environmental Management, DAS Distribution, DAS Interiors, Works Australia and the Australian Operational Support Services are being offered for sale.

The sale process is being conducted at arm's length from the businesses by the Office of Asset Sales within the Finance portfolio, and that is well advanced. There has been very strong interest from the private sector. The advertising, short‐listing and selection of the successful purchasers will occur early in the new year, with the sale of the businesses expected to be finalised by the end of the financial year.

Five of the businesses will be retained in government ownership because they provide important public interest functions. They are the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, the Australian Government Publishing Service, the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, the Australian Valuation Office and Removals Australia.

Nonetheless, the government believes that these businesses should also be reformed to ensure that their programs are delivered more efficiently and more effectively. To this end, their commercial activities will be market tested. For example, in relation to the AGPS, proposals have been sought from the private sector in relation to 12 activities, including core parliamentary and government printing and security printing of such items as passports and citizenship certificates.

Similarly, Auslig's commercial activities in the areas of geographic management information systems and consultancies, field surveying, customised mapping and navigation services are also to be market tested. Removals Australia, which performs a valuable and profitable whole of government procurement function, is being retained within government ownership, but from 1 July next year it will have to compete on a fully competitive neutral basis and be exposed to a full taxation regime.

Just last week I announced that up to $100 million worth of business will be let out to private sector removalists. The government has also sought proposals on the sale or refinancing of Dasfleet and we expect to reach a decision on that before the end of the financial year.

The sale and market testing of a wide range of commercial activities will create major opportunities for the private sector, and especially for small and medium enterprises, allowing them to gain further access to a government market which is valued at some $450 million a year.

I also announced in the budget significant changes to the way in which the government's real property portfolio is to be managed. Fundamentally, the government believes it should own property only where there is a real economic benefit from public ownership or where there is a strong public interest argument for doing so.

To this end, a Commonwealth Property Committee, comprising both public and private sector expertise, was formed in August 1996 to review the Commonwealth's commercial estate against the Commonwealth's property principles adopted by the government earlier this year.

I do anticipate there will be some significant property divestment and that will be undertaken over the next few years. Frankly, that is going to deliver some very significant savings to the taxpayer and some real business opportunities in the private sector. Already, 11 Commonwealth properties around Australia have been earmarked for sale.

In addition, the government is outsourcing its property management functions and that will give us an estimated saving of $4 million. In addition, I recently announced the appointment of a series of panels of real estate agents to assist in the sale of Commonwealth properties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The minister is quoting from a document and, pursuant to standing order 321, I require him to table it.
—The minister has been asked a very widely based question associated with privatisation within the public sector and he has not yet completed his answer.

—These reforms are going to deliver savings of $690 million over four years, with the Office of Asset Sales assisting in returning to government an estimated $440 million over the same period as a result of asset sales, refinancing and the related measures.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member mentioned procurement reforms: we are going to be a very active and central player in implementing the coalition government's reform agenda. It is well placed to provide expertise and policy guidance on procurement and contracting out and we are already playing a key role in developing guidelines for competitive tendering.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the 10 per cent estimate.

—I will tell you about the 10 per cent because I think we are going to do much better than the 10 per cent and we will be making some announcements about that very soon. Recently, the government had contracted Telstra as the government's strategic partner for the provision of the Commonwealth Electronic Commerce Service, to be known as TRANSIGO. TRANSIGO is going to operate across industry and government, allowing electronic transactions to be conducted in a secure and reliable environment. The system is structured so that small business can take advantage of it to reduce the search and tender costs of doing business with government. Electronic trading will make government purchasing—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is now clearly a policy statement. It is being read word for word. It is not an answer to a question; it is a policy statement and has no place in question time.
—There is no point of order. The question was comprehensive. The answer is equally comprehensive. I know the minister is rapidly drawing his answer to a conclusion.

—The advent of electronic commerce is going to be a major boon to small and medium enterprises in Australia. Quite frankly, these reforms are going to change the nature of the way the government does business. Most importantly, they are going to make a major contribution to the achievement of a vibrant, efficient and most effective public sector.
—Mr Speaker, as I indicated earlier, the minister was quoting from a document and I therefore require him to table it.
—Was the minister quoting from confidential material?
—The document is marked `confidential', Mr Speaker.
—I raise a further point of order, Mr Speaker. If the document was confidential, why was the minister reading it to the House?
—There were obvious elements within the document that were classified. The balance was generally available and I trust the minister's good judgment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer to the minister's press release of 23 July and his statement in the parliament on 11 September in which he and the Treasurer used four `actual' examples of rorts to justify cuts to research and development funding. Is the minister aware of evidence by his own department to the Senate that not one of these was an actual example? When did the minister learn they were not actual and that the `Wright family' had moved into R&D syndication? Why has the minister not corrected the record as required by the Prime Minister's code of conduct?

—I am surprised that the member did not get around to this some time ago. He is well known around Melbourne for his transport habits in back seats of Rolls Royces. So I dare say they are the ones who pointed out these little things to him—`Maybe there is a point in this, so you ought to ask the minister whether it is true or not, because it just might be me he's talking about'—you know, over the back seat of the Rolls Royce. So that is the way he carries on. Not only that, the member for Hotham should be aware that under section 45D of the R&D act, I am prohibited from giving precise examples. These are examples of what happened in every case with the finer details changed to fit the occasion. There is nothing wrong with that. But what is wrong with this is your behaviour as you go around telling your tax rorters, `Keep up the pace. We might just turn this around in the Senate if we keep objecting to it and by doing that, we'll get a good return for you for Christmas.' That is the sort of stuff you are up to.
—As a supplementary question, I ask the minister: if he cannot refer to them because of confidentiality, why does his press release refer to them as `actual' examples?
—There are no grounds for a supplementary question.
—I seek leave to table the press release of the minister.
—Oh, leave is not granted. They are frauds.
—Order! Resume your seat!
—Mr Speaker, he should be required to withdraw offensive language.
—In the general hubbub, I did not hear the remark, but I call upon the honourable member for Hotham to withdraw.
—Double standards. I withdraw.

—Mr Speaker, I rise to make the very obvious point on a point of order, that is, that the withdrawal was qualified. There is no room for qualified or conditional withdrawals and, on that basis, he should be required to withdraw.
—When the din has finally settled, Mr Speaker, I will make my point clearly. You are not entitled to withdraw and impose your own qualification on the withdrawal.

—Speaking to the point of order: this is diabolical brass coming from the manager of government business, who alone as a person in this House has refused to withdraw when called upon by you. This man stood up and said, `I withdraw', which ought to be sufficient unto itself.
—It is sufficient.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Would the minister advise the House how the Howard government is handling the task of restoring public confidence in immigration and settlement services as promised at the March election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition did at the time of the election commit itself to administer an immigration program that has broad public and community support, that is suited to Australia's national interests and international responsibilities and that balances economic, social, environmental and international considerations.

ANSWER.PARA: We also committed ourselves to widespread consultation in relation to the settlement of an immigration program. We committed ourselves to continuing the longstanding commitment to a non‐discriminatory approach on the basis of race, ethnicity, nationality, gender and religion.

We did inherit an immigration program that was out of balance and out of control. The family stream was taking up about 70 per cent of the program. The spouse category had grown by over 32 per cent, while the parent category had grown by over 74 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —People are not allowed a marriage of their choice. What a shame.
—`What a shame', he says. Reports of abuse of the program and of sham marriages have become commonplace. And I get something of the order of 50 complaints a month from people who are abused by those—
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. I invoke standing order 304A in respect of the member for Isaacs. Remove yourself from the chamber forthwith. Forthwith!

PARA.EMPHASIS: The member for Isaacs thereupon withdrew from the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —The members opposite seem anxious to challenge the efficacy of the argument that there were widespread abuse and sham marriages becoming commonplace in the immigration program. It is important to put some of the evidence on the table in relation to those matters. We saw not only a 33 per cent increase in the number of successful applicants in the spouse category but also a 50 per cent reduction in the number of applications rejected overseas on the basis of their being non‐bona fide, and that occurred in the context of instructions that were given—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The migration bill before the House goes directly to these issues. Therefore, in the middle of this process, the minister is not entitled to answer a question in relation to this particular matter. He is anticipating the debate of the House.
—There is no point of order.

—I would not anticipate the debate but I do want to deal with some of the implementation issues which are quite unrelated to the aspects of the bill that the member was drawing attention to. We have sought to re‐regulate the requirement that people who enter into a marriage or a de facto relationship, or a fiance who enters Australia on a temporary basis, because those provisions were disallowed in the Senate as part of the general disallowance of measures that were undertaken by the opposition to ensure that the issues—
—A two-year probationary period we gave you.

—Yes, I acknowledge that you agreed to those matters being reintroduced. I would like to think that you would also reassess your approach on some of the other matters that you sought to disallow. They are very important issues to consider when addressing the question of confidence in the way in which the immigration program is conducted. We gave a commitment before the election that what we were about was restoring public confidence in the way in which that program is administered.
—Everything you asked in relation to fraud we gave you.
—Only in relation to the issues of fraud but not in relation to the issues of confidence in the way in which the program is conducted.

PARA.BREAK: Let me make it clear that we have acted quickly to restore public confidence in the program. We have announced a smaller and significantly more balanced program, and it is one that is in the national interest. It seeks to address the significant problem that occur red under you, where last year some 29 per cent of the program was devoted to skilled categories of entry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my point of order follows the request of the member for Calwell. Plainly, the matters in relation to control of the fraud program were matters outside the debate in migration bill No. 3. But the matters the minister is now addressing are entirely within the realm of migration bill No. 3. It is under debate in this House currently.
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—I am addressing the issue of getting balance back into the program. What we saw under Labor was a situation where only 29 per cent of the program was for skilled migration. We have restored the skilled migration category, in part, to 37 per cent. If you look at the Canadian program, you will find that skilled migration categories comprise 50 per cent of the program as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: We have not been inactive on other matters in the migration area. The issue of balance has been an important question, but we have also been able to improve the temporary entry arrangements. We have been able to implement the Roach committee recommendations where we were able to get pre‐qualification of those people who are entering Australia on a temporary basis.

The Prime Minister was involved several weeks ago in the implementation of the APEC business card, an important initiative that will ensure that we are able to obtain more ready access of business people to Australia and to enhance our trade within the region. We have implemented the electronic travel authority, which has ensured that we have been able to get reciprocal arrangements with the United States so that tourists from Australia are now able to access the United States without a visa. In the settlement area, not only have we been able to ensure that a settlement program is maintained but also we have committed an extra $20.7 million to improve settlement programs after next year for particularly refugee and humanitarian entrants. In the area of English language tuition, we are embarking upon particularly important reforms which involve the tendering process to make the adult migrant education program more effective and flexible.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a statement.
—If you would like me to keep on going—because we have been very active in this portfolio area—I could add a number of other issues that we have been able to deal with quite effectively.

—Mr Speaker, I have a further point of order: I made the point that the Labor Party supported the minister in every matter that he has raised in relation to fraud control, but the matters he is raising are on the blue. He is debating the matters that the House is currently debating.
—We are not debating the issue. The minister is not anticipating the debate. Resume your place.

—I would just mention two other matters. We have also instigated a major review of the process of immigration decision making to improve the confidence and efficiency of the system. I hope to be making some announcements during the course of next year to give effect to the decisions that the government will be taking in that area. We have also maintained the integrity of our border arrangements. We have been able to demonstrate that we can achieve removal from Australia quickly of non-bona fide asylum claimants who enter Australia. I was pleased to be able to ensure that we were able to remove most of those people during the course of this year—some of them within the space of two weeks.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer to the minister's weekend statement that negotiations on the compensation package for Howe Leather will be considered by cabinet before Christmas. Is the minister aware that Howe Leather's two major facilities are located in the two highest areas of unemployment in Victoria—in the Gippsland electorate of the Minister for Science and Technology and in my electorate of Batman? On the question of job security, in the Christmas spirit, can the minister assure the 520 Howe Leather workers and their families that there will be no danger to their job security resulting from the amount of compensation provided?

—I am quite sure the questioner would have had the same feeling for the workers when he was president of the ACTU with the number of unemployed that were around at that stage. As the question relates to Howe Leather, can I just congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade for negotiating the outcome that occurred there. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

During the course of the election campaign the coalition committed itself to maintain the financial assistance grants for local government at a level at least as high as was provided by the previous Labor government. Can the minister advise the House whether the Howard government's election commitment has been honoured? Can he also advise the House on the progress of any other election commitments in his portfolio?

QUESTION.PARA: Mr WARWICK SMITH—I thank the member for his question, primarily about local government. I am able to confirm to the member that the Howard government did meet its election commitments to local government—and significantly so. There was an absolute increase in grants to local government of four per cent, which is a total amount of $1.2 billion. If I am correct, the benefit to the member's electorate of Leichhardt was an increase of 6.3 per cent to $15.2 million. The electorates of all members in this House benefited by the decision of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to support local government. Indeed, when the Prime Minister attended the Australian local governments national conference this week he indicated to the new chairman, the Deputy Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Mr Campbell, who came to see me this morning, that they were extremely grateful that the government had seen that local government does play a pre-eminent role in our nation.

The member also asked what other areas in my portfolio—extensive as it is—had benefited from undertakings by the government. One area I want to draw attention to is a program called maintain the momentum. That was a program we undertook in the budget to reinstate, to continue. It provides $35 million a year for broadening the base of support to Australian sport through the Australian Sports Commission.

The interesting thing I found when we took this matter to cabinet to discuss it was that the Labor Party had decided in their last budget, and here is the piece of paper from the finance minister at the time—that was you, Mr Beazley—that `the maintain the momentum sports funding ceases after the provision of the 1995-96 financial year'. I want to know why it is you hate sport. Why do you hate sport? That would have devastated—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been grievously misrepresented. I love sport, Mr Speaker!
—There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —You may have been grievously misrepresented, but the facts are here. It is like the question about telecommunications. You cannot walk away from the facts. You took $35 million away from Australian sport, and the sporting community in this nation knows that. Furthermore, we are committed to the continuation of the Olympic athlete program to support our athletes as they prepare for the year 2000. We will spend $95 million in supporting young Australians to prepare themselves for the Olympic games.

ANSWER.PARA: I will take the opportunity to talk about my portfolio. Today we issued a new program called active Australia. The shadow minister was there. This program is aimed at broadening the base of recreation and sport in this nation. It is supported by all the states, it is sported by every institute of sport in this nation, it is supported by the Local Government Association of this nation and it is strongly supported by this government. BREAK.PARA: Finally, I would indicate that in the area of territories there has been major progress in a whole range of areas, one of which is the Australian Capital Territory, which the Prime Minister will be addressing tomorrow. There has also been progress in Norfolk Island, in Christmas Island—represented by the member for the Northern Territory—in the Northern Territory, in the Coral Sea Islands and in the Ashmore and Cartier Islands. No people live there, but I am pleased to inform the House that we still own them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Has the minister seen an Australian Business Chamber survey which predicts that 3,000 manufacturing jobs will be lost in New South Wales next year—a figure which translates to 12,000 retrenchments nationally? Has he also seen the Westpac survey of industrial trends which projects a further deterioration in manufacturing employment? In light of these figures, will the minister reaffirm the government's election commitment to create 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing by the turn of the century?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The question from the honourable member for Hotham reflects on a number of surveys taken in recent times. They reflect different activity in different states. The most important thing is that the national accounts, based on the ABS survey, show that output was up by 2.4 per cent in the September quarter and over six per cent on the previous year, so it cannot be all bad.
