As a consequence, I would have every reason to be confident of the outcome of the economy next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question. I specifically asked the minister: would he reaffirm his commitment to create 200,000 jobs in manufacturing by the turn of the century? He has failed to answer it. I invite him to do so by way of a supplementary answer.
—Order! The question is outside the guidelines.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Prior to the election, the coalition promised as one of its major priorities to deliver a new deal for small business. The coalition has also promised significant reforms in the area of consumer affairs and customs. Would the minister explain to the House what the Howard government has achieved in the nine months since the March election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The government can be proud of its remarkable list of achievements in just nine months. In our policy area of a new deal for small business, we certainly have delivered. We have progressed a favourable business climate; responsible economic management has lowered interest rates and given a better deal for small business. There have been three interest rate falls in just five months—a remarkable achievement that directly benefits all small businesses and consumers. In the capital gains tax rollover area, the Prime Minister a short while ago explained to the House that we went further than our policy commitment. While it has been stated before, it is worth quoting again the article from the BRW from Robert Gottliebsen—
—For heaven's sake!
—It is a significant point and you don't like it. It is not us saying it. The quote you hate goes:

ANSWER.PARA: The small business capital‐gains‐tax rollover relief is the most significant change made to taxation in Australia for decades.

It is something you landed small business with and we have fixed it for them. In addition, the small business summit was well attended by state and local government. The micro‐business consultative group is pleased that this government is talking to that end of the market after being ignored by the former government.

In addition, I will be meeting with state ministers to discuss the Small Business Deregulation Task Force report that was given to the Prime Minister on 1 November. We have instigated a House of Representatives inquiry into fair trading, an issue that small business has been very worried about. So in the small business area we have certainly delivered. After 13 years of being ignored by the previous government we have at least listened to their concerns—and they appreciate that. That quote is just one of many from small business organisations supporting the initiatives of this government.

In the area of consumer affairs we have taken steps to foster and encourage self‐regulation to give consumers a new and better option in this area. We have developed draft principles and guidelines for service charters. In the area of service charters for government the Prime Minister personally wrote to me and asked me to take charge of service charters for government services, something that your mob never proposed to do. We have instigated a new national advisory council for consumer affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I make two points. This is clearly a policy statement and outside the guidelines for question time. And is it possible for the Leader of the Opposition to ask that further questions be placed on notice?
—There is no point of order.

—This mob does not realise that we have so much good news it takes this long to tell it all, particularly in regard to small business. Small business is delighted with what we have delivered. In Customs, we have introduced an exposure draft in the cargo management strategy area. Customs won a national award for excellence in public management. Customs also revised the regulations governing the importation of firearms—another initiative of the Prime Minister. Customs has been involved in a number of drug busts in the illicit drugs area: cannabis, a drug bust of some 5.1 tonnes; cocaine, 92 kilograms; heroin, 60 kilograms; and ecstasy, 30 kilograms. In addition, Customs has purchased the patrol vessel Wauri and introduced new technology. In the small business area there is no doubt that this government—

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: on the question of relevance, perhaps the relevance of record bankruptcies might be included in the minister's answer. There are record bankruptcies in Australia right now.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—The honourable member forgets the record bankruptcies when they were in government—and the recession. They do not understand that in nine months we have given the business sector the opportunity for lower interest rates and the opportunity for confidence to grow. On 1 January, consumer confidence will grow because we are going to give them a tax cut—a great new year's present. It is a remarkable achievement in nine months for this government in the small business, consumer affairs and customs portfolio area. There is no doubt that the small business sector is well served by the Howard government.

—My question is to the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister seen reports of comments by a senior officer of the Western Australian health department that pensioners needing home and community care such as Meals on Wheels will have to pay up to $30 per week because of the anti‐aged federal budget? Will the minister guarantee to the elderly of Western Australia that they will not have to pay such an impost?

—I thank the member for that question. The fact is that in our budget we did make allowance for a 6.6 per cent increase in funding for the home and community care program. We also announced that we would work with the states and territories, because they are the deliverers of the services. It is a joint program between the Commonwealth and the state and territory governments. We did announce that we would seek with the states and territories to introduce a user‐charge policy. That policy is on the basis that those who can afford to make a small contribution towards their care will do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Science and Technology. Are you aware of an Australian world-first breakthrough using gene technology? Can you inform the House of other recent developments in this important area of science and explain what the Howard government is doing to ensure the community is informed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McGauran, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Hughes for her question. I am delighted to inform the House, particularly members from wine growing areas, that CSIRO researchers have achieved a scientific breakthrough of international significance with the creation of what may well be the world's first genetically modified grapevine. The vine, which paves the way for major gains in productivity and quality for Australia's $650 million wine, grape and dried fruits industries was developed at CSIRO's Division of Horticulture in Adelaide.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has been involved in a neck and neck race with France and America to make this discovery. As a result of the breakthrough, we will be able to create grapevines of enhanced flavour, improved colour development and increased disease resistance. The discovery represents a very large gamble that has paid off for the Australian wine industry. The industry has invested in the project, recognising the potential returns, even though the chances of success when they started out on this long journey of scientific discovery were low.

PARA.BREAK: Today's announcement coincides with consumer and environmental concerns expressed on Channel 9's A Current Affair program last night dealing with gene technology, or genetic engineering. Last week the first shipment of genetically modified foodstuff arrived in Australia in the form of Round Up ready soya beans which have been altered to resist herbicides. I would like to assure consumer groups and the community at large that the soya beans have been approved only after the most stringent guidelines laid down and enforced by the Austral ian Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee, GEMAC, as well as the United States Food and Drug Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: The soya beans pose no health risk to consumers. Nevertheless, the government is addressing a number of issues concerning the regulation of gene technology and labelling of gene technology food products in Australia to ensure that the industry has a clear assessment and approval process and that consumers can have full confidence in the safety of products.

I was just looking for the Leader of the Opposition—running out to get some new questions, because you have exhausted your supply. They had a quick tactics meeting, an emergency gathering, asking, `What can we do to keep question time going?' It just goes to show that the government is not in the slightest intimidated by or scared of your questions.

In drawing to a conclusion, can I say that, under existing and proposed guidelines, the public has nothing to fear from genetic technology but, instead, can look forward to very significant benefits in human and animal health, food production and agriculture because the technology offers very considerable improvement in agricultural yields, higher quality products, increased resistance to disease and pests, and reduced use of environmentally harmful chemicals. At the same time, public safety will not be compromised by this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has the minister seen reports that the Managing Director of the ABC conceded that, under the federal government's plans to slash $55 million from the broadcaster next year, the corporation would still have to make a further $28 million in savings and conceded that it might have to come from eliminating programs? Will the government guarantee that programs such as the live radio broadcast of the forthcoming Ashes cricket test series from England, the rugby league match of the day, the netball series, and the Australian Football League match of the day will be broadcast live by the ABC next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank the shadow minister for sport for his first question to me on the matter of sport.
—Do you know what those games are?
—Yes, I do actually know what those games are. I have been wandering along to watch them. I have to say that I salute the sportsmen and sportswomen of this nation. They do a great job.

ANSWER.PARA: I would hope that ABC, the broadcasting authority of this nation—and I have not seen the remarks to which the member referred—would take account of the fact that Australians would like to see those matters on television. Programming, of course, is a matter for the ABC and it would not be correct for the government to intervene, but I would be hoping that they would take account of the views that I have, and those of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts, about the types of sport that should be broadcast on the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will supplement that answer by saying that I expect the ABC to take very careful note of what the minister has said.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. This week we heard of timber mill closures on the north coast of New South Wales, with more on the way, all due to Bob Carr's New South Wales Labor policies. What is our federal government's response to these policies that put people out of work at Christmas time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am not surprised that the honourable member for Paterson should raise this question because it goes very much to the heart of the survival of a very important industry, particularly in some of the coastal areas of New South Wales. I want to take the opportunity of saying a few things very seriously to the House about the way in which the government in New South Wales is jeopardising what was meant to be an orderly and fairly bipartisan process to achieve a balance between the needs of our timber industry and environmental protection in New South Wales and, indeed, throughout Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been concerned for some time about the Carr government's approach to forest policy in New South Wales. Recent decisions taken by the Carr government are an unacceptable pre‐emption of the processes agreed between our government for assessing our forests and establishing regional forest agreements.

A number of members of the government, including the member for Paterson, the member for Page, the member for Cowper and the member for Eden‐Monaro, have expressed concerns to me that, by its pre‐emptive process, the Carr government is putting at risk not only the jobs of timber workers on the eve of Christmas but the Carr government, by its pre‐emptive behaviour, is also threatening to undermine an agreement that was originally forged between the former Keating government and the various state governments of Australia.

The Carr government is trying to detonate an arrangement originally made between the federal Labor government and the state Labor government of New South Wales. I am not surprised that my colleague should be concerned about it. We do not condone or support for a moment the anti‐job behaviour of the Carr government in the coastal areas of New South Wales. They are putting workers out of jobs. They are closing down timber mills. They are undermining a process that was meant to be bipartisan and which was meant to achieve a balance between conservation and development. The fact that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you're talking about.
—Somebody opposite interjects, `What are you talking about?' We are talking about the future of jobs for Australians on the eve of Christmas.
—That was Fremantle.

—That was the member for Fremantle, who is supposed to be the shadow minister for the environment. I am talking about the Carr government doing its level best to destroy a delicate balance that was struck between development and the environment. Once again, the people who are getting it in the neck are the blue‐collar workers of the timber industry of Australia, the people who used to believe that the Australian Labor Party cared about them, the people who used to believe that their natural political home was the Australian Labor Party. By its behaviour, the Carr government is demonstrating that it is willing to put this very important process at risk.

ANSWER.PARA: Here is the best illustration of its hypocrisy. In September the New South Wales government announced the results of its so-called forest interim assessment process and then entrenched them in a series of permanent decisions with new wilderness and national park declarations, long-term wood supply agreements and further reductions in wood supply quotas. I would like to know whether the federal Labor Party supports the New South Wales Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do.

—You do? We have a Victorian Labor member who supports it. Does the Leader of the Opposition support it? No, the Leader of the Opposition can't make up his mind. Lindsay Tanner supports the New South Wales government. I suppose Carmen Lawrence does. I wonder whether Steve Martin supports the New South Wales government. I think he is smart enough. What about the member for Hunter?

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition is encouraging me to get on with it. Did you know that this Leader of the Opposition is the first opposition leader in the history of federation to plead for an end to question time. He is the first person. I have never known a Leader of the Opposition not to want to ask questions.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This has been an unbelievably pathetic question time.
—What is your point of order?
—The point of order goes to the behaviour in this House. It is not appro priate in answering a question to start questioning the other side.
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat.
—I am happy enough to answer questions. Let us change the standing orders.
—There is no point of order.

—Can I just say to the House that I have had a lot of experience of being an opposition leader. I hope the present opposition leader has plenty of time to emulate my long experience. I have to say that, no matter what difficulties you get into as an opposition leader, no matter how many troughs you fall into, there is one thing you never do: you never plead for an end to question time.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: your ruling means that it is allowable for us to invite comments from those opposite in our speeches and not speak through you. Is that your ruling?
—There is no point of order.

—Can I just assure the member for Paterson and all those other members of the Liberal and National parties who have raised concerns on behalf of their constituents, who are worried that timber workers will lose their jobs before Christmas and who are worried about the behaviour of the New South Wales government in undermining this delicate balance—this policy that seeks to strike a balance between development and care for our environment—that we do not support the pre‐emptive decisions taken by the New South Wales government. We are concerned that they are undermining the credibility of the process.

ANSWER.PARA: We have always said that, as we move to establish the reserve system and secure the future of our forest industries, we will take full account of the social and economic issues involved. Demonstrably, the New South Wales government does not care about the economic and social dislocation in the coastal areas of Australia. It does not care if people lose their jobs. It is in the grip of a minority interest on this issue. It does not care about preserving a balance. It does not care about the future of blue‐collar jobs in the timber industry of Australia.

In concluding this question time, I want to give an assurance to all members of the coalition backbench and all representatives that we will look after the interests of the timber workers. We will preserve the integrity of the process and we will achieve that delicate balance between environment and development. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you may recall my question to you the other day asking whether the configuration of the school visits program to Parliament House had led to a disproportionately small representation of groups visiting Parliament House from Western Australian schools. Mr Speaker, how will the recently announced across‐the‐board cut to the program make it fairer for WA schools? Is it fair to predict that the cuts will in fact mean that even fewer WA school students will come to Parliament House as part of the program to visit their national parliament?

—We have looked at the problems associated with the program comprehensively and we have aimed to be as fair as it is humanly possible to be. The recent cuts that have been announced are in no way designed to reflect adversely against representation from Western Australia, but the 15 per cent reduction right across the board will apply to everybody. The question you raised with me the other day remains something that we are looking at separately.

—Mr Speaker, are you aware of a proposition to install the Speaker's chair from Old Parliament House into this chamber? Could you inform the House what would be the cost of relocating the chair? In the event that it were relocated here, what would be the cost of building a replica for the chamber in Old Parliament House?
—I thank the honourable member for Fowler for his question. I know that it is being actively considered in government, and the Leader of the House might care to amplify.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On indulgence, this matter was raised in the party room of the government parties yesterday. There was a general disposition towards the concept, but there was also a view that before the matter was considered further some information should be obtained as to costings and all the matters associated with the proposition. I will be writing to you today, Mr Speaker, to ask of you whether the information that is on file that was gained originally could be made available so the issue could be looked at properly on the basis of that information.
—This is the most stupid thing we have ever heard of.

—In response to the interjections, it was intended—and the relevant committee of this House made this decision—that the chair that we had in Old Parliament House would come up here. A different decision was made in late 1987, when the final decision was made to adopt the chair that we now have.

ANSWER.PARA: This matter has had a long controversy. There were very strong objections to the last-minute change made in the design of the building in respect of the chair. In fairness to the proponents of the idea, the concept simply is that that chair does have a lot of the history and tradition of the parliament and on that basis, as a symbolic transfer of the traditions and history of the House, the chair should have been made available and installed in this new House.

I appreciate that there are some for whom bringing our traditions with us into the new parliament is akin to bringing constitutional baggage with which they disagree. I think that was the attitude of some—but not the attitude of all—when that decision was made.

Finally, there will be some consideration of the matter, and it will be a detailed consideration. There will be a further discussion in our party room about the matter and, in due course, we will say more about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question to you was designed to find out the cost. The alarming rumours—and few are aware of them—were that removing the chair only would cost between $300,000 and $500,000. That is without the replica. I want to know whether there is any substantial information on that score.

—On indulgence, just to repeat the point I made in my answer a moment ago for the benefit of the honourable member, who seemed to have missed it: I am writing to the Speaker to ask him what information we have about costs. When we have a response from the Speaker, I am sure that the information can be made available to you. As at this moment, we have not received any advice as to what those costs might be, because I have not yet passed the letter to the Speaker. As soon as we receive the advice, you will be entitled to have it.

—In response to the honourable member for Fowler, any answer in terms of financial estimates would be highly speculative. I await the early receipt of the correspondence that the minister has alluded to, and we will embrace the House in any deliberations.

—Mr Speaker, in your consideration and deliberations on the issue of the Speaker's chair, could you also advise us whether it would be necessary to dismantle the chair that is in Old Parliament House? Alternatively, as I seem to recall was the case when we last looked at this, the indications were that it would have been necessary to construct a hole in the side of the old House of Representatives chamber in order to remove the chair from that chamber and deliver and install it in this chamber. Could you also include that in your consideration?

—Most of the points being raised are speculative because I have not yet received the correspondence in question. Be assured that the chair would be disassembled in one form or another, but recognise that it is an incredibly significant chair in relation to the parliament. It comes from the timbers of the original houses of Westminster and the timbers of HMS Victory . It is a very significant national monument, and I await the early receipt of the correspondence that the minister has alluded to.
—Mr Speaker, I am reluctant to pursue this matter, but could you have an answer for me and the parliament by the close of business before Christmas?

—Again, this is speculative. I cannot respond in definitive terms to you or the minister until I see the array of questions that are being asked. In my office today we addressed the question in very general terms about cost, and at the moment the considerations are very general. We will address the definitive questions as soon as we see the correspondence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Treasurer claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Proceed.
—In another example of poor journalism by the Sydney Morning Herald , under today's headline of `Super funds risky, inquiry warned', the journalist Paul Cleary said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ISC sets out a detailed case against the "hands off" disclosure regime being pushed by Treasury and supported by the Treasurer, Mr Costello.

The Treasurer's buyer‐beware system, which would mean full disclosure of detailed financial information from financial institutions, has also been criticised in the Reserve Bank's submission to the inquiry.

He was referring there to the Wallis inquiry. I have already made this point in the House, and I make it again. I am pushing no particular outcome on the Wallis inquiry. The Wallis inquiry has been set up as an independent committee of experts. People have been encouraged to make submissions to it. The government will deal with the outcome, but I am not putting any particular outcome to that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Most grievously.
—Proceed.

—Today the Australian newspaper printed a comprehensive list of those who voted for, those who voted against and those who did not vote on the bill known as the Andrews bill. When scanning the list I became very concerned that my name was not listed. The federal member for Lilley was listed as Liz Grace. How this lady was able to vote on my behalf, I do not know. I would also be pleased if you, Mr Speaker, could investigate how she was able to gain access to the federal parliament and vote on legislation without anyone on either side noticing. Mr Speaker, I was christened Elizabeth—
—You are obliged to declare where you have been misrepresented.
—I was christened Elizabeth, Mr Speaker, not Liz. As I plan to be representing the people of Lilley for some years in this parliament, I would be pleased if my correct name—
—The honourable member is way outside the guidelines for personal explanations.
—Mr Speaker, I would like my correct name to be used. My name is Elizabeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Proceed.

—Hansard shows that I did not vote on the third reading of the Euthanasia Laws Bill. Mr Speaker, I understand that your office has viewed a tape of the vote and that that tape confirms that I was indeed present and voted for the ayes.

SPEECH.PARA: An article in the Australian newspaper today which shows that I did not vote in the bill has caused me great embarrassment and significant anxiety. If, as it appears is the case, the Australian took their information from Hansard, then it is obviously an innocent mistake on their part. I do not wish my comments to be taken as attacking the Australian newspaper, but I hope that the Hansard will be altered accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Ballarat. We are aware that there was an anomaly and there was an error. We are aware that you did vote and the anomaly will be adjusted.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Proceed.

—An article in the Australian newspaper on page 2 this morning presented a list of members who voted for, against and did not vote on the Andrews bill or the Euthanasia Laws Bill. Indeed, I was present at the division, which is evidenced by the fact that I made a point of order during that division. I did vote on that division. I voted in favour of the Andrews bill. Unfortunately, I am listed in the Australian newspaper as having not voted on that bill. I have written to the Australian asking them to correct their reporting, and Hansard has also said that they will correct the Proof Hansard , which was incorrect.
—I thank the honourable member for Cook. The error will be adjusted.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Grievously.
—Proceed.

—In answer to the Leader of the Opposition's question today asking whether the government would now accept the Telstra legislation amendment that prevents the deletion of the Minister for Communications and the Arts to direct Telstra, the Prime Minister stated that—
—Where have you been misrepresented?

—Here it is. The Prime Minister stated that the deletion of the power to direct Telstra was part of my package of telecommunications reforms. This is incorrect and the former government never proposed to delete the direction of power of the minister for communications because we believe, and we still believe, that rural subscribers should pay the same as their city cousins for local telephone calls.
—You have shown where you have been grossly misrepresented. Resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker, I have a question for you and it relates to the incident earlier—
—What incident?

—The incident in which the Prime Minister was actually inviting people to make comments. That has always been ruled to be disorderly and we have always been told not to invoke or invite that in any way and to always speak through the chair. By ruling that in order and saying that there was no point of order earlier today, I would be grateful for a subsequent comment. We seem to have changed the procedure.
—Conventions of the House are well known to us all. Today was not a proud day in the history of this parliament. There was considerable disorder, which will not be tolerated in future.

—Mr Speaker, could I ask you a question apropos the transfer of the Speaker's chair from Old Parliament House to this House. If you are considering that, would you also examine whether or not the bar table in this place in some way could be narrowed so that the chamber might be narrowed and the sides brought closer together to make it more of a debating chamber than a public forum?
—How much will that cost?

—I did not say you do it. I said you have to look at it. It seems to me, Mr Speaker, if you are going to have a look at one aspect, it would be worth while also assessing the width of the bar table to see whether or not this chamber could be made to function more as a parliament instead of a public auditorium.

—I thank the right honourable member for New England for his question. I am sure you remember the days of the intimate and robust debates that occurred in Old Parliament House. As I say, I have not yet received the correspondence that I expect from the Leader of the House, but we will take that question on board and see if we can improve the intimacy and the general attractiveness of the chamber for debate.
—Mr Speaker, seeing as we are now going to absolutely ridiculous extents and maybe export the whole of the Old Parliament House up here—
—Do you have a question for me?

—Most certainly I have. Will you dig up Speaker Snedden's wig and give it to the right honourable member for New England so he can pretend that he is the Speaker, because that is about as close as he is going to get?
—Order! The wig is no longer comfortable on any head that comes instantly to mind.

—Mr Speaker, I am sorry to dwell on the matter that arose the other night in the Euthanasia Laws Bill debate. I mentioned in an earlier debate the problem that comes from those of us who vote on conscience on every particular division where one might be—
—Ha, ha!
—I do not think it is funny.
—Are you raising a question?

—I am, Mr Speaker. If you are attending a committee meeting and the division bells ring and you arrive here just at the point of the division time concluding, then sometimes it is difficult to be able to make the journey over to the clerks table to ascertain—
—See me and I'll put you right.
—The member for Watson is not helping matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —He has got a bucket mouth. If I could just point out that, in order for a member to ascertain, firstly, what the question is, a trip to the clerks table is required to ascertain what the question is and then of course, in the case of an amendment that may have been circulated in the period immediately prior to the division, there is obviously the fight to get the amendment paper to be able to look at it.

QUESTION.PARA: All I am saying is that, from time to time, it may not be possible, given the time between the point at which the division bells conclude and entering the chamber, to do that. Part of the problem that the right honourable member for New England has alluded to is the fact that this chamber is so large that from time to time that may be difficult. I am just wondering, Mr Speaker, whether it is possible to look at some other means whereby one can ascertain the question being divided on on entry into the chamber to be able to make a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the thrust of your question. The onus of responsibility rests entirely with individual members within the parliament and, of course, they are aided handsomely by the splendid work that our whips do. There is no doubt that the Independent members receive supplemental allocations of staff. I would encourage you to keep abreast of events, and all of the amendments that were circulated this week relative to the Euthanasia Laws Bill were circulated well in advance.

—In spite of the early intervention of the member for Watson, could I suggest, to help the honourable member, that it would be possible to put the question on which we are speaking or debating with the sign `Division' on our in-house broadcasting system at the same time. It would mean that, when a division comes up, the honourable gentleman's question is answered.
—This will be part of the area looked at when we examine or revisit electronic voting. The response of the incumbent of the chair at the time will always revolve around the question anyway.

—In your answer, Mr Speaker, you mentioned that a member could use one's staff to help to find out what the division is about. Can I just point out that if you are entering from one of the committee rooms from that side of the building, it is difficult for a member of staff, unless you happen to have a mobile phone with you. And it is considered to be disorderly to bring a mobile phone into the chamber with you, for obvious reasons.

—It would be utterly disorderly. The division bells usually ring for four minutes and you do have sufficient time to address a call to your office, which should be monitoring the events on your behalf. I think we have had enough discussion on these events.
