INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The prospective loss of jobs and rail services arising from the governments's decision to privatise Australian National and National Rail.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Over two weeks have passed since the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) announced that the government intended to privatise Australian National and to sell its share in National Rail. It is not because of any lack of seriousness or regard for the issue that the opposition has chosen not to raise this for debate in this chamber until the second week of sittings.

BREAK.PARA: There is a very simple reason why we have chosen to do that, that is, to give the minister an opportunity to do the right thing and to make a ministerial statement in the parliament, as he should have done and has failed to do, with respect to this very serious issue. He chose to announce it on the Sunday program, but to treat this parliament with contempt by not even coming in and making a ministerial statement about a very substantial proposal which was not previously mentioned by the government.

When you look at the content of the proposal, it is no wonder that he has chosen to do this. We have a decision to privatise Australia's National Rail Corporation and Australian National based on a report that the government refuses to release, based on one year's bad figures that the minister is deliberately distorting and grossly inflating to further his case and, in the case of National Rail, based on no bad figures but based on National Rail continuing to perform as it was originally intended to perform when it was established by the former government and gradually moving towards commercial viability within five years and towards break‐even unsubsidised circumstances. National Rail is broadly on track to achieve this.

The fact that the government has only been able to produce one justification, namely, bad figures, for its proposal to privatise Australian National gives an absolute indication that this is completely unjustified when you look at the situation with National Rail, which is on track to commercial viability. It is also a decision based, I might add, on no consultation of any great substance. The Public Transport Union, the main representatives of the workers in Australian National and National Rail, was given a mere 15 minutes before the government's committee in discussions on this issue.

It is a decision conceived in secrecy and deceit. It has been gestated in unrelenting hostility to the public sector and the rail industry, and given birth to in a shimmer of distortions and lies. It is interesting to look at coalition policy, where we see no mention of privatisation of Australian National or National Rail, no mention of removing the subsidy that has been there for some considerable time and long before the previous Labor government was in office, and no mention of destroying jobs or services in the rail industry.
The coalition policy was not exactly a long document but it states:

The Coalition will establish a national interstate passenger rail service in partnership with the States, linking all interstate passenger rail services. Australian National will be given the task of operating this new and innovative service designed to increase rail patronage on a fully commercial basis.

Australian National has been poorly treated under the Labor Government. The Coalition is committed to providing AN with a future through such means as the interstate passenger initiative which will increase AN's business base and promote job security for its employees through policies designed to increase the use of rail, utilising an under‐utilised resource.
How hollow these words now sound. Is the government giving AN a future? Is it increasing its business? Is it giving job security, a promise to the workers of AN? Definitely not. It is dismantling it.

We hear even today again more unctuousness about previous decisions of the former government with respect to privatisation—about Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank—and claims that these were not taken to the electorate, at the very same time that this government is doing precisely that by proposing to privatise Australian National and its share of National Rail when it has made no commitment to the electorate along those lines and, quite to the contrary, has committed itself to improve and increase Australian National and its business.

In September, the minister was forced against his wishes to release the Brew report executive summary in the Senate. This recommended the wholesale dismantling of Australian National but not of National Rail—merely to put National Rail on a commercial basis, which is where it is due to end up in any event.

When it was released the minister said, `Don't assume that we'll do any of these things that were recommended; the report is to the government, not of the government. And in any event it's all Labor's fault; they did nothing, they sat there, they were asleep at the wheel, they didn't take any decisions or action to fix the problem.'

On the same day we got a press release from Australian National indicating it was already starting the process of selling off its core businesses. So on 11 September we heard from the minister, `Labor did nothing, Labor was asleep at the wheel,' but on 12 September, when he is confronted with the draconian proposals to sell the businesses of Australian National, we heard a totally different story: `No, that was all Labor's decisions. That was all Labor's fault, nothing to do with us. Labor's decisions had these in train.' But the lie in this was exposed on the following day, on 13 September—he had a bad run during these three days—when the minister's letter of 15 August to the chairman of AN, Mr Jack Smorgon, was tabled, indicating that he had given specific instructions for the sell‐off to proceed.

Then, on 26 September, the real agenda behind the Brew report became clear. The real role of the consultant, Mr Brew himself, was revealed, because at the same time as he was acting as a consultant to the government, advising about the future of the rail industry in Australia, advising about what should be done with Australian National—how the government should treat the future of rail in this country—he was lining himself up to be a consultant to the main bidder to buy Australian National. At the same time as he is advising the government to sell Australian National, he is also getting into bed with the main consortium that is lining up to buy the company.

As a result of that, we now have a completely tainted report. We cannot read the full report, but it is fully tainted, because the person who has done the report, at the same time as he was forming his conclusions, clearly had in mind, `Where can I profit as a result of government decisions with respect to the future of Australian National and National Rail?' Answer: as a consultant to somebody in the private sector who might buy some or all of the businesses that are going to be up for sale. So we had a consultant advising the government, `Go ahead and sell all these things; beauty, I'll be able to get in there at the carve‐up, I'll be able to get my share of the action later on down the track.' Finally, as I indicated, on the Sunday program the minister announced that all of it would be sold. He has made a decision effectively to fatten up the assets for a fire sale by restating the government's responsibility for various liabilities such as the AN debt and endeavouring to take on board to the government all existing liabilities for Australian National.

In effect, all that is doing is shifting from one accounting heading to another a set of liabilities that the government already has. The government has those liabilities anyway. The minister said, `This is a $2 billion reform package.' Some journalists, unfortunately, have chosen not to look behind the statement and see it for the absolute lie that it is. It is a restatement of existing liabilities, a restatement of certain commitments already in the budget and carry‐on commitments from the former government, albeit with substantial reductions in funding—such as the former Track Australia, $161 million—and some very unlikely contingencies, such as $50 million for environmental cleanup.

My information from Australian National is that that figure within AN was based on an assessment of what it would cost to do a decontamination of every single AN site. In other words, it can only have meaning if the entire rail network and the entire business of AN is actually closed down.

We see the superannuation figure there—$580 million. It is a complete fake because AN has been making superannuation payments to the federal government, into consolidated revenue. So it technically has part of its superannuation unfunded, but money has gone into consolidated revenue on a monthly basis. That $580 million covering superannuation is simply an accounting device. It is a complete fraud and the whole $2 billion figure is a complete fraud.

What is an even bigger fraud is the claim that AN had a $250 million loss for 1995‐96. Roughly $140 million of that loss actually consists of one‐off asset revaluations. Yes, that is an issue, but it is dramatically different from comparing operating revenues and operating expenditure, which is the real issue about future bleeding of the business. The minister, Mr Sharp, has grossly misrepresented the situation; again, he refused to tell the people of Australia, particularly people with an interest in AN—those workers, those people who depend on the services of AN—what the real story is, in order to justify what is basically an ideological attempt to get rail out of the public sector, to give a few mates in the private sector a bit of a free kick, have a bit of a fire sale and get the subsidies away from the federal budget.

What he has not actually revealed is that the operating result for AN for 1995‐96, I am informed, will come in slightly better than what the Brew report predicted. He has also indicated that AN and NR may be sold in bits; in other words, cherry‐picking may occur. There is no guarantee of existing services being maintained. That was revealed in his answer to my question the other day in the House. There is no guarantee that things like the workshops will not be asset stripped by competitors who will simply buy them up, close them down, take out the assets and look forward to a situation where there is one less major competitor in the marketplace.

There is nothing about obligations being imposed on new private owners to maintain services; no guarantees about the future of the Indian Pacific, the Ghan and the Overland; no guarantees about the future route for the Indian Pacific. People in Broken Hill and other parts of inland New South Wales are very concerned about these issues. But there are no guarantees, beyond the sale, about the future of these services.

There are no guarantees about the future of the grain services in South Australia, which South Australian wheat farmers depend on. There are no guarantees about the future of Tasrail and the freight services which help to underpin the economic viability of a range of industries and industrial activities in Tasmania, such as the Fingal Valley coalmines.

Particularly, there are no guarantees about jobs. We have heard some pretty contradictory statements from the minister about jobs. On the Sunday program, courtesy of some questions from Laurie Oakes, he was asked, `Will this necessarily mean job losses?' The answer from the minister was, `No, it won't necessarily mean job losses.' On the same day he had a letter going out to all Australian National employees which said, `Further reductions in employment will inevitably result from the sale process.' So on television, to the Australian people, he says, `No, there won't necessarily be job losses,' but to the employees he says, `Sorry, yes there will be.'

You can guarantee there will be job losses. What about the workers in Launceston? I visited there last week. The minister has not been seen there. Indeed, the local member, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), has not been seen there. They are very worried about their job futures, as are the workers in South Australia, whose shop stewards I spoke to again yesterday at some length.

There is no explanation given for selling National Rail, which, as I have indicated, has substantially moved towards its target for commercial viability set by the former government. The interstate freight deficit has fallen from $350 million to $50 million, based on the evidence given by the minister's own department to a Senate committee on 19 September and vindicated by National Rail itself on 22 October to the same committee.

There has been a $300 million reduction in the deficit on that side of the ledger. On the other side, there has been a deterioration, but nothing to the extent that the minister indicated—nothing of that magnitude. The overall picture is still an overall $200 million‐plus improvement in the total rail deficit picture over those four or five years. National Rail is on track to commercial viability, where it will have no subsidies after five years.

The minister—this gives an indication of what the real story is—was fronting up to the annual general meeting of National Rail only a few weeks ago demanding a $1 million extraordinary dividend out of them. Far from them being in financial strife, the government is trying to milk extra money out of them.

The government are providing only $20 million of their so-called $2 billion package, which amounts to about one per cent in real expenditure, for regional adjustment. That is about one year's wages bill at Port Augusta. It is a drop in the ocean with respect to the economic impact that will occur at Port Augusta. It will not help the loss of heavy engineering capacity in Adelaide. It will not pay for the cost of increased road usage and increased road costs in Tasmania, which will ultimately lead to double the costs. The deficit on Tasrail in the last two years is now at the lowest it has been for 10 years. The last two years in Tasrail have been the best of the last 10 years.

The regional adjustment fund will not cover the road damage that results, it will not cover assistance to inland New South Wales communities that lose their services, and there is no mention anywhere of the fact that the former Labor government's labour market adjustment programs have been abolished, which 1,200 AN workers who were previously retrenched benefited from.

The government's attack on the record of the former government with respect to jobs is equally fallacious. The loss of jobs in AN in the last 13 years has been mirrored in every rail system in the country for the same reasons—new technology, work practices and improvements in productivity. That is where they have come from. Citing examples of New Zealand and other countries around the world to justify what the minister is doing is equally ludicrous. New Zealand Rail does well because road charges are three or four times higher than they are in Australia, so the playing field is radically different.

If you look around the world, you see, for example, Amtrak in the United States. Amtrak long distance passenger rail is subsidised by the American government to the tune of over $1 billion per year. The picture is the same throughout Canada and throughout the United Kingdom. Rail throughout the world is subsidised.

The key thing in all of this is a minister who is economical with the truth. He has tried to claim that Labor's actions led to his decision to sell off AN. He has tried to claim that the losses AN are incurring for 1995-96 are $250 million when they are in fact way below that. And he said on TV that this will not necessarily mean job losses when he was telling the workers the direct opposite.

This is a pattern that is recurring throughout the minister's statements because he likes to leave out key facts when it suits him. He is very well named, not because he is sharp as in intelligent, not because he is sharp as in bright, but because he is sharp as in practices, sharp as in conduct, sharp as in card sharp.

This privatisation plan is purely ideological. It is designed to get rid of a subsidy on the budget. It is designed to get the government out of the rail industry. It is based on one year's bad figures that are nowhere near as bad as the government suggests and it is based on a secret report that the government refuses to release. The Labor Party will fight this all the way in the Senate and in the Senate committee. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr SHARP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a withering, pathetic attack. Gee, if that is the best you can do on this subject, then I think you have got a long way to go before you will convince anybody that you have any arguments to sustain your particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been fascinating. We have had two weeks, as the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) points out, for the Labor Party to mount their withering attack on this particular subject. Indeed, we have had to ask ourselves questions on this very subject in order to get up in the House. There was only one question from the Labor Party in the whole of this fortnight whereupon they asked about the AN reforms.

It took us, on behalf of the government, to ask questions of ourselves to get the issue up in the parliament in the first place. Even today in the House, where we had 24, 25 or possibly 26 questions—the Labor Party ran out of questions because they did not think question time would go as long as it did today—they had plenty of opportunity to raise questions about this subject in the House, but they did not.

The reason the Labor Party has not raised this as a topical subject that they believe is of political value to themselves is simply that this is a political embarrassment to the Labor Party. The Labor Party is politically embarrassed over the way AN and NR have been managed during their 13 years of office. The honourable member for Melbourne would know that the reason is simply—you can talk to the workers down at AN, anywhere you like—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do. You don't.
—Indeed I have. I have had delegations of them in my office.
—Have you been down there?
—I have been to Port Augusta.
—Recently?

—I spoke to some people who worked for AN just the other day in Adelaide. Indeed, it was a most illuminating exercise. The first thing they say to me is that the reason AN is in the problem it is in today is the previous Labor government's decision to set up the National Rail Corporation the way it did.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason they say that is that when the National Rail Corporation was set up in the early 1990s National Rail was given two‐thirds of AN's business. AN had to give it a lot of its rolling stock, locomotives and other equipment free of charge. AN had to give over two‐thirds of its business to the National Rail Corporation—plus its locos, plus its rolling stock, plus a lot of other assets—without any charge or cost going to NR and without any revenue coming to AN.

AN was left with the debt on those locos, the debt on that rolling stock, the debt on the assets that they handed over. So NR got the revenue from all of this equipment and AN had to pay the bill. NR got two‐thirds of AN's business and AN was left with all the infrastructure and costs to bear. That is the thing that people who work for AN say was the problem they had to work with, a problem created by the previous Labor government. That is why this is a very embarrassing issue for Labor. AN's death knell was struck with the foundation of the National Rail Corporation by the previous Labor government. That is why this is embarrassing.

It is also embarrassing for the Labor Party because during its time in office 7,000 people who worked for AN lost their jobs. Here we are today dealing with an MPI in which the Labor Party is railing about the possible loss of jobs within AN, yet 7,000 jobs were lost at AN during the 13 years of a Labor government—under Labor's management.

In the speech of the honourable member for Melbourne he said, `Those job losses? They were good job losses because that is what everybody else was doing. Any job losses in the future will obviously be bad.' I can assure the House that there will not be anything like those sorts of job losses in AN or NR in the future, because it is this government's proposal to grow those businesses, to make them more efficient and to reduce the debt load, the debt burden, that those businesses have had to suffer.

It is very interesting to consider what the previous Labor government could have done, had they chosen to try to fix the problems of AN. AN's problem was that it lumbered with enormous debts, debts that have a commercial value of around $1,100 million. AN had to pay the bill for those debts. That was one of the major problems that AN suffered from. What this government has done is exactly what the PTU representatives asked us to do when we discussed these matters with them. The PTU representatives said, `If there is one thing you can do for AN, it is to relieve it of its debts. If you relieve AN of its debts, then AN's problems will be, to a fair degree, resolved because it is the debt that weighs us down so much.'

As a result of our announcement on rail reform, this new coalition government will be removing all of the debts and liabilities of AN: taking over its debt, paying out any possible redundancy commitments that are within the labour force at AN, paying out all of the superannuation commitments within AN and dealing with all of the environmental problems—if they are tidied up properly, to the value of about $50 million. We are taking over all of the debts and liabilities of AN in order to ensure that AN, under a new owner, has a real future.

This is something that the previous Labor government could have done. They could have done precisely that, if they had wanted to fix the problems of AN, but they chose not to do it during their 13 years of office. Instead, what the previous Labor government chose to do was to mislead the people who work for AN, as they did in the run‐up to the last election when the former Minister for Transport and the former Prime Minister visited the workshops at AN and told them that everything was sweet, everything was hunky‐dory. `Vote for us and you'll have a future,' they said. Well, their business plan that the former Minister for Transport and the former Minister for Finance, now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), had signed off on had agreed secretly to strike out 972 jobs. In the Labor business plan it had been agreed that 972 jobs had to go, at the very time the Labor Prime Minister and the Labor transport minister were down there telling them that everything was sweet; they had no worries at all.

I go to a couple of the points that the honourable member for Melbourne made in his withering attack. The PTU, he said, got only 15 minutes with us. That is incorrect. There were several members of our committee there and they had a much longer time than that. They had considerable contact with me and members of the government over the months that led up to that decision. We had consistent contact from the PTU. We listened to their advice and, in many cases, we have accepted their advice.

The other point that the honourable member for Melbourne made in his address was that the National Rail Corporation is on the road to profitability and it is only a Labor government with its policies that would have seen that happen—or words to that effect. National Rail Corporation is not on the road to profitability. In the September quarter, it was $10.8 million down on its budgeted revenues.The chief executive officer at the time of announcing the September quarter results said that revenue for NR for the whole of the financial year would be something like $45 million to $50 million below budget forecasts.

Is this a business on its way to profitability? Is this a business that does not depend on government subsidies for its existence? The truth of it is that NR gets $25 million of government subsidies in 1995‐96. It will get subsidies again in the current financial year. Not only that but NR receives goods and services, assets, from other rail operators at below cost. Companies such as AN are forced under the arrangements Labor put in place to provide services—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is finished. That's over.

—Yes, finished under our initiative. We no longer require AN to provide those services free of charge to National Rail, contrary to the arrangements that you had in place. That occurred as a consequence of some negotiation that John Brew himself was involved in.

SPEECH.PARA: The other attempt that was made by the honourable member for Melbourne in his address was to slur the good name of Mr John Brew. It is worth while pointing out to the House that Mr Brew is not involved with any of the people who are being considered—

TALK.START.PARA: —He got sprung.

—He didn't get sprung at all. If you listen to Mr Brew, he will tell you that he had no arrangements with anybody and he informed me that he had no intention of making any arrangements with anybody. So it is quite a scurrilous thing for the honourable member for Melbourne to try to attack the reputation of Mr John Brew in his remarks just a few moments ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition government has announced a $2 billion package to try to resolve the problems of AN and to reform our rail system here in Australia. This package of reforms is in stark contrast to the death by a thousand cuts represented by the 7,000 job losses that Labor had under their 13 years of management.

The one and only question I can recall being asked by the member for Melbourne in the last fortnight was about whether there would be a guarantee of the maintenance of passenger and freight services. It is interesting to note Labor's track record on maintaining passenger and freight services during their 13 years of office when they had the management of AN. A long list of services was axed under their management. For example, passenger services: Adelaide to Victor Harbor—axed; Adelaide to Peterborough—axed; Adelaide to Broken Hill—axed; Adelaide to Whyalla—axed; Adelaide to Mount Gambier—axed. Those are all passenger services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did that?

—Labor did that during their 13 years of office, their 13 years of mismanagement. Let us see what happened with the freight services that AN operated during the 13 years of a Labor government. Services were withdrawn from rail lines to Mount Gambier, Loxton and Kapunda. In Tasmania, freight services were axed on the Mole Creek line and the Tonganah line.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, a number of lines were technically closed during Labor's 13 years of mismanagement: the Millicent‐Snuggery line; the Snowtown‐Wallaroo line; the Mount Barker‐Victor Harbor line; the Kapunda‐Eudunda line; the Alawoona‐Paringa line; and the Karoonda‐Peebinga line. So Labor Party people have no credibility when get up on their feet and talk about possible job losses or reductions in passenger or freight services or closure of lines at AN and NR—because nobody has done it more than they did during their 13 years in office. Indeed, the whole purpose of our reforms is to boost rail in this country to give it a real future.

I can tell members of the House now that people who work for AN recognise that this announcement we have made gives them a solid future to work with—a future that they would not have got under Labor's mismanagement. Indeed, you ought to see some of the letters that I have received from various people who work for AN. Some of those letters are very complimentary indeed. If I could find them, I would read them out to you but I do not have them with me now. However, several letters have been written to me by people who work for AN saying, `At last somebody has grasped the nettle and had the courage to make some decisions to build a new future for AN and our career.'

We have had a number of those letters because they got sick and tired of the deception, the run‐down and the lack of interest by those people who ran this country in the form of a Labor government. There has been a tremendous response from people working for AN. Even in the media there has been a tremendous response. Editorials in newspapers such as the Launceston Examiner—a town where this decision affects them—have been very praiseworthy of what the government is doing. Look at the comments of the Mayor of Port Augusta, Joy Baluch, who said that this is a new turning point, a new opportunity. These are complimentary and positive responses from people who are affected more directly than anybody else by the decisions of this particular government.

So this government is proposing to give rail a real future. We believe that by bringing private sector investment into the rail system, as has been the case in a lot of other countries, rail will grow here in Australia. By setting up a national network of rail lines connecting our capital cities and allowing the private sector to operate on it, we believe there will be more freight on our rail system and, ultimately, more passengers than we have seen in the past. Evidence of that was just 48 hours ago when TNT and Toll Holdings agreed to a joint venture to put more freight onto rail under this government's initiatives.

This government is giving rail a real future for real jobs to be created in the rail industry in Australia, rather than the death by a thousand cuts that the former Labor government imposed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Railways have always played a vital role in the development of countries like Australia—countries with wide open spaces and many miles between settlements. In the development of Australia railways were vital for the transport of passengers and freight, for maintaining communication and for supporting jobs in regional areas which relied on them to bring people and goods into the area and to get the produce out of the district and to the market.

PARA.BREAK: They have also been vital though for industrial development in themselves: the manufacture and maintenance of rolling stock and engines; and the maintenance and laying of track. All of these provide jobs and funding for regional economies like Port Augusta and for areas like Islington in suburban Adelaide. They are also vital lifelines for towns along the route, such as the Indian Pacific through Broken Hill providing one of the only eco nomical links for many in our community between Perth and Sydney and also links for those rural communities across that Australian route. The same is true for towns along the Overland route between Adelaide and Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: Railways have also been vital for the defence of our country. It is worth noting that it is only Labor which has provided a real and significant possibility for the Alice Springs to Darwin link, which not only has substantial advantages in trade in this country and for South Australia and the Northern Territory but also provides a real link to the north of Australia for the defence of Australia. The role of railways in the development of this country, be it trading or entrepreneurial activity, manufacturing, mining, agriculture or defence, has always been vital in all of those areas of national development.

But while the times and the economies of scale and the technology and working practices in rail have changed, the whole notion of our rail network has had to change too. It continues to perform the same vital functions that it performed a century ago in the national development of Australia and which it will always perform in countries like this. But the last few decades have seen the rail system under some threat from the competition for passengers from the airline industry and the road transport industry which has sought to take freight and to undercut the rail system in Australia—in fact, to undermine the very economic basis of that rail network.

Only Labor has had the vision and this generation to look at the rail network and to seize the opportunity to build a viable national system with it. The Whitlam government of the early 1970s, for example, recognised the problems which rail faced and sought to overcome those shortcomings by building a national rail network that did not rely on the individual state governments and individual state ownership.

The isolation which the state ownership provided for rail ensured that you could only have an effective intrastate network and that interstate networks were unnecessarily handicapped by that. The Whitlam government seized that opportunity. Unfortunately, not all states were agreeable to being part of that process but the states that did—South Australia and Tasmania—certainly benefited from that then.

Had the other states cooperated back then, 20 years ago, we would by now have had a much more viable national network. Whitlam offered the states a way out of their difficulties and provided the opportunity to build for South Australia and Tasmania. Victoria and New South Wales stayed outside the system and Australia has paid the price ever since.

Prime Minister Fraser did not continue this good work. Indeed, it was during this period that much of the foundation for our current problems was laid. For example, in the final year of the Fraser government, when another National Party minister held the position of Minister for Transport, the current value of the debt—if you look at the debt then in current dollar terms—was some $190 million, which certainly is within the ballpark of any current problems being faced by the rail network. It just shows you where much of that debt came from back in the late 1970s and early 1980s during the Fraser years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going back to the F.J. Holden years.
—No, if you look back at those Fraser years, you will see where the debt that we are talking about now started from. That is where the initiative was lost.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last decade, in the period of the Hawke-Keating governments, Labor again faced up to the challenge of building a viable national rail network. I do not claim that all the decisions which were taken during that time were ideal. But the reality of the need to ensure state cooperation left us with no alternative but to take the unfortunate decision to split National Rail from AN. That created two organisations, one of which, unfortunately, carried a fair amount of lead in its saddle bags.

If we had had the option then of building a single national network around a national rail organisation, then many of the difficulties which we now face may well have been avoided. However, it must be said that it has always been Labor which has taken the national development approach to rail. It is Labor which negotiated agreements with the unions which resulted in some job losses—but not on the scale alleged by the minister—and which were needed then to ensure the viability of AN.

Yes, we also ensured that those who were voluntarily retrenched were compensated both financially and in terms of educational and retraining opportunities—educational opportunities which are being cruelly, savagely and harshly withdrawn from them by the minister and his government who are cutting costs in education across the board, cutting costs in training across the board and thereby condemning those AN workers who are no longer part of the structure.

Yes, we imposed changes to work practices and required the adoption of new technologies. These were hard decisions for the work force to accept. As a frequent visitor to the Islington workshops—like my colleague the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) more recently as shadow minister—I have seen the dramatic changes to the work force, to productivity and to technology which those people have done a very good job in implementing. The workers accepted that challenge that was put before them by the Labor government. They understood the need for that challenge. It was negotiated at all times with the work force. They rose to that challenge. The response has been fantastic.

We have seen dramatic change in those rail industries, much more so than in most other industries. That was starting to lay the framework for an improvement to the financial position of Australian National and, of course, the commercial basis for national rail. They also understood the social contract which existed between the government of those days and the work force.

We had the commitment to build and sustain the rail network, to build and sustain the regional development commitment and component which ensured major job opportunities at Port Augusta, at Islington and in the country towns along those national routes—the Overland, the Ghan and the Indian Pacific. Our commitment to that development must be contrasted with that of the new government. Certainly, it is far from their election commitments. I quote from an article in July 1995 in which Mr Sharp, who was then the coalition spokesman, said:

The Coalition is concerned that Australian National should have a viable future that not only assures its survival, but enables it to grow, bringing job opportunities to important rail centres such as those in the Grey electorate.
The Coalition's intention to establish a separate company to own and maintain the rail track will also facilitate and encourage the entry of new participants . . .
The Coalition is committed to the continued and growing strength of rail transport and of Australian National in particular.

We see now 18 months later just how hollow those words were. Before the election it was okay to talk about the future of Australian National and the future of a national rail system. After the election we talk about a fire sale destroying the assets of Australian National by selling them off and abolishing the jobs. There will be a loss of 550 jobs in Port Augusta alone which will certainly destroy the local economy in the Iron Triangle and put the livelihood of those people at considerable threat.

Those workshops are very much an important part of the regional economy of Australia. They provide jobs. They provide maintenance work. They inject funds into the whole economy. It is not only those people who work in the workshops but also the teachers, the people working in the service industries which are built around the workshops and the suppliers who provide the infrastructure for those workshops—they are all vital to the economy of regional Australia.

Regional Australia has suffered enormously under this minister and under this government. Look at the pretence of a minister who claims the title of `Minister for Regional Development' but whose first act is to sack most of the staff in that department and to cancel the funding for that department—indeed, he virtually abolishes the department. I understand there are only some six people left in that office who service a minor function of advising the minister on regional development.

BREAK.PARA: If you can be the minister for regional development and preside over the demise of the department of regional development, if you can be the minister and preside over the withdrawal of $620 million from road funding from regions, if you can be the minister and wear the removal of telecommunications from regional Australia, if you can be the minister and wear the whole destruction of the Australian national rail system through its privatisation and disposal at fire sale prices, then you are not the Minister for Transport and Regional Development that I would expect because those things will destroy regional economies. They will destroy jobs in Port Augusta; they will destroy jobs in Islington; they will destroy jobs in towns along our great national rail routes.

I suspect that, when it is all said and done, the fire sale recommended by Brew will go ahead and that great national railway network, which has been built in this country over decades and decades by the work force of this country, will be destroyed. It will be this minister supposedly for regional development who will have presided over it; it will be this minister supposedly in support of transport and a public sector transport basis who will have presided over that failure. I condemn him and his government for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We revisit yet again the issue of rail. I cannot help but be amazed that the opposition would bring the matter forward in this way. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) has very well explained the position, and I think the loss of 7,000 jobs in the life of the Labor government sums it all up. But the more remarkable thing to me is what those opposite actually did in government and what they actually say after they have left government and are in opposition. The shadow minister, the member for Melbourne, Mr Tanner, talked about a whole range of matters from hostility, distortion, lies—
—Where is he?

—He appears to have vacated his previous position, Minister. The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) has given us an historical perspective of Labor's role in rail. I actually believed that for a little while when I first came into this place. But I did the numbers on the Fraser era from 1975 to 1983 and compared that with the Hawke-Keating era and found that the Fraser era put exactly double the amount of money into Australia's rail system that Hawke and Keating did. The rhetoric of this opposition is quite remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister is well noted for his exaggeration of what actually occurs, but one of the more remarkable statements I have heard in recent weeks was when Martin Ferguson visited the electorate. In an interview on the ABC he said, `There have been some job losses.' I remind him that there were actually 7,000 job losses when we had something like 2,000 jobs remaining in AN altogether. He subsequently went on to say that there had been `some job losses', not acknowledging in any way the 7,000 jobs lost. I find it absolutely amazing that they would come into this place and argue this case.

Staying with Martin Ferguson for just another few words, Martin Ferguson was the President of the ACTU who signed off the memorandum of understanding which set up the greenfield site to establish National Rail. The hostility from many in the work force at Port Augusta is still quite profound because they fully understand that AN was doomed once National Rail started.
The member for Melbourne brought forward the reason why National Rail was established in the form it was in his speech on a similar matter on 7 September 1996:
National Rail was established separately because the states forced the Labor government to do it in order to have a proper interstate network.
The states forced the Labor government! True leadership! As we sadly have to keep reminding the House, once that decision was taken it was death by a thousand cuts for AN.

In the remaining time I have I want to talk about the future of rail. I think we have an opportunity to face up to our past and give it an honest assessment. For example, we can go back to the 1982 report of the House of Representatives transport committee which clearly stated then that there was a need for reform and that it was expected by about the mid-eighties that AN would be in a position to break even.

For the shadow minister to come into this place and say that we are acting on one year's bad figures is just unbelievable, but then he suggested that National Rail was performing well enough to justify its continued existence when, as the minister has indicated, it is expecting a revenue drop of between $45 million and $50 million. National Rail is already in trouble. We have intermodal revenue from all origins to Perth down $10.4 million for the quarter—that is 27 per cent—and the announcement by TNT. To further apply the pressure, will only exacerbate that situation.

The future of rail is bright. Rail is about a quarter of the $30 billion transport task in Australia. About $8 billion of transport task is a big business in itself. Port Augusta, Port Lincoln and Ceduna, those areas that do remain in rail—we will not talk about Peterborough; the opposition made sure that they did not have a future—have a strong future in rail.

Comments of the local union secretary are most appropriate. He said, quite clearly, that AN had to change. There was absolutely no dodging that issue. He made the observation that he thought the management of AN had let them down. Where does the responsibility for the management of AN end up? It ends up with the minister. Minister Brereton went to the people in South Australia prior to the election and told them that all was well and that they would be protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another Brereton bungle.

—There is no doubt about that. The tragedy for rail is that for too many years there has been too much politics and not enough clear thinking. It is once again up to this government to face up to the realities: to put rail on a firm footing and to offer the only structure that will give rail a reasonable future.

PARA.BREAK: I remind the House that there is $20 million for regional assistance in the package. That, if spent wisely and well, will give great opportunities for my electorate and, particular ly, for the people of Port Augusta, Port Lincoln and Ceduna. The $50 million environment package is very important, because it offers an opportunity to bring forward a lot of the work of rehabilitating the land and buildings that need attention so that they can be put to a more useful purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The redundancy packages have been honoured in Port Augusta. We have one of the big mines of the world at Olympic Dam, Roxby Downs. It can offer, with proper management, a great facility to combine with the efforts of rail in the region. Rail is very important from the grain lines to the iron ore lines to the Broken Hill lines—which rather artificially have been taken away from AN—right through to the Leigh Creek line and to the east-west traffic. So there is a great future for rail but with more imaginative and properly skilled managers we will see a much stronger effort in conjunction with the mining industry and the skilled work force.

One point on which I can agree with my opponents is that there have been very significant improvements by the work force in the rail industry. It is no fault of theirs that they find themselves in this position. It is due to the inability of the previous government to face up to the reality and, regrettably, the inability of the management of AN to show the leadership that is required for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports entitled Development of facilities for 5 Aviation Regiment at RAAF Base Townsville and Development of infrastructure of Townsville field training area, Townsville.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report which I have tabled concerns proposed facilities at RAAF Base Townsville for 5 Aviation Regiment. The proposed works examined by the committee encompass two major elements. The first is the construction of an advanced wash facility and environmental shelters equipped with dehumidification equipment for Black Hawk and Chinook helicopters. This will reduce corrosion caused by operation and open storage of the helicopters in salt laden atmospheric conditions. The shelters will also reduce exposure of the helicopters to high temperatures and ultraviolet radiation and will alleviate occupational health and safety problems associated with personnel working on the helicopters in the tropical sun.

SPEECH.PARA: The second is the relocation of 5 Aviation Regiment's transport and vehicle workshop facilities within the existing regimental precinct to enhance operational efficiency. Ancillary works involving the refurbishment of a helicopter arming area are also included. The estimated outturn cost of the proposed works is $21.332 million. The committee has recommended that the project proceed as planned.

The report concludes that Black Hawk helicopters operated by 5 Aviation Regiment at RAAF Base Townsville have experienced unexpectedly high rates of corrosion. This has been attributed to the use of high strength, lightweight alloys in helicopter structures and the operation and storage of aircraft in humid and salt laden atmospheric conditions. Prolonged exposure to ultraviolet radiation has affected internal electronic components and plastic fittings.

BREAK.PARA: In response to questions from members, the Department of Defence advised the committee that development of the proposed work commenced 12 months before the tragic Black Hawk accident and that it is not linked in any way to the crash. RAAF Base Townsville remains the preferred location of 5 Aviation Regiment due to the proximity of 3 Brigade and impracticalities and considerable investment associated with alternative locations.

High corrosion rates have diminished the capacity to operate the helicopters through to life of type planned for 2015 as well as affecting aircraft serviceability and requiring expenditure on maintenance, with associated costs expected to exceed sustainable funding levels. The Department of Defence has implemented a corrosion control program for the helicopters to permit 5 Aviation Regiment's Black Hawk helicopters to operate effectively through to life of type.

To satisfy the requirements of the corrosion control program, there is a need to provide environmental protection shelters serviced by dehumidification equipment and an enclosed helicopter washing facility. Based on the number of Black Hawk and Chinook helicopters operated by 5 Aviation Regiment and current maintenance programs, there is a requirement for 19 Black Hawk and four Chinook shelters.

The Department of Defence estimates that cost of environmental protection shelters would be recovered after two years, based on the $1.5 million cost of corrosion control undertaken in 1995 on four helicopters. With regard to the need for improved arrangements for vehicles and workshops, the committee has concluded that existing transport and some technical workshop facilities are located at inappropriately remote sites from 5 Aviation Regiment's precinct at RAAF Base Townsville. The facilities are inadequate and their locations present an ongoing cost to unit efficiency. There is also a need to relocate 5 Aviation Regiment's small arms repair section and to refurbish the gunship helicopter arming point.

The report concludes that the proposed environmental protection shelters, the provision of dehumidification equipment and the helicopter wash facility can be justified as providing the necessary facilities for the successful and economic implementation of the corrosion control plan.The scope of works for the transport compound and workshop facilities can be justified on the basis of considerably improved working conditions, improved shelter and security for the extensive fleet of vehicles and resulting improved efficiency. The extent of the proposed ancillary work will improve the small arms repair section and ordnance loading aprons.

The second report which I have tabled concerns the proposed development of infrastructure on Townsville field training area, Townsville. By way of background, the proposal will enable the army and the RAAF to effectively utilise a large training area encompassing more than 230,000 hectares and to ease environmental pressures on the high range training area.

Broadly, the proposal will provide: fences and warning signs; office accommodation for the range control organisation; communication facilities; access roads; basic infrastructure for a 350‐man camp; vehicle crossing points for creeks, roads and railways; and vehicle wash points. The estimated outturn cost of the proposed work was $18.694 million.

As part of the committee's inquiry, members were able to fly over this extensive tract of land in two Black Hawk helicopters to inspect the extent of the training area and the sites for various components of the proposed work. The committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The report concludes that a need exists to provide the necessary infrastructure to enable elements of the Australian Defence Force to undertake collective and joint training in live fire and manoeuvre, at brigade level, in the Townsville field training area. Of the development options examined, the preferred option will allow the range to be developed close to its maximum potential and provide training benefits within a realistic time frame and at realistic costs.

PARA.BREAK: The extent of the proposed development can be justified on the grounds of public safety, effective management and maximum use of the range, in accordance with the user require ment and concepts for manoeuvre operations. The report supports the use of army engineers on elements of the project which would provide training benefits and not directly compete with the private sector. Design standards will conform with relevant codes, statutes and operational manuals and procedures.

BREAK.PARA: The proposed development was the subject of extensive environmental impact assessments demonstrating a commitment to responsible stewardship of the Townsville field training area by the Department of Defence. I commend the reports to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Bruce Scott, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.
This is the second of two bills containing veterans' affairs 1996‐97 budget measures. The first bill contained budget initiatives that will take effect earlier than the measures in this bill.

When I introduced the first bill, I mentioned various budget and other initiatives that were important to the health and wellbeing of veterans and their families, but did not require legislation. I want to take the opportunity now to refer to another significant veterans' affairs budget initiative that will increase the general community appreciation of the sacrifices and the contribution made by the veterans of Australia.

In addition to benefits and services provided directly to veterans and their families, the government recognises the importance of developing the community's knowledge and understanding of veterans' war experiences and the contribution of veterans to the development of the Australian identity over the past 100 years. In this year's budget, the government committed funding for a four‐year program of commemorative activities. This program will publicly and proudly honour the debt owed by all Australians to our veteran community through a range of programs of commemoration and education, and through the restoration of important memorials. I turn now to the content of this bill.The main thrust of this bill is the rationalisation of payments between my department and the Department of Social Security. This reflects the government's commitment to administrative reforms to streamline the delivery of government services.

The bill will allow age pensioners, who also receive a disability pension, to choose to be paid both pensions by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. For the veterans, and their eligible partners, it will mean that they need deal with only one department. I want to stress that this arrangement will not affect the eligibility for a service pension. There will be a continuing requirement for a veteran to have qualifying service to be paid a service pension.

The new arrangement will simplify payments to, and communication with, veterans who do not have qualifying service and who receive an age pension and a disability pension. The popular support for a concept like this was demonstrated last year when most war widows, who also received a social security pension, opted to receive all payments from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Another administrative reform flowing from this bill is the centralisation of payments to carers. From 1 July 1997, the Department of Social Security will have responsibility for all carer payments. Carers who have received Veterans' Affairs payments will be automatically transferred to the Department of Social Security's carer payment. A small number of carers, who could be disadvantaged or temporarily inconvenienced by the transfer, will continue to be paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Other changes in this bill relate to the better targeting of income support benefits. The first of these address the relative economies single people can obtain from sharing the cost of rental accommodation. Two people in this situation can now receive more rent assistance than a pensioner couple, even if their combined financial circumstances are the same. This bill will address that anomaly. Single people who share rented accommodation will be paid less rent assistance than they would receive if they did not share. There are some shared rent situations, such as for single people who have dependent children and for people in nursing homes, where the pensioner gains no advantage. The new arrangements will not apply in these situations.

This bill also discontinues the `saved' eligibility for fringe benefits of a group of former service pensioners. These are people who would have lost eligibility for fringe benefits as a result of the introduction of deemed income in 1991. All service pensioners later became eligible for fringe benefits and many of those whose eligibility for fringe benefits had been `saved' a few years earlier could again qualify without the help of the `savings' provisions.

The people who will be affected by the changes in this bill are those whose income has been in excess of the pension limits for the past four years. There is no justification to continue to allow these people to enjoy the broad range of fringe benefits provided by the Commonwealth and the community for the assistance of those in greater financial need.

This government remains committed to maintaining existing veterans' entitlements. Benefits and services need to be reviewed to maintain their quality, fairness and appropriateness. The government is also committed to improving efficiency in the delivery of these benefits and services. The outcome will be a system that is responsive to the changing needs of veterans and their families, and one that directs resources to the greatest needs.

In conclusion: this is a bill that reflects the government's intent to achieve greater efficiency in the delivery of services and fairness in the benefits it provides to veterans and their families. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerr) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that we find it necessary in this parliament to debate a bill of this type. The fact is that the Flags Amendment Bill would never have been introduced if there had been absolute certainty amongst members of the parliament and the Australian public that there was no intention ever to change the Australian flag. It was only during the period of the last government that on a number of occasions, which began in 1984, it was necessary for members of the then opposition to constantly remind the parliament and the Australian people that we had a flag that was captive purely to an act of parliament and not to the constitution itself, a flag that was captive to the whims and the balance of numbers in this place and in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: So there were circumstances where uncertainty of the future of the Australian flag started to arise, and it was fostered, I would have to say, both by former Prime Minister Keating and by his predecessor, Bob Hawke. So there were hints, innuendos and some straight statements from time to time which aroused great concern amongst sections of the Australian community and amongst the majority of Australians that their flag, something they had grown up with, something they respected and honoured, was going to be changed at the whim of a parliament.

As I have said, from 1984 there were moves in this parliament and in the Senate—as recently as 1994 by Senator Parer, who brought in a private member's bill in the Senate—to ensure that, firstly, the Australian people were conscious that the Australian flag could be changed by an act of parliament and, secondly, the sophistry of the Australian Labor Party was fully exposed. It seemed to us on this side of the House during that period when the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, went on foreign junkets or foreign travel that he wanted to raise and talk about nothing more significant than the Australian flag or the need for Australia to become a republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a diversion.

—It was a diversion, as the honourable member says, to attract press attention in Australia, but it seemed a strange method of conducting our foreign relations for a Prime Minister to go overseas and then bag the symbols of our nation, the things that we have grown to cherish, the things that we value, to foreigners.
—It is shameful.

—It was shameful, and nobody would understand that better than the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who is at the table, a man who knows the hearts and minds of Australia's veterans, those people who have given their lives and in many instances are suffering ill health from the conflict they participated in on our behalf. Those people know and understand the Australian flag, and that fact is appreciated by the minister and members on this side of the House, but it is not appreciated by the previous Prime Minister.

BREAK.PARA: The previous Prime Minister, on meeting President Suharto, launched into a tirade about the insignificance of the Australian flag, the irrelevancy of the Australian constitution, the need to change the flag and the need to establish a republic. President Suharto, in my opinion, would have been most impressed with a leader who thought so little of his own constitution, his flag and his country's symbols when the first thing that leader did when travelling overseas was to criticise and denigrate those very symbols!

If I were endeavouring to convince the previous Prime Minister—or anybody else for that matter—that he should take a certain course of action, I would seek to persuade him that, first of all, the things I stood for were of value and that he would appreciate sharing them with me. I would tell him that his lifestyle or his opportunities would be enhanced by sharing the same values and goals that I had.

But the previous Prime Minister would not have a bar of that. No! The statement he is claimed to have made is presented in the book of the Prime Minister before him, Bob Hawke. Keating is reported to have said that Australia is the backside of the earth—

TALK.START.PARA: —Arse end.

—I would not use that language in the parliament, but it was language similar to that, I am sure. Keating said that he would leave Australia, because of these characteristics that he described, if he were not made Prime Minister. He said that he must be given a go at leadership or he would buzz out of Australia. He could not stand the place any longer and he was not going to stay here.
—The Labor Party has even taken the Union Jack off the flag.

—Keating had the opportunity in that time, and I think it showed such bad judgment on the part of the Australian Labor Party. Bob Hawke was a bit rough and a bit of a larrikin in his own way, but he was liked by Australians. They thought he was a knockabout Aussie and not a bad sort of fellow. He was not the sort of man who would come into this parliament and snooze. He would enliven the place. He would set it on end. I cannot imagine Bob Hawke, even today in his advancing years, going to sleep on any public occasion, because he with his wife would want to embellish and improve upon the environment where they were. But that is not the case with every member of the Labor Party. Members only have to look around them to know that Bob Hawke's standards are not the standards of the House today.
—Order! The member for Mitchell might return to the subject of the bill.

—I was just referring to the environment of the parliament and the members in it. I thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. Bob Hawke was thought of as something of a larrikin. He was liked by the Australian people and he had the heart of an Aussie. Whilst he endorsed to some extent the broad issues of a republic and the change of the flag, he never pushed the issue hard.

BREAK.PARA: It was the following Prime Minister who made the difference in this place. Keating said that one of the great goals of the Australian Labor Party was to make these changes. I think that was most regrettable. It hurt many important Australians—people important to the strength of the nation. They were not leaders perhaps, but they were people who had worked hard, people whose family had suffered loss or people who had been wounded or maimed during the great conflicts. These are the people who felt the battering and the denigration that was aimed at them through the words of the previous Prime Minister.

Hence, the Flags Amendment Bill that we are debating today has become a necessity for the future of Australia. This issue has been raised three or four times from 1984 until last year, but with the change of government has come our commitment. When in opposition we said that we would, on coming to government, pass an act of parliament which would make it compulsory for the Australian government—unless they wished to be law‐breakers and become illegal in their method of operation—to go to the Australian people with a referendum to decide the future of our flag.

I include that qualification, because a future government wanting to change the flag would have to be a law-breaker. It would be possible for a future government to say, `We're going to ignore this act of parliament or we're going to amend it, so we don't have to go to a referendum and consult the people.' That is certainly true, but they will have to break a law or change a law to do so.

I would like to see the Australian flag and what it stands for become part of the Australian constitution because, whilst the population of Australia changes and the attitudes of the people change, surely the values, the standards and the inheritance that we have make Australia different and unique, and those are the things we ought to be clinging to. Those are the values and standards that have made Australia the great nation that it is, and we must, if possible, stick to them.

I want to read briefly into the Hansard part of a letter I received from a fine gentleman, a fellow called Reg Sampson. Reg Sampson was the auditor for the Reserve Bank. He knows Canberra well. He is a fine, distinguished career banker, a very high level public servant. He wrote to me recently about the matters in this nation which he felt strongly about. I cannot find words that better describe the inheritance of the people of Reg's generation. They are the people who look forward to this parliament and the current generation carrying on some of the standards they set. Reg begins his letter by saying:

One upsetting aspect of Keating's performance regarding our flag is that it is born out of hatred of anything British. Any change born out of hatred is bad and I surmise this is his motivation because the arguments he advances for change are so empty and specious he couldn't believe them himself.

Another aspect of course is his predisposition that we cannot have complete sovereignty, independence and a sense of nationhood until we are a republic and have a new flag. While he and his government spout about sovereignty they surrender ours in numerous ways to the U.N. and other international organisations.
What more do we need to add, because that is a fact? He continues:

When it comes to the question of unity, it was because of the sense of unity already there, that the Australian States federated. Had Keating read much of the diaries and letters of the men of the A.I.F. he would have learnt that they had an intense feeling of Australian nationalism and a pride in it. It is significant that their pride, which with most Australians today lies in the achievements of our sporting greats, was in themselves and their achievements fighting for their country as Australians. My father's own Great War diaries and letters are bound with expressions that the AIF hoped to bring credit to Australia as a nation. On Gallipoli he wrote, "Thank God Australia breeds such heroes".
There is an Australian battler, writing from Gallipoli `Thank God Australia breeds such heroes.' Reg Sampson goes on:

But the feeling of nationhood and unity and pride in their country by Australians was there much earlier than in the Great War. It led to Federation, without the need for unity being created by having to fight a war of independence as happened in America.

In August 1900, before Australia was a Commonwealth, the Australian force at Elands River, during the Boer War, when surrounded by a greater force, and called upon by General De La Rey to surrender, sent the following reply—

"If De La Rey wants our post, why does he not come and take it? We will be pleased to meet him and his men, and promise them a great reception at the end of a toasting fork, Australians never surrender! Australia forever!"
Those words were from the Boer War in 1900—something Keating never understood, something Keating never acknowledged and something Keating could not, in any way, endorse. Reg continues:

The Australians succeeded in holding their position. It should be remembered that they were not an AUSTRALIAN force; But forces under different titles from various States. They were State's military units.
And yet they thought as Australians. It continues:

Reverting to Keating's statement, mentioned in my earlier letter, that Australians fought under the Union Flag in the Great War; I enclose two pieces of evidence of the use of the Australian Flag during that conflict. I would appreciate their return some time. On the notice menu for Anzac Commemoration Dinner in Paris in 1919 you will see the signatures of Billy Hughes then Prime Minister of Australia and Joseph Cook a former P.M. on the left top side. Also (very faint but clearer on the original) that of H.S Gullett, one time M.P. who served in the Light Horse and also wrote the history of the Sinai and Palestine campaigns.

There was one aspect of our heritage and seldom used now, but an excellent form of ombudsmanship, and that was the right to petition the sovereign or his or her representative. Many an injustice or wrong was put right by this device.

He encloses those photographs, records and the news bulletin, The Whispering Boomerang , with a photograph from 20 September, 1917 of Australian soldiers in the Great War holding aloft the Australian flag. Those things that Reg has spoken about to me, and through me to the parliament, are very significant for Australia's future.

I want to conclude my remarks by referring to the flag and what it means for the future of this nation. If we look at the elements of the flag and the symbolism of the flag rather than the precise details of the flag, then we start to appreciate what an inheritance we have.

If we look at the Union Jack, we have to appreciate that there are only about 14 or 15 absolutely free democratic nations on earth. Australia is fortunate to be one of those. In the United Nations scale of ranking of freedoms, if you can devise such a process, Australia is the third freest nation on earth. There are a couple ahead of us, but we have a freedom that I believe is inherited by the parliamentary system that we have and the freedom of the courts from interference by the political process. So the right of a person to go before a court as an innocent individual is a very significant feature of Australian society.

In many courts of the world, people are confronted by an adversarial court system where they go before the court guilty and must prove themselves innocent. Our system is quite different to that, and it is a valuable freedom that we have. I believe that those two features of parliamentary democracy and the freedom of the courts stem from our British inheritance.

In addition, the flag carries the symbol of the Southern Cross, claimed by republicans to be the symbol of republicanism. But I reject that concept. The miners at Eureka were typical Aussies. They told the government to get out of the way and get off their backs. The Australian people told the opposition some years ago that they did not want a GST. I think the fervent nature of Australians in their disregard for authority and government is an endearing character that we inherited and it is something that we should be proud of. No government in Australia will get too big for its boots while we have Australians with an attitude of dismissiveness towards authority and those people who want to preen or to promote authority.

It is my view that the inheritance of the Southern Cross is that of a typical Australian symbol, one that says that we are not overawed by authority. It is a matter where people look to an egalitarian society where there is equality of opportunity and where people seek the best by their own attributes and attitudes.

Finally, the third symbol of the Australian flag is the federal or Commonwealth star which symbolises the states and territories of this nation. The symbolism of one star representing the whole nation is in fact a symbol of unity and the need for this nation to work together as a people if they wish to have achievements.

So, in the symbolism of our flag, if you are thinking of symbolism for the future of this nation, we would have to say that we need and must cling to those inherited values of freedom, the parliamentary process and the significance of our court system, because they very much underpin our very society. The individuality of Australians is a very important characteristic, as is the capacity for us as a nation not to be overawed by government or those in authority but to be able to stand up for our own rights as individuals and as is the need for us as a nation to be able to work together if we want to achieve things.

I think the symbolism of the flag has stood us in good stead in the past and it would be very difficult to replace it with another flag of similar significance. So it is with a great deal of pleasure that I support the Flags Amendment Bill 1996. I know that the bill will go through this parliament. I hope it will become an act of this parliament. I hope that future generations will value the contribution of members of this House as much as we can value the contributions of those who have gone before who have pointed out to us the way in which we need to revere and adhere to the principles and symbolisms that our flag stands for, because our flag does represent our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly gives me great pleasure this afternoon to rise to add my contribution to this debate on the Flags Amendment Bill. You may have picked up that I am wearing a bow tie, which is not my custom. This is a particularly fine bow tie.
—It is a fabulous bow tie.

—Exactly, a fabulous bow tie. It has been fashioned on the Sunshine Coast and represents our national flag. It was given to me by Mr Peter Lawlor, who is the current President of the Caboolture RSL Subdistricts. I thank him very much because it says a little about my feelings towards our flag. I am an unabashed supporter of the Australian flag. I believe it represents us well today and I hope very sincerely that it will continue into the future.
—I love your bow tie.
—I appreciate your comment. I love my bow tie as well.
—I think the gallery should see it too.

—Yes, the gallery really should see the bow tie. What I like about the Australian flag is that it tells a story. It is not just a piece of coloured cloth. It is not three stripes. It tells a story about where we are, who we are and where we come from.

BREAK.PARA: As the previous speaker, the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), said, it shows the Southern Cross, which represents where we are in the world. It shows our unity as a nation with the federation star and the Union Jack. The Union Jack is not only about where we have come from and where our roots are—I am not too sure that others have alluded to it in this debate—but also the compilation of three other flags, they being the three Christian flags of St George, St Patrick and St Andrew.

It also says something about what we are as a nation. When we fill out our census forms the overwhelming majority of Australians today still refer to themselves as Christians. It says where we are in the world geographically, the fact that we are unified, the fact that we are all together as one, and it says a little about where we have come from. The flag crosses all boundaries, whether you are black, white or brindle. It crosses your demographic and social boundaries. It is all‐encompassing. That is why I embrace the Australian flag.

This bill today is not about whether I like the Australian flag or whether I want to see it changed, as some in this House obviously do. It is about whether or not one person or any one organisation should be able to change that flag without first relating that back to the people in the form of a plebiscite, a vote of the people.

A symbol as important as our flag certainly deserves the consideration of the nation as a whole before it is changed. Many speakers before me have related how the flag was decided by competition and that it was only in the fifties that the flag actually passed into law, even though it has been used for the best part of 100 years. It is also important for people to remember that we have only been a nation for less than 100 years. Whilst white Australians have been in this place for over 200 years, we have only been a nation—one Australian people—since the turn of the century. When we go into the next millennium, we must ask ourselves whether we are going to allow the will of just a few people or one or two organisations to determine the future of our pre‐eminent symbol of this nation.

I would like to turn to a couple of the comments that have been made by those opposite in regard to our current flag. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) pointed out to us that when he is overseas and people run the New Zealand flag up the flagpole he is embarrassed because they have mistaken the New Zealand flag for the Australian flag.
