INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Student Leadership Forum on Faith and Values

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to draw attention to what will be known as the National Student Leadership Forum on Faith and Values. This is an initiative primarily of a constituent of mine, Mr Peter Pickles, and his wife, Sue. It is also supported by business and community members and facilitated by a group of members and senators from the federal parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Those members, of which I am one, with Mr Pickles and his colleagues will be conducting the forum here in Canberra from 13 February to 16 February 1997 at the Rydges Lakeside Hotel and also in Parliament House. I think credit also needs to be given in particular to Mr Jock Cameron, the brother of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron), who has actually been doing a lot of work in organising the forum. We are hopeful that our national political leaders will be addressing the forum. The forum is about nurturing leadership qualities in young Australians in their late teens and early 20s.

At a time of year which is usually characterised by prize-giving night speeches—with which I know honourable members will be only too familiar—and young people making decisions about careers, I think it is worth saying a few things about success and leadership, which will be themes addressed by the forum.

I have been asked in recent years about success—in particular, by young doctors about success in medicine—and I would like to share with the House some reflections that I have upon it. I think it is important that we all remember that, no matter how old or wise we may think we are, many of the facts that we now learn, the things we believe to be facts, will become superseded and those that are not superseded we will forget.

In the end, for young people in particular, I think it is worth remembering that your final achievements in life eventually depend on your continuing ability to acquire new knowledge, the inner integrity of your intellect—something which is destroyed, of course, through experimentation with drugs—and the humanity with which you deal with other people. As they say, those who give the most in life are those who receive much more than they give. In the end, people are remembered not for what they know but for who they are.

For young people also, I think it is worth remembering that success is not measured by the number of degrees that you accumulate, the wealth that you may also accumulate as you go through life, nor by the spectrum of people whom you know. If you look throughout the community and society to those for whom we have the highest regard, it is those who have fought for the things in which they believe. Facing adversity and hardship and, at times, criticism in their chosen fields, these are people who persevered in making the lives of the rest of us perhaps that much better.

In choosing a career, which is something that many young people are doing at the moment, I have certainly found that it is helpful to ask yourself the question: `When I get to the end of my working life, is this the sort of career which I feel will have made my life worth while? Is it one in which I will have been of greatest service to others?' That of course is something which gives people the greatest satisfaction with their lives—no matter what field of endeavour they may pursue.

In considering the issues of leadership throughout the forum, we will be considering precisely what it is about and trying to nurture these kinds of values in young people in particular and, in doing so, relate them to a sense of values and perhaps a faith in something greater than themselves. Essentially, I believe that leadership is a presence that attracts other people to follow and to participate in a common cause. It is not about charisma, as the St James Ethics Centre reminds us, but it is an infectious wish to bring about positive things for the good of the community and for the country. Leadership is about engendering and evoking in others a genuine enthusiasm for overcoming their own self‐interest and supporting those things that are in the best long‐term interests of society.

We will be thinking about things like ethics. We will be encouraging people to be at ease with themselves, to be motivated by a sense of duty and responsibility. We will encourage clear‐minded decisiveness in young people and the courage to achieve. I urge honourable members to bring forward names of young people in their electorates who they feel may be interested and suitable for such a forum. We will be looking for energy, wit, commonsense, integrity, self-restraint, humility and openness in the young people who come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the year draws to a close, I would like to reflect on the fact that this year, 1996, is the International Year for the Eradication of Poverty. It is also the year that John Howard was swept into office with massive support from Australians, particularly those battling and blue‐collar Australians who deserted the Labor Party in droves.

PARA.BREAK: Australia has always been the lucky country. But for some Australians the luck has run out. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that the poorest 10 per cent of Australian households struggle on an average gross income of $5,230 per annum; that the average income of the poorest 30 per cent of house holds is less than $10,000 per annum; and that half of Australian households live on $24,000 or less per annum. It is therefore no surprise that a recent Smith Family study into poverty showed that as many as 30 per cent of Australians are living in poverty. These facts should greatly concern all members of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: In June this year, I was shocked to read a UNICEF report, The Progress of Nations, which outlined that Australia is one of five industrialised nations to have more than 10 per cent of its children living in poverty. This comes just a few years after that immortal line by former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who said, `No Australian child will be living in poverty by 1990.'

It is well known that one of the main causes of poverty is unemployment. And there is no denying that members opposite presided over some of the highest unemployment rates in this nation's history. It is also well known that the best way to alleviate poverty is the creation of secure, full‐time jobs. But real jobs can be created only if we free up the labour market and get small business back on its feet.

The workplace relations bill is the start of a more sensible and flexible labour market for our country. Since the Howard government has come into office, three interest rate cuts have meant great news for people battling to pay their monthly mortgage and for young families who have put off buying their first home.

Further good news comes in the announcement of a safety net increase of $24 a week, phased in over three years, to low paid workers. And many families, particularly those with young children, will benefit from our family tax initiative which comes into effect from 1 January 1997 and delivers an extra $34 per fortnight of disposable income.

You can see, Mr Speaker, that our aim on this side of the House is to raise people out of the poverty trap into which they have fallen through no fault of their own over the last decade of Labor government.

Since last week, my electorate office has been contacted by many people who have found it extremely difficult to cope with purchasing basic foods, let alone presents for their children this Christmas. We can help these people in the short term by providing special food hampers, but it does not change the fact that their situation is desperate all year round.

Many Australians do not understand just how bad it is for the 1.8 million poor who hide their poverty because they are too embarrassed to ask for help. In recent years there has been an increasing number of working poor who are not eligible for concessions but who also do not earn enough money to make ends meet.

Traditionally, welfare agencies provided short‐term emergency relief. Yet during the past few years charities and social welfare agencies have been increasingly requested to prop up low income families to cover their basic living costs.

I take this opportunity to acknowledge some special people who bring happiness over the Christmas period to those families who are struggling to get by. Father Brian Morrison, a tireless worker, is this year launching his 20th Christmas appeal. Graham Maybury, of the Livingstone Foundation, has distinguished himself by being a friend and helper to many throughout my electorate of Canning. Then there is Keith Tyson, from the Gosnells Salvation Army. Keith and I have worked together many times at Christmas, preparing Christmas hampers for locals in need.

There are far too many others to mention, but what would our community do without these wonderful people who, together with the members of their organisations, volunteer their services.The coalition government has not only recognised the wonderful work carried out by such organisations, but also increased spending on youth homelessness, emergency relief and several other welfare programs. Solutions to alleviate poverty rest not only with the government and service providers, but also with members of our community. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to express some concern in the House tonight that the government's announcement today concerning the future of the petroleum industry will do nothing to guarantee the future livelihood and wellbeing of some 9,000 service station operators who sell, service and repair Australia's motor vehicle fleet. I refer to the members of the Motor Trades Association of Australia and also those involved in service stations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission had recommended to the government that the petroleum industry's price surveillance regulations be removed and that the two petroleum specific acts, the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980, be repealed. In fact, we need the opposite—that legislation needs to be strengthened.

Most honourable members should have received two pieces of correspondence from the Motor Trades Association of Australia and from the Service Station Association Ltd which bear this out very strongly. They indicate that to date oil companies have not shown that they are willing to negotiate in good faith on matters of importance to service station operators. The situation is so serious that the directors of the Motor Trades Association of Australia decided at their meeting in October to withdraw immediately from Oilcode.

When Oilcode was established back in 1989, those who became parties to it did so on the understanding that it would be underpinned by the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act rather than be a substitute for that act. So Oilcode has relied for its existence upon the acts and therefore cannot substitute for them.

It is also a matter of concern that service station operators are excluded from all of the state and territory tenancy acts because tenure is provided by the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. Repeal of these acts would mean that service station operators have no tenure, no legal rights with respect to renewals, non‐renewals or any other of the elements of their commercial relationship with those franchisors unless they are provided by contract, which they never have been.

BREAK.PARA: This is a matter of considerable concern, as have been the proposals for the entry of new parties like Woolworths to the petroleum market in circumstances where the competition would not be fair because they would have a buying advantage as against the franchise service station operators who are tied to their franchisor for 100 per cent of their supplies for petroleum markets.

So in those circumstances, with Woolworths expected to open an estimated 250 petrol outlets, the industry will be subjected to significant structural adjustment through attrition, quite probably through bankruptcy, and quite possibly many service stations will close with the loss of a great many jobs. So in these circumstances we need some changes.

We have had strong recommendations from the Service Station Association concerning the need for price access to untie supply in order to keep oligopolies and the major oil companies honest over the long term. We need the supply untied but we also need legislation to protect franchisees. In this regard it is important that the federal parliament's inquiry into fair trading come down with appropriate recommendations.

In the past oil companies have not made adequate disclosure to franchisees. They have harshly and unilaterally altered franchise agreements without the prior agreement of or even in consultation with the franchisees concerned. In those circumstances, franchisees are often the economic captives of the franchisor and they do not get a fair go. As a result, there is a need for legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act to specifically prohibit harsh or oppressive commercial conduct.

We need price access by untying supply to allow 50 per cent of fuel to be competitively outsourced. We should update the petroleum acts into one effective petroleum act and support a stronger petroleum code of practice.

It is disappointing that the government's announcement this afternoon said absolutely nothing about the future of those involved in petrol retailing in this country. I am concerned that, if the government does not turn its mind to these issues, a great many people who are involved in petrol stations will go out of business or will continue to be the victims of the oil company's abuse of the market power which it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Western Australian Labor Party has promised to wind back the industrial relations clock by four years by promising to remove the industrial relations reforms on workplace agreements if it is elected this Saturday, 14 December. This is yet another indication that the Australian Labor Party is an industrial relations dinosaur when it comes to workplace reform. It is a step back into the dark ages of workplace regimentation.

SPEECH.PARA: All informed workers and hence voters in this Saturday's Western Australian election will be aware that the award is, quite rightly, the safety net provision for workers. Without the flexibility of the workplace agreements provisions, workers are locked into a very rigid pay deal which gives them little chance to better their pay and conditions. Dr Gallop's proposals should scare the living daylights out of Western Australian workers when they contemplate his returning them to the dark ages of industrial relations, especially those tens of thousands of Western Australian workers already happily employed on individual contracts.

Is there really another agenda? Prior to the 1993 Western Australian election, the former ALP labor relations minister, Yvonne Henderson, stated that it was her party's and her intention that all WA workers would be compelled to join a union. Yes, the ALP were going to make union membership in Western Australia compulsory. Yvonne Henderson and the former Lawrence ALP government were keen supporters of the draconian no ticket, no start mentality in the Western Australian work force.

Is this what Geoff Gallop and the state ALP want to return WA workers to? Under the Court coalition government, Western Australian workers have had a choice. This flexibility in the Western Australian work force has seen WA workers achieving great take-home pay and the ability to earn more.

It has seen the union hobnail boot taken from the throat of the worker, but small business and employers need the ability to make localised and personal decisions about mutually agreed pay and conditions, and the flexibility to negotiate and trade off to achieve these ends. There is no creditable economic commentator in this country who does not agree that the Australian work force in general must become more flexible before greater and sustained growth can occur and that this flexibility in the labour force will see a genuine reduction in unemployment, and youth unemployment in particular.

Few workers and employers in Western Australia would disagree that the coalition's current workplace policy strikes a good balance between productivity and fairness. It allows workers to negotiate agreements on an individual basis. Alternatively, if the worker wants to be employed under the award, they can choose to do so.

Geoff Gallop, by wanting to impose collective bargaining on workplace agreements, chooses to ignore the fact that 70 per cent of the Western Australian work force does not belong to a union. These people want the individual flexibility to negotiate their own set of conditions which they want to factor to their personal circumstances. For example, a mum wanting to start work after nine and finish at 3.30 p.m. can do so under a flexible agreement—so she can take her kids to and from school—if agreed terms and conditions are negotiated.

The other 30 per cent making up the unionised work force can choose to negotiate with the union as their agent at this moment in Western Australia, if that is their choice. However, I am not convinced that all of that 30 per cent union membership in Western Australia would choose to select the collective arrangement with the union as their agent.

I declare that Dr Gallop should stop pandering to the Western Australian unions. I say to Western Australians: don't vandalise the productivity gains and wages growth that have been achieved under a more flexible workplace agreements program in Western Australia; don't victimise or terrorise those workers whose individual and legal right it is to choose the flexibility and productivity that go with the Court government's Workplace Agreement Act. I say to Dr Gallop: stop beating up on the workers for crass political mileage. Give Western Australia back to a creditable coalition government that has run its workplace the way that a progressive government should do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise two matters this evening. The first concerns a purchase by the 11-year-old son of one of my constituents, who was a member of a school delegation from Caves Beach Public School to the parliament and to the Australian War Memorial on 15 October. During that visit he bought and took back home to his mother what he thought was Australia's symbol, the kangaroo, and what he thought was an Australian flag. It is a very poor representation of the Australian flag. When you look at the label on the kangaroo, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: C.A. Australia
all new material
synthetic fibre
this item has been
quality and safety tested
designed in Australia
handcrafted in China

I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to have a look at the wisdom of this—with all the rhetoric that is going on about nationalism, particularly in the flag debate today—when a 11-year-old child thought he had bought something wonderful for his mother. Please have a look, Minister, to see what can be done about it.

The other matter is totally different. It is one that I feel very deeply about. I ask all other members of the parliament to join with me this evening in paying tribute to the four miners who had their lives snatched from them in the tragic mine disaster at Gretley Colliery near Wallsend at about 5.30 a.m. on 15 November last. The four men were: 48-year-old Edward Batterham of Teralba, which is in the electorate of Charlton; 36‐year‐old John Hunter and 30‐year‐old Mark Kaiser, both of Belmont; and 19-year-old Damon Murray of Redhead. The latter three were all from my electorate.

Here in the parliament of Australia, I want to place on record the courage of those four Australians. They worked in a hostile environment—as do all underground miners. They worked in conditions under pressures and dangers which would not be tolerated, even understood, by many members of this House.

They were decent, honourable Australians doing their everyday job of work. How they died and why they were engulfed in the sudden torrent of water that broke through the coalface is yet to be established. I want to convey to each member of the four families involved and to the loved ones of each of the deceased my deepest sympathy at their tragic loss. Miners are so often derided as underworked and overpaid, mostly by people who have no conception whatsoever of mining conditions and the bonds between miners—the bonds that are so utterly essential to their survival underground.

Mining is a dangerous occupation. The risk of injury is seven times greater than any other industry, yet there are Rambo mine owners, mine managements and mine associations which claim that the safe working regulations, the safety practices, are too tough, too stringent; that mine safety should be deregulated; and that mine safety practices should be left to the determination of individual mine managements.

There is scarcely a family in the Hunter that is not in some way linked to mining. My two eldest sons work underground, so I feel it particularly. Since 1847, some 1,532 miners have died in mining accidents in the Newcastle area. The grief of the Hunter and the pain that is shared was evident at the emotional and crowded memorial service conducted on Wednesday, 27 November at the Sacred Heart Cathedral, Hamilton. The service was conducted by the Catholic bishop Michael Malone and the Anglican bishop Roger Herft. It was attended by the Governor of New South Wales, His Excellency Gordon Samuels, the New South Wales Premier, members from both sides of the New South Wales parliament plus many other members of parliament both state and federal. We honoured those four miners; we honoured their families.

The industry is tough and dangerous and the rules governing its safe working conditions must be correspondingly tough. I have heard various explanations of the cause of the flooding of the coalface where the four men were working. There were old workings nearby dating back to the 1920s. The maps, it appears, may have been wrongly marked. I am told that approximately a 4-feet by 4-feet hole burst through the coalface and they were engulfed with the enormous force that came through, that water, about 100 metres under ground.

I am encouraged that the honourable member for Port Stephens, the Minister for Mineral Resources, Mr Bob Martin, has established a judicial inquiry to be conducted by Mr James Staunton, the former District Court judge who conducted the Seaview Air commission of inquiry. I ask other members of the parliament to join with me in an expression of grief, comfort and condolence to the members of the families of the four deceased.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Shortland. I am sure the hearts of all Australians go out to the grieving relatives of those killed in the tragic accident referred to by the honourable member for Shortland.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Meyers, Mr LindsayRedford, Sister Mary Agnese

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight about some of the wonderful people of Petrie. It is with very great sadness that I speak about the passing of Mr Lindsay Meyers. The St Peter the Fisherman's Anglican church at Clontarf was packed on Monday with hundreds of people for the funeral of Redcliffe businessman and community activist Lindsay Meyers. Mr Meyers died last Thursday aged 71 after fighting a very long battle with motor neurone disease. He is very sadly missed.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Meyers was born in Maryborough, attended the Gympie High School and joined scouts at a very young age. He had a very long and active involvement in the scouting movement. For that, he was duly recognised as a district commissioner and a regional commissioner. He was also assistant chief commissioner and Brisbane North area commissioner.

After the war he became a saw doctor and married Molly McMillan. They had a home in Redcliffe for many years. They have two children, Kathryn and Russell. He was very keen on tennis and was a very active member of the Redcliffe Tennis Association, where he was president for five years.

From 1972 to 1975 the family was situated in Papua New Guinea where Mr Meyers oversaw the establishment of a planing mill for Papua New Guinea softwoods. On many occasions since my time as the member for Petrie, he lobbied me about the importation of these wood products from overseas—quite heavily, I might add—so I was in constant contact with him. He was a man of great energy.

He was a member of the Papua New Guinea Apprentice Board. He also set up three scout groups in Papua New Guinea. He returned to Redcliffe where he bought the Dunstan's Planing Mill on Anzac Avenue and he went into joint partnership with an English firm to fingerjoint timber and produce mouldings. They are very well known throughout the Petrie electorate for this work. His son, Russell, now manages the family business.

After some time, Mr Meyers sold out and decided to help his son. He then joined the Queensland Timber Board Merchants Division where he was elected to the Queensland Forest Industry Training Council to help young people train in the timber industry, and he was noted for the great work he did in this industry.

He was a charter member of the Kippa‐Ring Rotary Club and was awarded one of Rotary's highest honours—the Paul Harris Fellowship. I have had a number of events and functions organised by Mr Meyers and have had a great involvement with Rotary as well. As if that was not enough, he was a member of the Alcohol and Drug Foundation Redcliffe branch and became Queensland branch treasurer.

BREAK.PARA: I will always remember him as a man of great energy and great dedication. He always had a smile. He was respected by all in the Redcliffe community, and was also willing to help anyone who needed a hand. I pass on my sincerest condolences and sympathy to his wife, Molly, and his children, Russell and Kathryn. He will be sadly missed by all in Redcliffe.

Tonight, I also want to speak about another outstanding person in Redcliffe—a wonderful person by the name of Sister Mary Agnese Redford, who will be celebrating 60 years since she was professed. This is her diamond jubilee as a sister of the Good Samaritan order. She celebrates 60 years as a sister, having been ordained on 12 January 1937—60 years ago.

She is very well respected at the Ballycara aged care complex, which I visit on a regular basis. I have met with sister there on a number of occasions. We are very delighted to share in her wonderful achievement. She is very much loved there. She is quite an energetic lady and a wonderful contributor to the local community, as well as to all the people in that complex.

I would very much like to congratulate Sister Mary. She has had a distinguished career. It is just amazing. She has travelled throughout Australia in her role. I wish to congratulate her on the occasion of her 60-year diamond jubilee celebrations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to express my extreme disappointment with the answer from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) today to the question of the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) about compensation for Howe Leather. I think it was very mean‐spirited for him not to understand the difficulties that the workers of Howe Leather and their families face, especially in the run-up to Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a minister who needs to understand that, in a region like the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne where, over the last three months, unemployment has increased from 10 per cent to 13 per cent, there is a great degree of uncertainty. There is uncertainty because the minister will not take the lead on industry policy and explain to the Australian work force what this government is going to do about the intractable problems of the manufacturing industry.

Another project in the electorate of Scullin that gives scope for increased employment opportunities is the development of the Janefield land where there is a proposal to have an automotive components technology park that depends on support from not only industry but also local, state and federal government. I urge the minister to consider being involved in that project to ensure that it goes ahead.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Truss:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me this morning to talk on the report, Managing Australia's World Heritage , handed down by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I do so as a member of that committee, but with an apology as well. I became a member of this committee only this year, and have done so in my capacity more as a shadow minister for sport than as somebody with the prerequisite to be concerned principally with environmental matters. As a consequence, I did not participate in too many of the inquiry discussions on this matter. In fact, history will show that it was work largely done in the previous parliament by the former committee—and carried on ably, I might say, under the direction of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) in the present parliament—which has seen this document produced.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I would say that this again gives an indication of how effective parliamentary committees can be in looking at very important issues in the national parliament and making recommendations which we hope the government would like to act upon. It is specifically on the area of World Heritage recommendations that have flowed from this report and the way that government might operate and might take cognisance of those reports that I want to make some comments today. One of the most important World Heritage areas that Australia possesses is, amongst many others, the Great Barrier Reef. Therefore, I am sure it will come as no surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, or to my colleague the honourable member for Wide Bay, the chairman of the committee that is with us today, that I take this opportunity to make some comments about the management of the Great Barrier Reef, about the recommendations that are contained in this document, and about what I perceive to be some very misguided policy direction which the government has chosen to adopt as a result of budget constraints and the need to raise revenue.

Of course, I refer more generally to what has become known as the reef tax issue in North Queensland. Interestingly, the committee did in fact touch on this issue, at about page 183 of the report, where they talked about the reef tax. At paragraph 8.40 and subsequent paragraphs, the report lists a couple of the concerns which I have about the implementation of that proposal.

To refresh members' memories, I remind you that the proposal for an increase in the reef tax, or the environmental management charge, first surfaced in the 1996‐97 budget. As members would know, a $1 charge had been placed by the former government on the use of marine facilities by visitors to the reef; that is, the major tour operators using boats to take visitors out to the reef charged an extra $1 as an environmental management charge, and the proceeds of that were to go to the management of the reef itself and to aid in ensuring that the environmental purity of the area was not denigrated to any extent.

BREAK.PARA: This government, regrettably, has seen that charge as something of a milch cow: in the budget it was announced that there was to be a 500 per cent increase in the reef tax, to take effect from 1 January 1997. Quite rightly, the local operators in the tourism industry were up in arms about this decision. They were up in arms because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had, during the election campaign, stood in Cairns in the midst of the tourism operators and had told them categorically that not only would there be no increases in taxes and no new taxes introduced by his government but also that in tourism specifically, and in respect of the reef tax, there would be no change. To say that the tourism operators felt betrayed by the Prime Minister and that they questioned his credibility as a result of the 500 per cent increase mooted in the budget is an understatement.

As time went on we saw that this issue gained momentum, particularly in five electorates on the North Queensland coast. We saw that the local members, either Liberal or National Party, came under considerable pressure from the tourism operators and their constituents to have this decision overturned. They seemed to make grandiose promises whilst they were in their electorates but, unfortunately, when they came to Canberra they must have remained reasonably silent because they certainly have not delivered.

We saw that constant requests from our side of politics for this issue to be reviewed and debated in the parliament were rebutted on every occasion. Parliamentary tactics were used to shut me down when I tried to bring motions to the parliament or bring matters of public importance to the notice of the parliament. There were four separate occasions when that happened. It was quite obvious that the government was running scared on this matter, which the committee rightly identified in its report as one of major concern. As a consequence, we had extraordinary scenes. For example, an organisation in Far North Queensland actually came out and said that the minister responsible, Robert Hill, should be sacked.

Following an announcement of a review of the operations of GBRMPA—the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—which is covered in this World Heritage report, Steven Moon, General Manager of Ocean Spirit Cruises and spokesman of the Cairns‐based Marine Tourism Industry, said in a press release that that was nice, but it had nothing to do with the reef tax. He went on:

We are calling on the Prime Minister to intervene in this issue not only to resolve it once and for all but also to maintain his own integrity after promising the industry in Cairns this would not happen.
Mr Moon also said:

It is imperative that Senator Hill be asked to surrender his portfolio to a more competent and efficient member of government to maintain any credibility for any future negotiations that may be required with industry. The feeling at this time is the government cannot be trusted.

This was from the industry which had gotten behind the coalition in these five seats in the last election on the back of a promise that the reef tax would not be increased, and suddenly felt betrayed. And that press release had followed another, under the heading of `Promises, promises, broken promises!' which had been issued in September by tourism operators.

The simple fact was that, behind the scenes, the pressure was starting to tell because John Moore, the minister for tourism—who is, after all, a Queenslander—and also Minister Robert Hill did have some meetings with the operators in Queensland. That was the first sign of any consultation he had with them. Interestingly enough, at five seconds to midnight, literally—on the day before President Clinton's visit—a press release was slotted out by Robert Hill saying, `We have had a change of heart and we are going to have a two‐for‐one tax.' It is not just going to be an increase by 500 per cent in one hit; we are going to have a two‐for‐one tax. `We will increase the reef tax, the EMC, from $1 to $2 to start on 1 January 1997 and then'—interestingly enough—`there will be a new $4 tourist visitor charge levied on users of commercial facilities and craft from 1 January 1998.'

My maths tells me that is still going to be $6. My maths tells me that, in 1998, it will still amount to a 500 per cent increase. But, interestingly, it raises some other problems for the minister. A $4 tourist visitor charge is only going to apply to Queensland and it is only going to apply to users of the Great Barrier Reef. So it is anti‐Queensland and anti‐tourism, and it is supported by a minister who comes from Queensland—the minister for tourism, John Moore. After Minister Hill put out his press release, Mr Moore put out a press release saying this was a great idea. His press release said:
Mr Moore said today's announcement was a win for the tourism industry—
What a joke that is, because the tourism industry did not see it that way.

We found out that that little proposal was actually floated by Senator O'Chee and the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) at a secret soiree—which was not so secret—in Cairns on 11 November. I just happened to be up there at the time and I knew that it was on. It was on at 8.30 in the morning and these two guys—a couple of boys on a man's errand—went along to try and convince the tourism operators they should accept this so‐called compromise.

The Cairns Post the next day said it all: `Compromise over reef tax rejected.' The tourism operators said, `This just won't work. You are still going to give us a $6 increase management fee reef tax.' The thing that is even more worrying for the tourism industry—and which is rightly pointed to in that section of the report which we are debating here this morning—goes to the question of the new $4 tourist visitor charge. I do not care how you dress it up, that is an increased tax; it is a new tax. And that goes counter to everything that this government has said about no new taxes and no increases in existing taxes.

But there is something even more sinister in this—and people have not cottoned on to this yet. The reef tax, as it is now, is levied on people who get on one of the Quicksilver or Ocean Spirit cruises and go out to have a look at the Great Barrier Reef. I did it myself. I took my family out there in April of this year. You get on the boat and go out to the Reef. You get snorkel equipment and you paddle around and have a great look at the Reef. It is a fabulous experience. It is one of the main reasons why we are attracting so many tourists to Australia, particularly from markets in the Asian region.

But now we find that the press release that Senator Hill has put out and which Minister Moore thinks is fabulous—this is a Queenslander supporting an anti‐Queensland tax—says that this new $4 tourist visitor charge is going to be levied on users of `commercial facilities and craft'. What does that mean? Does it mean it is not now going to just apply to the vessels that go out, but also to commercial facilities in our tourism mecca of North Queensland? To me it means that it can also be levied on restaurants and hotels. This is a de facto bed tax dressed up as some sort of an environmental management charge. The words are not mine; the words are directly from this media release from Senator Robert Hill.

It is a joke. In this report on the managing of Australia's World Heritage, on that same page which I referred to earlier, it goes on to say that this charge should not be just levied upon the people that it was formerly levied upon; the tax should not just simply be on them. It talks about any users of the Reef. It talks about the recreational boat users—people that are in single craft up there.

That is quite interesting, because on 23 May 1995, John Moore, who was then the Shadow Minister for Industry, Commerce and Public Administration in the opposition—but, again, still a Queensland member of this parliament—and who now is the Minister for Tourism, purporting to represent Queensland tourism, wrote to the Independent Boat Owners Association and said:
Thank you for your recent correspondence regarding the introduction of an environment management charge or reef tax. I appreciate you writing to me on this matter.
I bet he did. He stated further:
I would like to assure you that the Liberal Party is opposed to the introduction of an environment management charge.
Once again, thank you for raising your concerns with me.

I know we all write letters and say things occasionally that come back to haunt us. This letter will come back to haunt John Moore. Quite clearly, the report, in its recommendation that the reef tax should apply not only to people using the Ocean Spirit or Quicksilver boats, on page 184, paragraph 8.43 says:

The Committee considers that a joint State/Commonwealth review of fees applied to users of the reef region should be carried out, with a view to recommendations being made on how a single fee could be applied to all users of the reef that incorporates in an equitable manner charges for those purposes for which each user accesses the reef.

So the recommendation coming from the committee—chaired by someone, I might say, who has done an excellent job in this report—suggests that all users of the reef now be levied the increases in the reef tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have already agreed.

—I have already disclaimed that part. We have seen Senator Robert Hill and his environment management charge—and that will be seen again when this regulation comes forward. I stand up and say in this place, as I have said in the parliament—or tried to say it until you lot gagged me in there—that this particular management charge we will be opposing. We will be moving against that when it comes both to the House and in the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: I again go to this fact about commercial facilities and craft. My beef is not with the committee and the committee chairman, because I think the committee, in the process of looking at the issues, came to decisions based on the information contained in reports that were given to them. My concern is that the minister has not responded, for example, to the editorial in the Sunday Mail of Sunday, 24 November, talking about the reef tax being introduced and being anti‐Queensland, anti‐tourism and anti‐jobs. That editorial has to be rammed home to both these ministers.

Let me conclude by simply saying again that I think the report itself in general is very good. Regrettably, I do not think enough time was spent on the reef tax issue. It is only a couple of pages and about three paragraphs, and not all its ramifications were considered. I note that none of the members who represent the North Queensland seats made any representations to the committee for consideration, but that is their prerogative and fits into the pattern that they have been adopting here. This tax will be opposed by the opposition when it comes before both chambers for deliberation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next member, I might observe to the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) that a soiree at 8.30 in the morning is rather a contradiction in terms. I call the honourable member for Wide Bay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome this opportunity to contribute to the debate on the report. Let me at the outset thank the members of the committee for their contribution to this particular report. I think it is a report of considerable substance. The honourable member who has just spoken, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), acknowledged that the reef tax took only one or two pages. That is because there were many other issues of at least equal significance—I would argue greater significance—on which the committee spent a great deal of its time in preparing the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to the former chairman of the committee, John Langmore, who resigned from this parliament on Friday. Unfortunately, not many of us were given an opportunity to speak following his valedictory comments. On behalf of the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee, I would like to recognise his considerable contribution to the committee as its chairman. I had the honour to be his deputy for quite a period of his term as chairman, and I always found him to be extremely fair, a very caring person, a very pleasant person, who went to great lengths to ensure that the committee was able to consider issues in a balanced and responsible way. John Langmore came into the parliament, from memory, in 1984. He was a member of the committee from 16 October 1991 and became chairman from 4 June 1992, until the change of government precluded his continuation in that position.

John took a keen interest in social, environmental and particularly economic issues. He was the author of a number of books and was very highly regarded by all members in the House. It could be argued that he was not a man of his time. He was advocating interventionist policies at a time when the trend was towards deregulation, he had a particular interest in social policy when economic issues seemed to be the priority, and he believed in equality at a time when there was a growing variation between rich and poor. But I think John contributed greatly to the intellectual and philosophical debates of the parliament. I congratulate him on the very high post that he has achieved at the United Nations. I know he will fulfil his responsibilities there capably and he will be a wonderful ambassador for Australia and contribute once more to his country in that post.

So I acknowledge with gratitude the contribution of John Langmore and the previous committee in developing this report. In that regard I would like to also mention a couple of other members of the committee who were not here to see it presented: Neville Newell, Bob Chynoweth and Bob Horne from the Labor Party, who took a keen interest in this inquiry and participated in many of the inspections; and particularly also Bruce Lloyd. He was one of those who were really at the forefront in instigating this inquiry and who were also very diligent in participating in its public hearings. He was, because of his retirement from parliament, not here to see it presented. I did arrange for him to get a copy of the report and he spoke enthusiastically about its recommendations and was delighted to see that it had come to the parliament.

The facts are that Australia is a wonderful country with tremendous resources and wonderful scenic attractions. Perhaps that is no better illustrated than by our involvement with the World Heritage Convention. The World Heritage Convention came into force in 1975. Australia was one of the first signatories and now there are 146 countries that are a party to the convention, which makes it one of the most significant international conventions.

There were 469 properties on the World Heritage list as of December 1995. Of those, 102 are natural sites and it is an interesting statistic that 11 of those 102 sites are in Australia. So of the 102 most notable places in the world, an incredible 11 are in Australia. That says a great deal about our scenic and natural attributes but also about our special responsibilities to care effectively for our World Heritage areas.

One of the key elements that was apparent in the evidence the committee received and, indeed, was an underlying theme throughout all of the deliberations of the committee, was that Australia, particularly in the early stages of the World Heritage Convention, was extremely enthusiastic about nominating areas. However, our enthusiasm for nomination was not extended to a commitment to the management and funding and adequate caring for the areas that we had nominated.

Regrettably, around the country, very negative attitudes started to develop towards World Heritage listing. There was almost a fear in the community whenever it was suggested that an area should be nominated for the list. In my own region, which probably has had more potential World Heritage nominations than any other electorate in the country, the issues became so significant that I prepared a guide on World Heritage listing to explain what it actually meant. I did so to try to explain to the people in my constituency that World Heritage listing did not mean giving the land away to the Libyans or having people from Paris come in and say what we could do and run the day-to-day affairs of the community. On the other hand, I needed to explain that some of the extravagant claims that were being made by supporters of World Heritage listing, namely, that it meant automatic tourism and the showering of money from Commonwealth and state governments, were also inaccurate.

It has always been the case that the only way to attract tourists to an area is to provide appropriate facilities and happy tourism experiences. The word then spreads from one to another that this is a great place to visit. In fact, there is quite a deal of evidence to show that at some sites World Heritage listing has actually led to a drop in the number of tourists. It is an issue that has been oversold in some areas as a benefit for World Heritage listing.

On the other hand, some of the fears that have been instilled in communities are, frankly, irresponsible and have not been borne out by the facts. I have not noticed any extra Libyans wandering around Fraser Island since it has been nominated, and that is clearly the case everywhere. However, I think that the Commonwealth and the states, but particularly the Commonwealth, failed for the first decade or more of World Heritage listing to adequately explain what it meant and to take the local communities into their confidence when an area was proposed for nomination.

The committee has therefore recommended that in the future, before an area is nominated, there needs to be thorough and active community consultation. We need to win the support of the community and a part of that process needs to be to develop the management plan in advance. It was always intended under the World Heritage Convention that the management plan be submitted as a part of the nomination, but that did not really happen in Australia's case. In fact, we had the farcical case, the international embarrassment, of the Willandra Lakes which was all that is bad about the World Heritage listing process.

The Willandra Lakes case was a rushed nomination that was clearly made for political purposes. We got the boundaries wrong and the most important parts were left out of the area nominated for World Heritage listing. There was no commitment to funding. Some state bureaucrats incorrectly advised us that landowners could no longer use the land. This has festered for more than a decade but, finally, the boundaries have been corrected. Around one‐third of the area is no longer listed because it was not considered to have the sorts of values that required it to be listed. Also, there has at last been some commitment to compensation. A management plan has been developed. In fact, we even acknowledge in the report that what has happened over recent years could perhaps be a model for what could happen in other places.

But it has been over a decade too late. Sadly, reports of the experience of the Willandra Lakes have spread around the country and, naturally, have caused concern in other areas. In the future, when we have an area that we want to nominate, let us first talk about it with the community. We can then develop a management plan and also get the commitment to funding—this is a key element—the ongoing management and development of the area before the nomination is made.

Sadly, we have stored up all of these World Heritage areas but there has been a lack of commitment to fund them to make sure that the maintenance occurs and that the necessary visitor facilities are installed. It has to be said that the Commonwealth managed World Heritage areas such as Kakadu and Uluru have been less disadvantaged in relation to funding than other areas. I think the committee, during its deliberations, visited most of the World Heritage areas. Indeed, the committee has visited all of the World Heritage areas over recent years. The financial assistance that the Commonwealth has provided at Kakadu and Uluru is obvious to any visitor. There are excellent visitor facilities and the standard of management has reached a high level. Sadly, that is not the case in some of the World Heritage areas managed by the states. Queensland has more World Heritage areas than other states but its record is probably the poorest.

Fraser Island in my own electorate was nominated in an atmosphere of great controversy. The Commonwealth and state provided a $51 million compensation package which essentially arose from the parallel decision to stop logging on Fraser Island. But that $51 million package, negotiated between the Goss government and the federal government of the day, has largely disappeared into the sands. There is very little to show for it. Instead of securing the future of the region, as was intended when the package was announced, the money has dissipated into many worthless projects and into activities that have no lasting benefits. There is little to show for the expenditure of that money.

Certainly, some of the projects funded were worthwhile, but they had little to do with securing the future of the region. Money was spent on constructing streets in Maryborough City, including one in front of my own office. Money was transferred into that project though work was completed before Fraser Island was even World Heritage listed. Money was spent on museums, church foundations, a home for the aged and buying rowing shells. They are all very worthwhile things but they had very little to do with the intention of the package.

Money was spent on routine maintenance such as garbage collections. A big package of money was allocated towards a forest thinning project, and for maintenance work on Fraser Island and other places. That sort of work would normally be done as a part of the routine responsibilities of the state parks service and other government offices. What developed was a systematic siphoning of Commonwealth funds into the state coffers by guise of the package funding public servants to do work that they would have done anyhow. There was little lasting benefit to the region.

More importantly, in relation to Fraser Island, no effective community consultation process was put in place before or after the nomination. The local community was overwhelmingly opposed but no effort was ever made to win them over about the merits of World Heritage listing. An interim management committee was established which involved local government leaders and others in the community. That committee has not met for around three years. The community consultation process has broken down. All of these things need to be addressed.

There are similar difficulties with some of the other World Heritage areas where there has been a failure to adequately consult with the people of the region. We came across similar difficulties on Lord Howe Island. So it is not just in the state of Queensland that there are problems. It is obvious that, in many instances, the states have made inadequate efforts to involve the communities actively in ensuring that the World Heritage areas are presented effectively to the interested world community, and also to ensure that the World Heritage area is a good citizen, that it participates in the local community and that its management is commensurate with the wishes of the local community to achieve the objectives of their region.

This report contains some 54 recommendations—a plan for the future. It will require a commitment of more money and resources. I call on the federal government to make an early commitment to provide the financial resources to ensure that these recommendations can be implemented. We need to look after the precious areas that we have.

On occasions there will be a desire to nominate new areas for the list. I hope that the processes in the future will be better than we have had in the past. I thank everyone who has contributed to the report. I think it will play a very useful role in planning Australia's World Heritage management in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to join with the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) in his generous comments on the former member for Fraser, John Langmore. The member for Wide Bay has gained the respect of the people in this House. He has clearly acknowledged people's contributions. As he said, John Langmore has made a great contribution to this particular area over a long period of time.

SPEECH.PARA: I also thank the honourable member, on behalf of the Labor Party, for his kind comments on Neville Newell and Bob Chynoweth, who also have a long history in and commitment to this area. I also join with the honourable member in his comments about the former member, Bruce Lloyd. I think it was a very appropriate addition to his speech. Members of the Labor Party thank him.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Bob Horne.
—Yes, and for his comments on Bob Horne, the former member for Paterson. I thank him for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also acknowledge what a privilege it was to work with the former member for Fraser, John Langmore. I have read his articles dealing with a return to the Bretton Woods system, and also the book he wrote recently on return to work for all. Work for All was published about a year ago. I also acknowledge the work of the current chairman who gave us a lot of guidance and who, of course, had been part of the previous inquiry. That was very useful.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened this morning to the contribution of the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), the ALP spokesman on tourism. He devoted the whole of his speech to the environmental management charge on the Great Barrier Reef. In talking on a report such as this dealing with World Heritage areas, I would have thought that a tourism spokesman for the ALP would have mentioned the park at Uluru, Kakadu, the Tasmanian wilderness, the Wet Tropics in Queensland, Fraser Island, Shark Bay, the Naracoorte fossil sites, the Riversleigh fossil sites, or the Willandra Lakes.

However, the member for Cunningham did not mention them. He focused instead on the environmental management charge of th Great Barrier Reef. It is very interesting to read what the committee actually said about that charge. On page 183 of the report the committee said:

The Committee considers that where it is feasible to collect fees, they should be more than a token amount. It supports the move in the 1996‐97 Budget to increase the environmental management fee by $5 . . .

Who signed off on that report? The ALP members of that committee were the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), the former member for Fraser, the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), who is the shadow environment minister, and last of all the member for Cunningham—the man who this morning spent 15 minutes talking about the environmental management charge. The member for Cunningham, the honourable S.P. Martin MP, signed off on this report.

I would have thought that a shadow spokesman for tourism who signed off on a report like this would have at least read the report first. I know there was a minister in a previous government, Ros Kelly, who used to sign off on things such as environment packages before reading them. But I would have thought that before he signed off on this report the member for Cunningham would have read it. I remember someone on our own side—I think it was the member for Fadden, in 1991 or 1992—who signed a report that contradicted his own party's policy at that stage.

But for the member for Cunningham to come in here this morning and devote the whole of his speech to the environmental management charge shows a disrespect for the important parliamentary work done in committees—I acknowledge that he did do some work in committees in the late 1980s and early 1990s relating to banking—and it shows a disregard for the other 10 World Heritage areas in Australia.

His concern with the environmental management charge shows a neglect of the very people who elected him. He came here as a representative of the people of Wollongong. What he is saying to them is that it is all right that they pay a lot of taxes through their own income; it is all right that they pay an incredible amount in wholesale sales tax; but it is unacceptable for the government to increase a charge on visitors to the Great Barrier Reef from $1 to $6.

When he talks about a 500 per cent increase, admittedly that sounds horrific. But when you consider that it is an increase from $1 to $6—that is an increase roughly equivalent to the price of a hamburger—and the average price of a package to the Great Barrier Reef is something like $130, it puts the matter in perspective. If people actually make a decision to visit the Great Barrier Reef an increase of $5 is unlikely to make any difference to their decision.

In its submission to this committee, the Department of Finance actually regarded the $1 charge as being on the low side and more of a token charge. And there was feeling, even from the acting executive officer of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, that the market would probably bear something much higher than the $1 that is in place at the moment. Five dollars a day was mentioned as the possible charge, but increasing the charge was seen as presenting considerable difficulties.

In looking at some of the other World Heritage areas—and Australia does have 11 of them; the member for Cunningham mentioned only one of them—during the course of the inquiry, the committee, of which I was a member, travelled to Kakadu and we found that Kakadu is, by and large, well funded and well managed. The key question while we were there revolved around whether Kakadu and also the park at Uluru should be managed by the Commonwealth or handed back to the Northern Territory.

The Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory argued that having the Commonwealth run Uluru and Kakadu—it is run by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency—was expensive, was an administrative duplication and was inconsistent with the constitutional development of the Northern Territory. There have been some votes in the last week which they might also see as being inconsistent with the constitutional development of the Northern Territory. The Tourism Council of Australia in its submission said that it would support handing the management of the World Heritage areas at Uluru and Kakadu in the Northern Territory back to the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory.

The feeling of the committee was that a transfer could only be effected with the agreement of the traditional owners. The evidence that we gained was that, while on one hand the Gagadju, the board at Kakadu and the Anangu of Uluru opposed the transfer, on the other hand the Jawoyn Association, which has land both in Nitmiluk National Park and in Kakadu, said in a letter to the Prime Minister that they would like to be dealing with one body, presumably the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory. They had no objections to a transfer of the Jawoyn area of Kakadu back to the Parks and Wildlife Commission.

What was evident from our trip was that relations between ANCA and the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission had deteriorated. Our concern was that, without any cooperation, that deterioration would be evident in areas such as weed and feral animal control. Therefore, in two of our recommendations we felt that, before transfer back to the Northern Territory could be considered, the relationship between ANCA and the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory needed to be re‐established.

We suggested a number of ways in which that could be done. It had been the practice in the past that through a mutual agreement the officers of the Northern Territory Conservation Commission, now the Parks and Wildlife Commission, had worked in Kakadu and Uluru. We suggested that they re‐introduce that practice and have some of the Northern Territory officers working in the park. We also suggested that the Northern Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission should be involved as observers at board meetings, in order to re‐establish the relationship between ANCA and the Northern Territory.

There are, as I said, 11 Australian sites listed as World Heritage areas, owing to their universal natural and/or cultural significance. As a signatory to UNESCO's convention concerning the protection of the world cultural and natural heritage, the Commonwealth is responsible for the conservation, preservation and presentation to the public of these sites. Most sites are managed by the states, with Commonwealth oversight, the exceptions being Uluru and Kakadu, which I have just mentioned. As we would all be aware, the Commonwealth can use the external affairs power to intervene if the states fail to protect the values of those World Heritage areas.

Such intervention has characterised some of the environmental battles of the past 20 years, revolving around the differing responsibilities and roles that the Commonwealth and states have had. The examples of the banning of sandmining on Fraser Island—which, I might add, occurred before Fraser Island was listed as a World Heritage site—and the prevention of the building of the dam in the Tasmanian wilderness, a prevention which relied on the Tasmanian wilderness being a World Heritage area, highlight Commonwealth government intervention in the area of the environment.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of funding, the committee felt that Kakadu and Uluru‐Kata Tjuta were well funded by the Commonwealth, but that in areas managed by the states, with some top‐up funding from the Commonwealth, there should be two principles which established the level of funding. The first was that the state government should fund the areas to the level that they were funded at prior to being listed as World Heritage areas, and that the Commonwealth should provide top‐up funding to raise the standard and also to preserve and present the values that allowed the areas to be listed as World Heritage areas. The second was that agreement—which, as the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) has highlighted, has not always been there—should be reached between the state governments and the Commonwealth on the amount of funding that each should contribute.

In my own state of South Australia we have only one World Heritage site and that is the fossil site at the Naracoorte Caves Conservation Park. When the previous chairman, the former member for Fraser visited the caves, he considered that they were well run and that they were managing quite well with limited funding.

Unfortunately, as the member for Wide Bay has already mentioned, Fraser Island and the Riversleigh fossil site were identified as two World Heritage areas which lacked adequate funding and had problems in terms of information sites, the way the values were presented to the public and the way in which they were highlighted as World Heritage sites.

All World Heritage areas should consider the need for cost recovery measures to supplement government funding. It is important to establish the principles which should dictate how user fees should operate. And that was dealt with in recommendation 53. In that, we asked the department to review user fees in the World Heritage areas, and to establish how user fees should be administered and set.
This is the first report that I have been involved in. It is a very interesting report and it has been a great privilege to be a part of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, just before I move that the vote be adjourned, I would like with your indulgence to add to the comments about the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who was the chair of the ERA committee in the previous parliament. I was privileged to serve through quite an amount of that time as his deputy. John Langmore is a person who is greatly admired and his commitment, especially to the environment, is widely recognised. He thoroughly enjoyed working on this particular report on the World Heritage areas.

SPEECH.PARA: As we toured around the country visiting various areas, Mr Langmore could also indulge one of his passions: birdwatching. He was a great twitcher. When we visited Lord Howe Island, I called out at one stage, `John, John, there's an orange pacific booby.' Swinging around with his binoculars he said, `My God, where?' He was the only person I know who could have been disappointed to see a particularly well‐developed young woman in an orange bathing costume. He was greatly disappointed. But he was a fine chairman and he did a lot of work on this report, and I would like to put that on record.
Debate (on motion by Mr Eoin Cameron) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Mr Bartlett:

BREAK.PARA: That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset I put on the record my commendation of the chairman and the committee for the conduct of this inquiry. It is traditional to have that kind of backslapping, but I mean that very genuinely. The committee visited the central areas where this is important—Port Lincoln, Perth and Hobart—and where there are very substantial localised issues. The overall conduct of the inquiry was, indeed, commendable.

SPEECH.PARA: These agreements are interrelated with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the agreement on straddling fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks.

The thrust of the committee's concerns was that in the area of by‐catch there was a fear that current abatement processes might drag on to the point where that might act as a factor in delaying action. We have the current investigation of that. Obviously, there were concerns about the rights of those people who indulge in fishing as a hobby. They were the thrust of the concerns.

The agreements are argued for on the basis of our negotiating leverage with the Japanese; the access fee that we receive; the protection of the southern bluefin tuna stocks; species monitoring; the funding of research; and, as was indicated by the earlier comment, the meeting of international treaty requirements.

I must say that I am not as convinced as others about the `high access fee'. It is very questionable that we actually know the value of this produce on the Japanese market. I have seen estimates of $94 million. We tend to be too inclined to look at a comparison of ourselves with countries that are not really in a very strong negotiating position. We only have to look at the events in Vanuatu over the last month or so to see some of the infrastructure that is lacking in those countries affecting their ability to deal with major powers. The Solomon Islands is another instance. I appreciate that South Africa was one comparison made to the committee and maybe they could say we are in a reasonable position in what we have accomplished compared to South Africa. But with the dislocation there in the last few years I do not know how strong their bureaucracy is in its ability to deal with these kinds of issues.

I do think the committee has to keep under review whether we are getting a reasonable deal out of this. At the same time, we do have to be careful in dealing with the Japanese that we do not force them out of the system and thereby endanger the species by their non‐involvement. The committee dealt with the threat of non‐involvement of Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and others. That is a matter that the government has to keep under serious review.

The one thing that did concern me—and this is probably a personal view and did not concern other members of the committee—was that the Australian tuna boat owners have a very close connection with the Japanese market. Although I can understand their personal requirements and commercial interests, I did have a fear that their very positive attitude towards the Japanese involvement was perhaps affected to some degree by that interrelationship. We have to be very careful when people have these commercial tie‐ups that, whilst they might perceive themselves as arguing from the basis of Australia's national requirements, perhaps their position is constrained by those realities. In the long term I see a need for us to be vigilant when they argue that we have gained the technology or the knowledge. As I say, they are very closely entwined with the Japanese market and that is a factor in how we review this industry.

BREAK.PARA: Returning to the thrust of the inquiry, we have advocated more training for the observers to increase their knowledge of seabird research, the collection of data on seabird by‐catch and the effectiveness of by‐catch mitigation measures. While the committee could not arrive at an unquestioned determination, there have been claims that although there seemed to be a reasonable presence of observers there have been instances where there was a correlation between the observers' presence and the reports of by‐catch or other concerns in the field. The thrust of the inquiry was around the question of seabird by‐catch and I want to commend the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) on this issue. If any member of the committee really did focus on this issue throughout, it was him and the committee's report owes something to his determination to put that issue forward, particularly on the question of the albatross.

We must be concerned that since the 1952 arrival of the Japanese in the long‐line industry there seems to be an increasing danger to the albatross and related species. It was interesting to read the information about the albatross that came to the attention of the committee. Its survival is very much a hairline exercise, not just because of by‐catch but throughout history. Albatrosses take 11 years to start breeding and they only produce one egg every second year. Those are all factors, as well as the fact that the female does tend to forage in areas where long‐line fishing is prevalent. They are also not all one species and those from different islands, such as the Antipodes, Auckland, Tristan da Cunha, are very much endangered.

It is worth noting the comments of Nature Australia in the winter of 1995. Their claim is that 50,000 had been killed in Australian and New Zealand waters, and I think this puts the issue where it is at:

As an expanding world population demands more from the ocean's resources, the task of protecting vulnerable species will not become easier. Our inadequate knowledge of albatross populations, their greater dependence on resources in international waters and their insignificant economic value result in complex political issues and no funds for research. Raising the funds to apply this technology is an urgent task as a diminishing population increases the difficulty of acquisition of knowledge essential for their survival.

So, when we take into consideration the fact that they do take 11 years to breed, every second year, that they basically need a 32 to 33 per cent survival rate to sustain themselves and the average one has to reach 30 years before it essentially replaces itself, there are concerns. I am pleased to say that the committee's emphasis is on measures that put this in the forefront.

Similarly, with the by‐catch of other fish species there is a very strong emphasis by this committee not that we seek to minimise the numbers but that we actually are proactive in trying to eliminate it as much as possible. Of course, the report goes into various alternatives: night setting, where there are indications of a 70 to 96 per cent reduction; the question of bait throwing gear, which is already, as I understand it, used on over 100 Japanese boats; the investigation in New Zealand and Norway of setting lines under water by a hydraulic ram to send the bait down; and forward baits. All of these things should be followed through very strongly, and I think it is fair to say that the committee is very supportive of activities in those fields.

In conclusion, the committee has given approval to the treaty. It emphasises throughout the need for greater information. It does express concern because of the circumvention of Australian ownership of vessels; it does extend the boundaries on the Tasmanian coast. But overall it does express a concern that we must put the conservation measures to the fore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I thank the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) both for his comments this morning and for his contribution to the committee. Both have been substantial. I will come back at the end of my contribution this morning to say a little bit more conceptually about this committee and what it is about in this parliament. But let me start off by saying that this particular report, which is the third report of four that have been tabled since the committee was set up as a result of our government's initiative in May, is a little different from the other three. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Truss, as a member of the committee, three of the four that have been tabled have dealt with specific treaties that have been tabled under the so‐called 15‐day rule. This is slightly different in that it is an issue that was thought by the committee to be appropriate to test the waters, in many ways, to see what a specific bilateral agreement was all about and to see the level to which the community and government organisations wanted to become involved. As a result of all that, quite apart from the magnitude and the size of the report and the issues that it covers, I think it reinforces the wisdom of what we are doing as a parliament in terms of the treaty making processes and the reforms thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an important report in that it deals specifically with a bilateral agreement between Japan and Australia in terms of southern bluefin tuna. The committee also took the opportunity, about two‐thirds of the way through the couple of months of inquiry, to pick up the suggestions from the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission. These issues are embodied in the report.

This is an important report at ministerial level for a number of ministers, and not simply because of its size—the report was prepared in very short order—and the issues that it raises. At the global level, it is important for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), in terms of the treaty‐making process, and for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), in terms of resource implications. It is also important for Senator Parer, in his responsibility as resources minister, and specifically the fishing industry. It is an important report for the state governments that were very heavily involved in our inquiries on this matter.

It is also important to some of the peak bodies and the non‐government organisations, notably, the Tuna Boat Owners Association of Australia. We hope it will be a valuable tool to enhance and improve what is already a very healthy situation in that industry. Hopefully, as a result of this report, and if ministers and government agree, some of the initiatives reflected in the recommendations will be helpful in enhancing the diplomatic and commercial relationships with our important partner—that is, Japan.
