As the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) indicated, the report gets into wider issues than the treaties committee intended with this particular one. I think the report will be an important tool for the house committee which, as I understand it, is dealing with the more global issue of fishing resources and the fishing industry. I know that the secretariat of that committee is looking at it and we hope it will assist them in resolving some of the issues and, inevitably, some of the problems within that particular industry.

As I said, this report is different from the other three that have been tabled in the House, the last, of course, on Monday of last week. The report deals specifically with the subsidiary agreement between Japan and Australia on long‐line tuna fishing. It also makes some valuable comments and recommendations in relation to the agreement on the establishment of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission. I am delighted that Senator Parer has announced—I think in the last week—that Australia is to become party to that commission. This highlights the fact that government can react to some of the recommendations that this committee has made in very short order and we welcome that.

BREAK.PARA: I will read into the record a number of the benefits of the subsidiary agreement between Japan and Australia because I think they are very important. I will then very briefly highlight one or two of the recommendations. The report makes the point that the benefits of the agreement to Australia include: a high access fee by international standards—the honourable member for Reid questioned whether it is high in relative terms but, in general terms, the feeling is that the access fee is high—no damage to Australian fisheries as Japan uses its own quota of southern bluefin tuna and highly migratory species such as yellowfin or bigeye, ensuring that southern bluefin tuna stocks are not further reduced; monitoring of species stocks that would otherwise not be possible, or would be difficult and expensive; and access to the Japanese fleet to influence their seabird avoidance practices.

The report talks about economic benefits. Those economic benefits, of course, are very substantial whether you look at the direct benefits or the multiplier effect. There is some argument as to what the multiplier effect is. It varies between about two and five but if you look at the direct economic impact in a port like Fremantle, for example, and apply a multiplier, it does have arguably an economic plus of about $70 million to $80 million to the Australian economy.

It provides the Australian government with some leverage in other negotiations within the commission on southern bluefin tuna. It provides us with access to Japanese data on fishing locations which is very important. It provides access to Japanese data on shared stocks outside the Australian fishing zone. It enables the collection of biological samples. It, in fact, provides direct funding for research on tuna and billfish. It should be pointed out that the Japanese contribution to that is substantial and without this bilateral agreement that would not happen. Of course, as the honourable member for Reid highlighted, it is part of meeting Australia's commitments under the umbrella United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea obligations.

We also make mention in the report of the disadvantages to Australia of not concluding the agreement. We hope that there is no consideration given to not concluding the agreement but we have reinforced our view by making the points that the disadvantages would be substantial and could include the potential environmental and financial losses. I forgot to mention that among the ministers who are involved here, an important minister who has more than a casual interest in what this report says is the Minister for the Environment. There is a very large element in this report in terms of by‐catch and mitigation measures et cetera that we hope the government will pick up and implement.

We point out the financial loss as a result of the loss of the access fee; the fisheries relationship with Japan in diplomatic and commercial terms; and the regular forum of communication with Japan albeit that that is always difficult. Japanese are hard negotiators as the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) would know and I hope he will say something about this in due course. I will say a bit more about the benefits from port access arrangements in a moment. As far as accurate and timely information on technological developments are concerned, the Japanese have been very influential with Australian tuna fishermen in transferring some of that technology. I suggest that this would not have happened without this particular bilateral agreement.

Australia's influence over Japanese fishing operations in relation to by‐catch has already been mentioned. Funds for management and research would need to be sourced from Australian industry or would not be available. That is reinforced in the report. We obtain overall valuable information in terms of the fishery and fishery stocks within our fishing zone.
In the short time left to me, I will make mention of three issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that half an hour ago!

—You will have your chance, Mr Price. There are three specific recommendations I would just like to highlight. One is in terms of the periodicity of the bilateral agreement. It has been one year. We are recommending at least two years for a number of reasons that I do not have time to go into. We think it is very desirable that the duration of that bilateral report is extended and I understand that Senator Parer, for example, is reasonably disposed towards that but it has to go through the bureaucratic processes.

BREAK.PARA: The second recommendation I would highlight is the one in relation to Tasmania and the 50 nautical mile recommendation for southern bluefin tuna. At the moment Tasmania is restricted to a 15 nautical mile limit. We, on balance, felt the limit should be consistent right across the country, and we recommend that Tasmania extend its exclusion zone to 50 nautical miles. We commend that recommendation to ministers and to the government.

The other recommendation I would like to highlight concerns port access and the separation of port access and quota. It took up a lot of our time in inquiries and in consideration in committee. We have come down very strongly on this view, which I would like to read into the record:
The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties recommends the separation of port access from the subsidiary agreement but—
with this caveat—

making port access subject to the continuation of Japan's membership of the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna and participation in the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna.
That is an important caveat, which we hope will enable the negotiations to continue and to enhance what are already reasonable arrangements.

I conclude by reiterating what the honourable member for Reid said about countries outside the bluefin tuna commission. There are some other important nations that fish on the high seas—namely, Indonesia, Taiwan and Korea—and the People's Republic of China is becoming an increasing player in this area as well. We hope that this agreement can, in due course, bring those countries in under the umbrella of the commission.

Mr Deputy Speaker, my final point is in relation to the reforms that were announced earlier this year and embodied in the formation of this committee. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) said in the House in question time yesterday, what this government is about is consultation with, and accountability to, the Australian people. That is what the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is all about. I regret to say, to be party political for a moment, that is what the other side did not do in government. We are out to reverse those perceptions and—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had the tap on the shoulder, too.

—In reply to the honourable member for Chifley, I want to finish by making a very final point, and that is in relation to the bipartisanship of this committee. It is a strong team. The members include the honourable member for Reid and the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss). I could not let the opportunity go by without making a particular point about the deputy chair, the honourable member for Barton (Mr McClelland), who has provided very strong support to me as chair, and also specifically about the secretariat—Peter Stephens and, for this particular report, Cheryl Scarlett. Cheryl put it all together in very short order. It is a very readable report, which I commend to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not often that I get the opportunity to have the drop on the chairman of a committee—in this case, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who has just completed his contribution. I want to take up the last point that he made. In the last parliament I well recall the current Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) talking about their proposal for a treaties committee. I believe that, in this place, the best defence is always truth and honesty. I have to say that not only did I have some reservations about the proposal but, at best, I was indifferent to it and probably a little sceptical about it. I certainly felt that having a committee that dealt with nothing but treaties was perhaps not the best approach and that utilising the existing committee structure was probably a better approach.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that members on both sides—to be fair—in the last parliament were unhappy about the inadequate addressing of treaties. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties has, in my view, proven itself, notwithstanding the shameless dorothy dixer asked by the honourable member for Groom yesterday. It has worked, and the fact that it encompasses a wide range of different subjects does not in any way seem to be impeding its good work.

For anything that adds to this parliament, I am always grateful, and I think that the treaties committee is doing that. I note, for example, in the report that we are talking about, that 45 submissions does not break the record, but it is 45 more than we would have received in the old parliament. The great virtue of the committee system is that, when a committee is run well, it opens the parliament up to the people. Just when we are facing the new millennium or the 100th year of federation, members of both houses need to be conscious that we are extending opportunities for ordinary citizens, in particular, to access the parliament, to be in touch with parliament and understand what it is doing. I congratulate the honourable member for Groom. I congratulate all of the committee members—I think they are doing a very good job. I am not a member of this particular committee.

Turning to the subject matter of the report, I also acknowledge the role of John Langmore, who was the chairman of the environment committee. As you know, he has retired. John has many virtues which were not always recognised in this place. One has been a commitment to the environment, particularly in his role as chairman of the environment committee. I have noticed, since I have been a member, that more and more people in the cities are becoming more and more concerned about environmental issues.

Fisheries is a particularly sensitive issue. As citizens of this world—I know that is a term some people do not like using, but we are all citizens of Australia and also citizens of this world—we have witnessed the extinction of some fishing stocks, where they have been absolutely fished out. In America, there have been the sardines and in Europe, the cod. There is quite a list of them.

We cannot treat fisheries or what is in our ocean as an inexhaustible supply. We have to be conscious that we owe it to future generations to preserve what we already have so that we do not lose any more species, and to ensure that species are not over‐fished. This becomes very difficult when some countries, in terms of diet, are heavily reliant on fish and think that they have almost a unilateral right to fish to meet that demand.

BREAK.PARA: That is, I guess, my general position. I also wanted to say, in terms of Australia and the environment, that I notice that school children these days are far better environmentalists than my generation ever was. There are probably a number of explanations for that: the impact of TV, of communications. In particular—and again, this is probably not fashionable—I would compliment the teachers in schools for the sense of awareness they are creating in a generation of younger Australians about the environment. I commend them.
The chairman of the committee really left me very little say. I think he ran through every recommendation and every conclusion in the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's thorough!

—Very thorough, and I note he was going to finish his speaking time on a number of occasions. I am particularly interested in the issue of by‐catch in the report and I want to commend the committee. I note that there are a number of recommendations dealing with the principal by‐catch which is birds—albatross and some other species. I will not run through the list. I think by‐catch, in all aspects of fishing, is a particularly important and serious problem. We do need to develop either techniques of fishing or management that eliminate by‐catch problems.

BREAK.PARA: In this case, of course, I am talking about the bird life, but in other cases it can refer to other species of fish that are just thrown out. And whilst we have undertaken a deal of research into those catches that have an economic value and are much sought after, unfortunately there is not a lot of research done on those species that form part of the by‐catch problem.

In conclusion, I think the government got it right in setting up the treaties committee; the committee has already, at this early stage, proved itself and I congratulate the Chairman and all members of the committee. This is a particularly good report and I am pleased at the way the committee structure has allowed treaty making to be opened up to ordinary Australians.
Debate (on motion by Mr Eoin Cameron) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Mr Sharp:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased again to have the opportunity to contribute to the debate today, this time in the Main Committee, on the question of civil aviation safety in Australia. The discussion today relates to the report that was done by Commissioner Staunton into relations between the Civil Aviation Authority, as it then was, and Seaview Air.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in the House previously on this matter, this report makes very disturbing reading. When you actually go through the detail in the report you can see that not only is there a very strong pattern of deliberate flouting of civil aviation regulations by the operator on a very wide range of issues, there is also an equally strong pattern of the regulator, in effect, conniving in this flouting of regulations—ignoring it and allowing the operator to continue flouting the regulations. Ultimately, this was in gross dereliction of its duty as a regulator.

Responsibility for this has been sheeted home to a couple of key officials within CASA who, thankfully, as a result of the findings of Commissioner Staunton's report, have since paid the consequences. Nonetheless, it does give a very disturbing picture of the situation within the then Civil Aviation Authority and it fits very well with a similar picture that was presented by Mr Peter Gould, the Coroner, in his inquiry into the Monarch crash, which was only a month distant from the Seaview crash. Both occurred in a very dark period for aviation safety in Australia.

Some of the issues that are dealt with in the Seaview report include: the operation of a regular passenger transport service without authorisation—Seaview was only supposed to be a charter operator but it was de facto operating as an RPT service; regular overloading of the planes; regular siting of unrestrained cargo inside planes; a variety of defects in maintenance with respect to instrumentation and equipment; and, for a period of time, flying without an appropriate maintenance release.

What we see in the Seaview report is a picture of an operator, Mr Green, who clearly had an absolute disregard for the basic safety and security of his customers; who was concerned to make money and was quite happy to cut corners in order to pursue profit; who was quite happy to put extreme pressure on his pilots in order to ensure that they complied with his wishes rather than their obligations to the passengers, their professional obligations as pilots, and their obligations to the public in accordance with the civil aviation safety regulations.

Mr Green does not emerge very well from this report and I share the concern of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to ensure that Mr Green no longer conducts any form of passenger transport service in the aviation industry, given the attitude that he has demonstrated and given his subsequent behaviour and apparent lack of contrition as a result of the findings of the report.

Of equal concern emerging from the report was the finding that the relevant Civil Aviation Authority officer at the time, Mr Paul, had virtually deliberately failed to carry out his duties to properly surveil the Seaview operation. On numerous occasions he was presented with clear evidence of breaches of regulations and other serious breaches—not trivial breaches, not technical breaches, but serious breaches—and on each occasion he seemed to bend over backwards almost deliberately to avoid taking any action. He took the word of the operator and failed to follow through on investigations. Clearly, he was biased in favour of the operator and was doing everything he could to ensure that the Civil Aviation Authority did not impede Seaview's capacity to operate in spite of the very clear evidence that serious deficiencies in the Seaview operation were apparent and that any reasonable regulator would have addressed those deficiencies.

Of similar concern is the behaviour of his superior, Mr Bryant, who failed to properly manage and to supervise his subordinate and clearly was complicit in the failure of regulatory enforcement that was involved. The failures of both of these officers are highlighted by the fact that there was, indeed, a conscientious officer, a whistleblower, within the CAA, Mr Hoy, who, as a result of his efforts to try to get some action with respect to Seaview, found that the one substantive response was that his ability to do his job was restricted, that certain limitations were imposed on him within the authority which previously were not there, and that his efforts to conscientiously do his job and to conscientiously look after the interests of passengers in aviation transport were met with not only obstruction but also outright penalties and restrictions on his work.

The other thing that is worth observing as a result of this report is that like the report that was done by the Coroner Peter Gould into the Monarch inquiry, there is a clear conclusion that the origins of these problems lie ultimately in the regime within the Civil Aviation Authority in the early 1990s which imposed a perspective known as `affordable safety'. This led to a very drastic reduction in the number of regulatory staff within the authority—under the so‐called review of resources—and which led to a situation where the industry was deemed to be the customer of the authority.

Mr Justice Fisher, the Chair of the Civil Aviation Authority said pertinently that it is long overdue that we parliamentarians, the minister, and people in the authority, realise that the authority is not there to serve the industry; it is there to serve the Australian people. It is there to regulate the industry. It is the policeman of the industry. It is there to serve the Australian public and, in particular, the 30 million passengers that are carried in aviation transport every year. That is whom the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is there to serve, not the industry itself. And that ideology which permeated the organisation in the early 1990s has had disastrous consequences and these can be seen in the Seaview and the Monarch reports.

I have been fortunate earlier this morning to be part of a briefing for the House committee that was conducted by the CEO of CASA, Mr Leroy Keith, and a couple of senior officials. That briefing was designed to inform us in some detail as to the steps that CASA is taking bit by bit to bring itself up to scratch, to eradicate the problems that have clearly contributed to the disasters—one of which we are dealing with today. There is an increase in staff, not only administrative staff, which is necessary because of the separation from Air Services, but also regulatory staff both on the flying operations and airworthiness sides.

There is also provision for better training of regulators, and more standardised procedures to ensure that any particular operator is going to get approximately the same treatment, the same line and the same approach with respect to the enforcement of regulations, no matter what part of the country the operator is in. We have heard of the regulatory review that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development has introduced, and that I applaud. Although the content of the regulations is not the key problem—the key problem has been the enforcement of those regulations—clearly it is appropriate that the regulations be reviewed and brought into line with international numbering and with international standards with respect to precision, lack of ambiguity and the like. So that review is an equally important part of the overall strategy.

CASA is also planning to increase its activities with respect to oversight of international operations in our region, and to ensure that any plane coming in to Australia is subject to an equivalent regime of surveillance in the country of origin. We have planes flying to Australia from a variety of countries and often from very small and poor countries. In some cases, there are questions about the extent to which those planes are surveilled within those countries. CASA is going to step up its operations on that front, a move which I applaud. Another thing that is very clear and that I also applaud is that CASA is fully aware that its obligations are to serve the people of Australia and not to serve the industry, and that CASA is there to regulate the industry.

The minister has had, in the eight or nine months he has been in the ministry, a rather peculiar track record on the issue of aviation safety. We have seen him overrule his own safety regulators with respect to electronic locater transmitters and impose on the Australian people an alternative standard—and we are the only serious civil aviation safety regulator in the world to permit this—which Mr Keith, the head of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, has acknowledged is a lesser standard of safety. And the minister has directly intervened to bring this about.

BREAK.PARA: We have also seen the minister deliberately try to blacken the name of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in order to pursue his very peculiar vendetta against the board of the authority. Mr Keith again made it plain that the board and the minister both support the strategy that CASA management is pursuing to improve performance and to eradicate the problems of the past. In spite of this, the minister is pursuing an extremely peculiar vendetta against both the chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Mr Justice Fisher, and other board members.

As a result, we have seen the situation where, in the case of the recent Falcon Airlines crash, the minister—in seeking to blacken CASA by pointing out that the former owner of Falcon Airlines was now a CASA officer in the same region and by suggesting that there was a conflict of interest issue involved—deliberately failed to point out that, as a condition of his new employment, the person involved, a Mr Killen, was obliged to engage in no regulatory activities and no supervisory activities in respect of his former airline.

Even though there clearly is a question to be considered with respect to the appropriateness of the appointment—let us face it, the source of potentially half of CASA regulatory employees is going to be the aviation industry, because that is where the expertise to regulate civil aviation is going to come from; and so there are always going to be problems of this sort—it is also abundantly clear that there can be no connection between Mr Killen's appointment and any question mark that may exist with respect to CASA's supervision of Falcon Airlines, because he was specifically excluded from being involved in that supervision. But did the minister mention this at any point? No, he did not.

In the same vein, Dr Robert Liddell resigned from the authority as Chief Medical Officer some weeks ago, in a burst of publicity and with a range of accusations. It emerged, following that resignation, that the real reasons he was resigning were that the authority was now refusing to pay the cost of his being trained to fly 767s and that his international travel budget had been reduced—neither of which, I would have thought, were particularly deleterious decisions with respect to the core issues of aviation safety. Minister Sharp has failed to come out and acknowledge that, in this instance, CASA was not in any way in the wrong, and that Dr Liddell had made his decision to resign but that his accusations against CASA were quite clearly ill founded. Has the minister actually acknowledged this in public? Not once. He is engaged in a vendetta against CASA and particularly against the board, for reasons which are very difficult to explain.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they do not. The board have only been in office since mid‐1995, well after this disaster occurred and well after the Monarch disaster occurred. It is abundantly clear that they are both actively involved and supportive of the position that is being adopted by the CASA management. As far as I am concerned, if he does not have confidence in the CASA board then he equally does not have confidence in the CASA director, Mr Keith, in whom, as I have said in the parliament previously, I certainly have confidence. That confidence has been renewed by the discussion we have had today.

BREAK.PARA: The minister has got to start facing up to some facts. Not only is he failing to contribute to the process of renewal and improvement of our aviation safety regulation process which has deteriorated in the early 1990s, as this report indicates, but also, in effect, he is positively undermining it by constantly attacking the organisation which is charged with that responsibility by undermining the morale of the staff who work in that organisation, by the attacks on the board and by the implied attacks on the CEO, Mr Keith. It is high time that he grasped his responsibilities, which are to the 30 million passengers out there who fly, not to small sectional interests in the industry with whom he is very closely associated. They are the people whom we must serve with respect to aviation safety in this country. They are the people whom we have to look after and ensure that they are protected. That is CASA's task. It is not to serve the industry; it is to regulate the industry. It is high time that the minister got behind the authority and the changes that are being made, instead of attacking and undermining it. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 October 1994, nine people died in a plane on their way to a holiday. No doubt their expectations were high as they looked forward to their holiday break on Lord Howe Island.

SPEECH.PARA: Leeca and Anthony Atkinson were starting off on their honeymoon and their new life together. Reg and Pam Drayton were taking a second honeymoon. Parents Stephen and Carol Lake and Judith and Benhamin, two of their children, were excitedly starting off on a family holiday. The young pilot, Paul Sheil, is also a victim of the accident.

The commission of inquiry into the relations between the Civil Aviation Authority, as it then was, and Seaview Air is one of the most disturbing and slamming reports we could have the unhappy obligation to read and take note of. Commissioner Staunton's report is a damning indictment of the CAA and all of its operating processes. In July 1994, the CAA conferred the status of an airline—a regular public transport operator—on Seaview Air. Just 10 weeks later, its flagship, VH‐SVQ, crashed while flying from Williamtown to Lord Howe Island.

This report reveals how an unsafe organisation, Seaview Air, could have the status of regular public transport operator conferred on it and could continue to operate, despite knowledge of lack of safety both within its own organisation and within the so-called regulator, the Civil Aviation Authority, and despite repeated warnings. This report reveals the incompetence of a regulator too shy and toothless to implement the most rudimentary safety standards. This report reveals the slipshod and uncaring attitude of a greedy operator which threw caution to the wind without considering the consequences of putting lives at very real risk.

The nine people who died when that Seaview plane crashed in 1994 would not have known that they were risking their lives by getting on that plane. They would not have known, as did others in the industry and in the CAA, that the airline was essentially unsafe. So widespread was the knowledge of the lack of safety of this airline that when he was a shadow minister, the now Minister for Transport, John Sharp, made warnings in the House about this specific airline.
On 4 May 1994, in the House of Representatives, Minister Sharp, as he is now, when speaking about Seaview's operations, said:
. . . this airline which was operating so dangerously and which was putting people's lives at risk continued to fly.
The minister has subsequently said that it gives him no satisfaction that those concerns were most sadly proven correct by the Seaview crash in October that year.

The terms of reference for this inquiry were to inquire into the operation of the CAA in connection with: firstly, the appropriateness of decisions and administrative actions of officers of the authority relating to the operations of Seaview Air during 1994—and earlier if necessary—including its upgrading to a regular public transport operator; secondly, the diligence and propriety with which officers of the authority and Seaview Air discharged their respective responsibilities relating to the safety of Seaview Air operations and, thirdly, the effectiveness of the management systems within the Civil Aviation Authority and communication between its various levels as they related to Seaview Air. The terms of reference were to include also an examination of the implications of any findings including the measures necessary to ensure total propriety in air safety and administration, or the most appropriate and effective method for the government to consider those findings for the purpose of determining the measures necessary to ensure total propriety in air safety administration.

The report's 39 recommendations are well considered and insightful. They are the result of the contribution of 142 witnesses, over 900 exhibits, 224 days of sitting, and almost 17,000 pages of transcript. They are, given the most essential standards of air safety, absolute commonsense. In this two‐volume report, Commissioner Staunton has noted a number of serious issues which require further attention and almost immediate action. Included amongst these are: firstly, an attitude that characterises breaches of the Civil Aviation Act, regulations and the orders—the attitude is called `aviation trivia'; secondly, a practice of cross hiring that enables an operator to use an aircraft of a type not endorsed on the AOC; thirdly, what can at times be considered widespread disregard by general aviation maintenance organisations for the manufacturers' requirements; fourthly, a practice of pilots overstating flying hours to obtain employment with larger operators; fifthly, the standards and adequacy of pilot training; sixthly, allowing new or relatively inexperienced pilots to fly alone and with passengers with very close to the minimum required flying hours for that particular aircraft type; seventhly, and again, the inadequacy of the maintenance release system; and, eighthly, the importance of the regulatory authority to have adequate information about operators and pilots.

Since earlier this year I have chaired the Sydney aircraft community forum which was established by the new coalition government and is charged with the responsibility of consulting with communities in Sydney affected by aircraft noise and other environmental matters concerned with the operations, primarily, of Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport. For all of us on the committee, safety is paramount to our consideration of the operations of the airport and the delicate balance of ensuring, as a responsible government, that Australia's most significant airport operates effectively, while minimising the inconvenience and environmental implications for Sydney's large number of residents.

As the chairman of the Sydney airport community forum, with its geographically—and I would like to point out—politically diverse membership, and our close relationship with Sydney's residents on this issue, I baulk at the thought that the slipshod and careless attitude which led to the Seaview crash off Lord Howe Island in 1994 could in any way occur in or out of Sydney airport.

Out of all the concerns that have been expressed by Commissioner Staunton in this report, the underlying question has to be: was the Civil Aviation Authority competent in its activities and considerations in the lead‐up to the very tragic Seaview aircraft crash? It is absolutely crucial that the now safety regulator, CASA, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, which was hived off out of part of the body of the Civil Aviation Authority, has as its key consideration the safety of fee paying passengers.

When the Civil Aviation Safety Authority provided a briefing to the Sydney Airport community forum on their day‐to‐day operations, they were unequivocal about their commitment primarily, and almost only, to the safety of fee paying passengers in commercial aircraft. That is absolutely totally appropriate. One of the concerns of the Sydney Airport community forum was—and I think it was a fair concern—that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority does not take into account the safety of some of the passengers that live their daily lives underneath the most busy flight paths in the Sydney basin.

The joint responsibility for safety is not just with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It extends to Airservices Australia and the Federal Airports Corporation and the guiding hand has to come from the Department of Transport. But the dangers are lived by the people of Sydney every day. In fact, the commuters of Australia are living daily with the possible threat of a major aviation disaster. It gives no comfort at all to the people of Sydney that the Civil Aviation Authority, as it once was, has been found, by Commissioner Staunton, to have some of the most irregular and unsophisticated work practices of any safety authority in Australia. Imagine if the 20.5 million passengers who flew in and out of Sydney Airport last year were subject to the same risk as those nine unfortunate people flying on board Seaview to Lord Howe Island were. Imagine if the 269,000 aircraft movements to and from Sydney Airport last year had the odds stacked up against them in the same way that the Seaview plane had the odds stacked up against it.

Thankfully, there are some redeeming factors. The commercial airlines that operate out of Sydney airport have higher standards than Seaview Air. This report reveals all too fully the fact that Seaview Air was a shoddy organisation. It was run for the most base principles of making money, getting the planes up in the air and getting the passengers out. There was total disregard for some of the most basic elements of civil aviation safety. For example, there was a failure to comply with the basic requirements of regular passenger transport. There were extensive defects on the planes and maintenance was regarded as poor. Also, one of the most obvious requirements of air safety—flying with the proper maintenance release—was often not complied with. Often the planes were overloaded as they were flying off to Lord Howe Island—sometimes up to 130 kilograms overloaded. That is one of the concerns, I might add, of the Sydney Airport community forum—that the courier planes and the transport planes that are departing and arriving into Sydney Airport during the curfew hours may not be complying with the load requirements for the airport and for the individual planes.

There is also strong evidence of excessive work hours for pilots. Sometimes the pilots would understate the number of hours in their trip. In fact, in the report, there is one incident where the Civil Aviation Authority safety officer was in the cockpit with the pilot of the plane flying to Lord Howe Island.

If I remember my figures correctly, the flight was a six‐hour flight. But the pilot recorded 4½ hours and he had the Civil Aviation Authority safety officer in the cockpit next to him during the flight. So, where it suited them, there was an excessive recording of work hours for pilots to get their flying hours up and, on the other hand, they understated the flying hours. It does indicate there is a deeper problem in the aviation industry with some of the smaller operators and with what pilots will do to keep their jobs, which are very hard to find in commercial enterprises.

A lot of people leave school, go and spend a lot of money, raise a lot of money to learn how to fly, and then they are desperate to get their flying hours up and the only way they can do that is with a commercial operator. It was shown that when Seaview Air was operating at an earlier date, the owner of the airline was particularly harsh on the younger pilots, making sure that they worked longer hours and did not receive the proper awards.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has given me some level of comfort out of his briefing with CASA this morning. He said that there will be an increase in the number of staff, particularly in relation to regulation. He said that there will be better training for regulators and that there is an increased oversight of international airlines, which is a major problem at the moment. So there is some comforting factor but there is still some way to go.
In this report, Commissioner Staunton said:
The public safety demands high standards of diligence and integrity by both the regulator and the industry.

There is an obligation to ensure that the regulator is not institutionally timid, as was the criticism of the CAA with regard to Seaview. The regulator is there to protect the passengers. The nine people who died off Lord Howe Island deserved better than what they received. Air passengers, in trusting their lives to airline operators in every plane flying in and out of Australian skies, deserve better than that. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 November, 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the total sum of tax deductions claimed for political donations in 1994‐95.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The value of tax deductions claimed for political donations cannot be separately identified from tax deductions claimed for all donations and gifts. In the 1994‐95 income year approximately 3.2 million tax payers claimed tax deductions of $495.3 million for all donations and gifts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many court counsellors are employed by the Family Court of Australia on a (a) full‐time, (b) part‐time and (c) casual basis.
(2) What was the total cost of court counsellors in the most recent year for which figures are available.
(3) What is the average hourly cost for court based counselling.
(4) Were private counsellors engaged; if so, (a) on how many occasions and (b) what was the (i) total, (ii) average and (iii) hourly cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised by the Family Court of the following information:
(1)(a) Full‐time counsellors employed by the Court in 1995/96—125; (b) Part‐time counsellors employed by the Court in 1995/96—26; and (c) Casual counsellors employed by the Court in 1995/96—4.
